text.eng: I.— THE STORY OF ARION.
text.lat: I.— FABULA ARIONIS.

text.eng: Arion, after travelling abroad, hires a vessel to take him home.
text.lat: Arion, postquam peregre profectus est, navem conducit ut eum domum reducet.

1.— Arion citharista praeclarus erat. Is diu apud Periandrum Corinthiorum regem versatus erat. Tum in Italiam Siciliamque navigare cupivit. Ingentibus opibus ibi comparatis, Corinthum redire voluit. Itaque Tarento, urbe Italiae, profectus est; ibi navigium hominum Corinthiorum conduxerat.
text.eng: 1.— Arion was a famous lyre player. He had spent a long time at the court of Periander, king of the Corinthians. Then he wished to sail to Italy and Sicily. Having acquired great wealth there, he wished to return to Corinth. Therefore, he set out from Tarentum, a city of Italy, where he had hired a ship of Corinthian men.
The sailors form a plan to rob and murder him.
text.lat: Nautae consilium faciunt ut eum spolient et interficiant.

2.— Hi autem eum in mare proiicere constituerunt; pecunia enim potiri cupiebant. Tum vero Arion consilium intellexit. Tristis ad preces confugit. Pecunia omni nautis oblata, vitam deprecatus est. Nautae vero precibus viri non commoti, mortem ei statim minati sunt.
text.eng: 2.— These, however, decided to throw him into the sea; for they desired to seize the money. Then indeed Arion understood their plan. He sadly resorted to pleas. Offering all his money to the sailors, he begged for his life. But the sailors, unmoved by the man's prayers, immediately threatened him with death.
Arion sings a beautiful song, and leaps overboard.
text.lat: Arion carmen pulchrum canit, et in mare se proiecit.

3.— In has angustias redactus Arion, in puppi stetit, omni ornatu suo indutus. Tum unum e carminibus canere incepit. Nautae suavi carmine capti e puppi mediam in navem concesserunt. Ille omni ornatu indutus, capta cithara, carmen peregit. Cantu peracto in mare se proiecit. Tum nautae Corinthum navigaverunt.
text.eng: 3.— Reduced to these straits, Arion stood on the stern, dressed in his full attire. Then he began to sing one of his songs. The sailors, captivated by the sweet song, withdrew from the stern to the middle of the ship. He, clad in his entire attire, having taken up his lyre, completed the song. With the song finished, he threw himself into the sea. Then the sailors sailed to Corinth.
He is miraculously saved by a dolphin.
text.lat: A delphino mirabiliter servatus est.

4.— Arion autem a delphine exceptus dorso Taenarum delatus est. Egressus in terram, Corinthum cum eodem habitu contendit. Ibi nautarum facta narravit. Periander autem ei credere noluit. Arion igitur in custodia ab eo retentus est.
text.eng: 4.— Arion, however, having been taken up by a dolphin, was carried on its back to Taenarum. Upon reaching land, he went to Corinth in the same attire. There he narrated the deeds of the sailors. But Periander did not want to believe him. Therefore, Arion was kept in custody by him.
The wicked sailors are detected and punished, and Arion is rewarded.
text.lat: Scelerati nautae deprehenduntur et puniuntur, et Arion praemiatur.

5.— Interim nautae Corinthum advenerunt. A Periandro interrogati sunt de Arione. Turpissime mentiti sunt omnes. Subito Arion apparuit cum eodem ornatu. Attoniti nautae scelus confitentur. A rege Periandro omnes interfecti sunt, et multum pecuniae Arioni datum est.
text.eng: 5.— Meanwhile the sailors arrived at Corinth. They were questioned by Periander about Arion. They all lied most disgracefully. Suddenly Arion appeared in the same attire. The astonished sailors confessed their crime. All were put to death by King Periander, and much money was given to Arion.

text.lat: II.— THE HABITS OF THE MASSAGETAE.
text.eng: II.—MOS MASSAGETARUM.

text.lat: 6.— Utuntur Massagetae et vestimento et vitae ratione simili Scytharum. Ex equis pugnant; arcu et hastis utuntur. Ad omnia auro utuntur aut aere. Ad hastas, ad sagittarum cuspides aere utuntur; ad capitis ornatum, et ad lumborum cingula, auro. Argentum et ferrum in eorum terra non reperiuntur; sed aeris et auri est immensa copia.
text.eng: 6.— The Massagetae use clothing and a way of life similar to the Scythians. They fight on horseback; they use bows and lances. For everything they use gold or bronze. For lances, for the points of arrows, they use bronze; for ornament of the head, and for belts, gold. Silver and iron are not found in their land; but there is an immense abundance of bronze and gold.

text.lat: Senes interficiunt propinqui, et pecudes cum iis; cocta carne deinde epulantur. Terra autem condunt morbo mortuos. Sementem nullam faciunt: cibus eorum ex pecoribus, piscibus, lacte, constat. Deorum unum Solem colunt: huic equos immolant.
text.eng: The elderly are killed by relatives, along with cattle; then they feast on the cooked flesh. But they bury those who die of disease. They sow no crops: their food consists of livestock, fish, and milk. They worship only the Sun among the gods: to it they sacrifice horses.
III.— BEASTS IN EGYPT AND LIBYA.
text.lat: III.— BESTIAE IN AEGYPTO ET LIBYA.

7.— In Aegypto paucae bestiae reperiuntur. Itaque omnes sacrae habentur. Feles canesque coluntur. Mortua fele in quavis domo, omnes aedium illarum incolae supercilia sola radunt: mortuo cane, totum radunt corpus et caput. Mortuae feles in sacris sepulcris, Bubasti in oppido sepeliuntur. Canes mortuos in suo quisque oppido sepeliunt. Mures etiam, araneos, accipitres. ibes, ichneumones, colunt.
text.eng: 7.— In Egypt, few beasts are found. Hence, they are all considered sacred. Cats and dogs are revered. When a cat dies in any house, all the inhabitants of those homes shave only their eyebrows: when a dog dies, they shave the whole body and head. Dead cats are buried in holy graves, in the town of Bubastis. They bury dead dogs in each of their towns. They also worship mice, spiders, hawks, ibises, and ichneumons.
The hippopotamus.
text.lat: Hippopotamus.

8.— Hippopotami a nonnullis Aegyptiis sacri habentur; ab reliquis vero non sacri. Horum natura atque species talis est. Quadrupes animal, bisulcum, ungulis bovinis, simo naso, iuba equina, dentibus prominentibus, cauda et voce equina: magnitudine tauris sunt similes.
text.eng: 8.— Hippopotamuses are considered sacred by some Egyptians; however, not sacred by others. Their nature and appearance is as follows. A quadruped animal, cloven-hoofed, with bovine hooves, a flat nose, a horse mane, prominent teeth, a horse tail and voice: in size, they are similar to bulls.
The phoenix.
text.lat: Phoenix.

9.— Est etiam avis sacra, nomine phoenix. Perraro Aegyptum adit, ex quingentorum annorum intervallo. Advenit autem mortuo patre suo. Est tantus atque talis; pennarum color, aliorum aureus, aliorum ruber; specie et magnitudine aquilae simillimus est. Phoenix ex Arabia profectus, in Solis templum portat patrem suum, myrrha circumlitum, et in templo Solis sepelit.
text.eng: 9.— There is also a sacred bird, named the phoenix. Very rarely it visits Egypt, from a five hundred year interval. It arrives, however, when its father has died. It is so large and of such quality; the color of its feathers, some golden, others red; in appearance and size most similar to an eagle. The phoenix, after journeying from Arabia, takes its father, covered in myrrh, into the temple of the Sun and buries him in the temple of the Sun.
The winged serpents and the ibis.
text.lat: Serpentes volucres et ibis.

10.— Ineunte vere in Aegyptum advolant volucres serpentes. Ibides autem aves illis occurrentes, aditu prohibent, necantque serpentes. Ob hanc caussam magni aestimantur ibides ab Aegyptiis. Species autem ibidis talis est; colore nigro avis est, pedibus gruis, rostro adunco. Serpentum forma similis est formae hydrarum. Alas habent non pennatas, sed vespertilionis alis similes.
text.eng: 10.— At the beginning of spring, winged serpents fly into Egypt. However, ibises, meeting them, prevent access, and kill the serpents. For this reason, ibises are highly esteemed by the Egyptians. The form of the ibis is as follows; a bird with black color, crane-like feet, and a hooked beak. The form of the serpents is similar to that of hydras. They have wings not feathered, but like those of a bat.
Wonderful animals in Libya.
text.lat: Mirae bestiae in Libya.

11.— Sunt in Libya immani magnitudine serpentes, sunt ibidem leones, et elephanti, et ursi, et aspides, et asini cornuti. Sunt etiam homines capita canum habentes. Sunt alii sine capitibus, oculos in pectore habentes, et feri homines. Sunt etiam mures bipedes, et parvi serpentes singulis cornibus instructi. Denique magnus numerus mirarum bestiarum in his regionibus invenitur.
text.eng: 11.— There are in Libya serpents of immense size, and there are also there lions, elephants, bears, asps, and horned asses. There are also men with dog heads. Some have no heads, with eyes in their chest, and wild men. There are also bipeds mice, and small serpents equipped with single horns. Finally, a great number of wonderful beasts is found in these regions.
The crocodile.
text.lat: Crocodilus.

12.— Crocodili autem natura haec est. Per quinque menses hibernos cibum nullum capit. Quadrupes est terram pariter et aquam habitans: ova enim parit excluditque in terra, et maiorem partem diei in sicco versatur, noctu vero in fluvio: est enim aqua noctu magis calida quam terra rore conspersa. Omnium vero animalium hoc ex minimo fit maximum. Ova enim haud multo maiora sunt ovis anseris: at pervenit ad septemdecim cubitorum longitudinem. Habet autem oculos porci, dentes vero magnos. Solum ex omnibus animalibus linguam non habet: neque inferiorem maxillam movet. Habet autem ungues robustos, et cutem squamatam. In aqua quidem caecus est, in aere bene videt. Os habet intus plenum hirudinibus. Iam aliae quidem aves et bestiae illum fugiunt: cum trochilo autem pacem colit. Hic utilem ei operam praestat: nam in os eius sese insinuans hirudines devorat.
text.eng: 12.— The nature of the crocodile is as follows. It takes no food for five winter months. It is a quadruped inhabiting both land and water: it lays and hatches eggs on land and spends most of the day on dry land, but at night in the river: for the water is warmer at night than the earth sprinkled with dew. Of all animals, it grows from the smallest to the largest. Its eggs are not much bigger than goose eggs but it reaches a length of seventeen cubits. It has pig-like eyes and large teeth. It is the only animal without a tongue and does not move its lower jaw. It has strong claws and scaly skin. It is blind in water but sees well in air. Its mouth is full of leeches. Most birds and beasts flee from it, but it lives in peace with the trochilus bird. This one offers it useful service: for it, entering its mouth, devours the leeches.
Strange pets.
text.lat: Ingenua animalia.

13.— Sunt autem crocodili aliis Aegyptiis sacri; aliis non item, sed hi illos ut hostes persequuntur. Omnes circa Thebas et Moeridis lacum incolae sacros illos ducunt. Horum utrique unum maxime crocodilum alunt, manu tractari edoctum. Auribus inaures inserunt, et anteriores pedes aureis armillis ornant. Eundem pascunt: mortuum sacro in sepulcro sepeliunt.
text.eng: 13.— However, some crocodiles are sacred to some Egyptians; to others, not so, but these pursue them as enemies. All the inhabitants around Thebes and the lake of Moeris consider them sacred. Each of these raises one crocodile that is especially taught to be handled by hand. They insert earrings in its ears and adorn its front feet with golden bracelets. They feed the same one: they bury it in a sacred tomb when dead.
IV.— AN AFRICAN REGIMENT.
text.lat: IV.— REGIMENTUM AFRICANUM.

14.— Aethiopes, pardorum leonumque pellibus amicti, arcus habent praelongos: sagittas vero breves: his pro ferro lapides acuti praefixi sunt. Hastas praeterea habent, his praefixa sunt cornua cervorum: habent etiam clavas nodosas. Corporis dimidium, in pugnam prodeuntes, creta dealbatum habent, dimidium minio pictum. Alii caput tectum habent pelle equina, de capite equi detracta, cum auribus et iuba. Pro scutis gruum pellibus corpora tegunt.
text.eng: 14.— The Ethiopians, clothed with the skins of leopards and lions, have long bows and short arrows; to these pointed stones are affixed instead of iron. They also have spears, to these the antlers of stags are fixed; they also have knotted clubs. Half of their body is whitened with chalk, when they advance to battle; half is painted with vermilion. Some have their head covered with a horse's hide, stripped from the head of the horse, with ears and mane. Instead of shields, they cover their bodies with crane skins.
V.— THE EQUIPMENT OF PERSIAN SOLDIERS
text.lat: V.— ARMAMENTA MILITUM PERSICORUM

15.— Persae hoc modo instructi sunt. In capite pileos gestant; hos tiaras vocant: circa corpus, tunicas manicatas varii coloris, et loricas ferreis squamis in piscium similitudinem: circa crura, braccas: pro clipeis vero, crates vimineas. A tergo suspensas habent pharetras: hastae breves sunt, arcus vero grandes, tela ex arundine: praeterea ad dextrum femur e zona suspensus est pugio.
text.eng: 15.— The Persians are equipped in this manner. On their head they wear caps; these they call tiaras: around the body, sleeved tunics of various colors, and breastplates with iron scales resembling fish: around the legs, trousers: instead of shields, wickerwork. On the back they have quivers suspended: the spears are short, the bows indeed large, weapons made of reed: moreover, a dagger is suspended from the belt on the right thigh.
VI.— THE STORY OF ATYS.
text.lat: VI.— FABULA AYI

16.— Croeso, Lydiae regi, filius erat, nomine Atys. Hunc Croesus in somnio vidit, ferrea cuspide traiectum et cruore conspersum. Expergefactus ille, domi filium retinet; deinde iacula et hastas abdit in area.
text.eng: 16.— To Croesus, king of Lydia, there was a son named Atys. Croesus saw him in a dream, pierced by an iron spear and sprinkled with blood. Upon awakening, he keeps his son at home; then he hides javelins and spears in the storeroom.
He purifies a man who comes to him stained with crime.
text.lat: Is hominem, qui scelere maculatus ad eum venit, expiat.
17.— Interim Sardes vir advenit obstrictus scelere. Eum Croesus expiavit, et benigne accepit. Tum eum percontatur his verbis : ‘Quis es? quem virum occidisti!’
text.eng: 17.— Meanwhile, a man bound by crime arrived in Sardis. Croesus purified him and received him kindly. Then he questioned him with these words: 'Who are you? Whom did you kill?'
The stranger tells his story — Croesus receives him as a friend.
text.lat: Hospes fabulam suam narrat — Croesus eum tamquam amicum excipit.

18.— Respondit hospes talia: ‘O rex, Gordiae sum filius, est autem mihi nomen Adrasto. Fratrem meum invitus occidi. Adsum a patre eiectus, rebus omnibus destitutus.’ Tum Croesus inquit: ‘Ex viris amicis oriundus es, et ad amicos venisti.’ Ita ille in Croesi aedibus vitam agebat.
text.eng: 18.— The stranger replied as follows: 'O king, I am the son of Gordias, and my name is Adrastus. I involuntarily killed my brother. I am expelled by my father and destitute of all things.' Then Croesus said: 'You are descended from friendly men and you have come to friends.' Thus he lived in Croesus' house.
A huge wild boar ravages the country.
text.lat: Immensus aper patriam vastat.
19.— Per idem tempus in monte Olympo aper exstitit mira magnitudine. Hic Mysorum arva vastabat.
text.eng: 19.— At the same time, on Mount Olympus, a boar of amazing size appeared. It was laying waste to the fields of the Mysians.
The people beg Croesus to send his son to kill it.
text.lat: Populus Croesum orat ut filium suum mittat ad eam occidendam.

20.— Mysorum legati ad Croesum venere haec dicentes: ‘Apparuit, o rex, in regione nostra immanis magnitudinis aper. Hic agrestia opera omnia corrumpit. Mitte filium tuum et delectos iuvenes canesque; nam beluam e terra nostra tollere volumus.'
text.eng: 20.— Ambassadors of the Mysians came to Croesus saying these things: 'A boar of immense size has appeared, O king, in our region. This creature destroys all rural works. Send your son, chosen young men, and dogs; for we want to remove the beast from our land.'
Croesus refuses.
text.lat: Croesus recusat.

21.— Haec illis precantibus Croesus, somnium recordatus, ita respondit: ‘Filii quidem mei ne amplius feceritis mentionem. Non enim illum vobiscum emittere possum. Lydorum autem delectam manum canesque mittam.'
text.eng: 21.— To these requesting people, Croesus, recalling the dream, thus answered: 'Do not make any further mention of my son. For I cannot send him with you. However, I will send a chosen band of Lydians and dogs.'
Atys implores his father to let him go.
text.lat: Atys orat patrem ut sibi abire permittat.

22.— Auditis Mysorum precibus intervenit Atys. Patrem movere his verbis conatur: ‘Antehac, o pater, hoc mihi honestissimum et nobilissimum visum fuit, bello et venatione gloriam parare. Ne igitur me domi retinueris. Quis tandem esse videbor civibus? Qualis videbor uxori?’
text.eng: 22.— Upon hearing the requests of the Mysians, Atys intervened. He tried to persuade his father with these words: 'Before this, O father, it seemed to me most honorable and noble to gain glory in war and hunting. Do not therefore keep me at home. What, then, will I seem to the citizens? What will I seem to my wife?'
Croesus gives his reasons for refusing.
text.lat: Croesus causas recusationis suae dat.
23.— Itaque Croesus talia respondit: ‘Mi fili, in somnio nuper te cuspide ferrea interfectum vidi. Ob hanc caussam domi te custodio.’
text.eng: 23.— Therefore, Croesus replied such: 'My son, in a dream I recently saw you killed by an iron spear. For this reason, I keep you at home.'
Atys urges him to let him go, and gives an explanation of the dream.
text.lat: Atys eum ut abire sinat instat, somnii explicationem dat.

24.— Rursus adolescens ita locutus est: ‘Ferrea cuspide me traiectum vidisti. At apro quaenam sunt manus, quaeve ferrea cuspis? Nihil dictum est de iniuria a dentibus suscepta. Quare abire me patere, mi pater.’
text.eng: 24.— Again, the young man spoke thus: 'You saw me pierced by an iron spear. But what are the hands or iron spear of a boar? Nothing is said about injury sustained from teeth. So allow me to go, my father.'
Croesus at length gives way.
text.lat: Croesus tandem succedit.
25.— Tum Croesus: ‘Fili,’ ait, ‘me vincis, sententiam somnii declarans. Itaque veniam tibi do venatum exeundi.’
text.eng: 25.— Then Croesus: 'Son,' he said, 'you have persuaded me by explaining the dream. Therefore, I allow you to go out to the hunt.'
And gives him in charge to Adrastus.
text.lat: Et tradit eum Adraste custodiendum.

26.— His dictis, Adrastum advocatum ita allocutus est: ‘Adraste, ego te calamitate obstrictum expiavi, et in meas aedes recepi. Nunc ergo, debes enim de me bene mereri, custos sis filii mei venatum exeuntis.’ Respondit Adrastus: 'Paratus sum exsequi mandatum. Filius tuus, o rex, custode me, incolumis redibit.’
text.eng: 26.— Having said these things, he addressed Adrastus as follows: 'Adrastus, I have purified you from the calamity and received you into my house. Now, therefore, as you ought to deserve well of me, be the guardian of my son going to the hunt.' Adrastus replied: 'I am ready to carry out the order. Your son, O king, will return safely under my protection.'
Adrastus kills Atys by accident, and fulfils the dream.
text.lat: Adrastus involuntarily Atyn occidit, ac somnium complet.
27.— Proficiscuntur igitur cum delectis iuvenibus canibusque. Beluam inventam iaculis adoriuntur. Casu Adrastus Croesi filium ferit. Itaque ille, cuspide ictus, somnii monitum explet.
text.eng: 27.— They set out, therefore, with chosen young men and dogs. They attack the found beast with javelins. By chance, Adrastus strikes Croesus' son. Thus he, struck by a spear, fulfills the dream's warning.
Croesus pardons him but he commits suicide.
text.lat: Croesus eum ignoscit sed ipse mortem sibi consciscit.

28.— Croesus, filii morte nuntiata, consternatus est. Adrastus sese tradidit Croeso. ‘Interfice me,’ dixit, ‘super cadavere filii.’ Illi Croesus: ‘Ignosco tibi, Adraste. Illud invitus fecisti. Non tu auctor es huius mali, sed deorum aliquis. Hoc mihi somnium iam pridem significavit.’ Adrastus autem se ipse super busto iugulavit. Croesus vero, filio orbatus, duos annos ingenti in luctu remansit.
text.eng: 28.— Croesus, upon hearing of his son's death, was alarmed. Adrastus surrendered himself to Croesus. 'Kill me,' he said, 'over the corpse of your son.' Croesus replied, 'I forgive you, Adrastus. You did it unwillingly. You are not to blame for this evil, but some god. This had been foretold to me by the dream long ago.' However, Adrastus killed himself over the tomb. Croesus, deprived of his son, remained in great mourning for two years.
VII.— A CROCODILE HUNT.
text.lat: VII.— VENATIO CROCODILORUM.

29.— Venatio crocodilorum multis atque variis modis instituitur. Suis tergus, pro esca hamo insertum, in medium flumen demittit venator. Ipse in ripa fluminis vivum porcellum ferit. Crocodilus, audita voce, ad sonum accurrit. In tergus vero suis incidens, illud deglutit, moxque in terram attrahitur. In terra extracti crocodili oculos luto oblinit venator. Tum facillime interficitur.
text.eng: 29.— A crocodile hunt is organized in many different ways. The hunter inserts the pig's back, as bait on a hook, into the middle of the river. He himself strikes a live piglet on the riverbank. The crocodile, having heard the noise, rushes to the sound. However, biting into the pig's back, it swallows it and is soon dragged to the land. On land, the hunter smears the eyes of the caught crocodile with mud. Then it is killed very easily.

text.lat: VIII.— ARTAYCTES.
text.eng: VIII.— ARTAYCTES.

text.lat: Deceit and sacrilege.
text.eng: Dolus et sacrilegium.

text.lat: 30.— Sesto olim praeerat Artayctes Persa. Hic Xerxem Athenas contendentem deceperat, Elaeunti clam ablatis Protesilai thesauris. Xerxem autem deceperat his verbis usus: ‘O rex, hic habitavit Graecus quidam. Is olim in regnum tuum expeditionem faciens interfectus est. Nunc mihi da, oro, huius divitias: ita enim omnes in te expeditionem facere nunquam postea audebunt.’ Itaque Xerxes deceptus, Protesilai domum Artaycti tradidit. Hic vero omnia Elaeunti ablata Sestum secum portavit.
text.eng: 30.— Artayctes the Persian once ruled over Sestus. He had deceived Xerxes marching against Athens by secretly carrying off the treasures of Protesilaus from Elaeus. He had deceived Xerxes by saying: ‘O king, here lived a certain Greek. He, while making an expedition into your realm, was killed. Now give me his wealth, I pray: for in this way all will be deterred from making expeditions against you in the future.’ Thus Xerxes, having been deceived, gave Protesilaus' house to Artayctes. He carried off all things from Elaeus to Sestus with him.

text.lat: Vengeance overtakes him.
text.eng: Ultio illum consequitur.

text.lat: 31.— Postea vero Artaycten ex improviso adorti Athenienses, Sestum diu obsederunt. Persae tandem intra moenia ad angustias redacti, funibus lectulorum vesci coacti sunt. His consumptis, Artayctes noctu cum filio in fugam se recepit. Mox tamen ab Atheniensibus captus, in vinculis Sestum iterum ductus est.
text.eng: 31.— Thereafter, the Athenians, having suddenly attacked Artayctes, besieged Sestus for a long time. The Persians, finally reduced to straits within the walls, were forced to eat the ropes of their beds. Once these were consumed, Artayctes fled at night with his son. Soon, however, he was captured by the Athenians and brought back to Sestus in chains.

text.lat: A strange story.
text.eng: Historia mirabilis.

text.lat: 32.— Dicitur tale prodigium accidisse uni e custodibus, pisces sale conditos coquenti. Pisces in igne iacentes insilire inceperunt quasi nuperrime capti. Obstupuerunt omnes: sed Artayctes, viso prodigio, homini dixit: ‘Hospes Atheniensis, ne hoc prodigium veritus sis, non enim tibi oblatum est. Hoc ad me pertinet. Protesilaus ipse in his piscibus est: mihi etiam dixit: “Te, o Artaycta, punire possum ob ablatas divitias.” Nunc igitur ei divitias restituere volo: pro pecuniis e templo Protesilai sublatis, centum talenta dabo: pro me et filiis meis ducenta talenta Atheniensibus solvam.’
text.eng: 32.— It is said that such a prodigy happened to one of the guards, while cooking fish preserved in salt. The fish, lying on the fire, began to leap as if just caught. All were amazed: but Artayctes, seeing the prodigy, said to the man: ‘Athenian guest, do not fear this prodigy, for it is not sent to you. It pertains to me. Protesilaus himself is in these fish: he also said to me: “I, O Artayctes, can punish you for the stolen wealth.” Now therefore I wish to restore his wealth to him: for the money taken from the temple of Protesilaus, I will give a hundred talents: for myself and my sons I will pay two hundred talents to the Athenians.’

text.lat: The fate of Artayctes.
text.eng: Fatum Artayctis.

text.lat: 33.— Ne hoc quidem modo Xanthippo, Atheniensium duci, suadere potuit: instabant enim Elaeuntini dicentes: ‘Interficito Artaycten;’ et interficere eum volebat ipse Xanthippus. Itaque cruci alligatum sublimem extulere; et filius eius ante oculos lapidibus oppressus periit. Tali modo Protesilai dirae ultrices Artaycten punierunt.
text.eng: 33.— Not even in this way could he persuade Xanthippus, leader of the Athenians: for the Elaeuntians urged, saying: ‘Kill Artayctes;’ and Xanthippus himself wished to kill him. Thus they raised him high on a cross; and his son perished, stoned before his eyes. In such a way the dread avengers of Protesilaus punished Artayctes.
IX.— ANECDOTES.
text.lat: IX.— ANECDOTA.
Contempt of pain.
text.eng: Contempt of pain.

text.lat: 34.— Pueri Spartani non gemunt flagellis lacerati. Adolescentes Spartae decertant manibus, pedibus, unguibus, dentibus denique, maluntque interfici, quam vinci. Puer etiam Spartanus dicitur in sinu vestis vulpem celasse, et bestiae dentibus necatus esse, nec gemitum edidisse: praeclarum enim apud Spartanos habebatur aliquid clam abstrahere; deprehendi vero, turpissimum.
text.eng: 34.— Spartan boys do not groan when lashed with whips. The youths of Sparta fight fiercely with fists, feet, nails, finally teeth, and prefer to be killed rather than conquered. It is said that even a Spartan boy concealed a fox in his garment and was killed by the beast's teeth, but did not utter a groan: for among the Spartans, stealing something secretly was considered admirable; however, being caught, most shameful.

text.lat: The trial of Sophocles.
text.eng: The trial of Sophocles.

text.lat: 35.— Sophocles ad summam senectutem tragoedias fecit: videbatur autem rem familiarem negligere propter studium. Itaque a filiis in ius vocatus est. Hi iudices orabant his verbis: ‘Patrem desipientem a re familiari removete.’ Tum senex dicitur tragoediam illam praeclaram, Oedipum Coloneum, recitasse iudicibus, et quaesisse, ‘Num hoc carmen desipientis videtur?’ Hoc rectitato sententiis iudicum est liberatus.
text.eng: 35.— Sophocles wrote tragedies up to extreme old age: however, he seemed to neglect his affairs owing to his study. Therefore, he was summoned by his children to court. They appealed to the judges with these words: ‘Remove our irrational father from managing affairs.’ Then it is said that the old man recited that famous tragedy, Oedipus at Colonus, to the judges, and asked, ‘Does this poem seem the work of a madman?’ The poem having been recited, he was released by the judges' verdict.

text.lat: Respect paid to age.
text.eng: Respect paid to age.

text.lat: 36.— Lysander Lacedaemonios hoc dixisse dicitur; ‘Lacedaemone optime vivere possunt senes.’ Nusquam enim tantum tribuitur aetati, nusquam est senectus honoratior. Athenis olim, ludis institutis quidam in theatrum grandis natu venit, nec ei locus datus est a suis civibus; tum ad legatos Lacedaemonios accessit; hi autem omnes consurrexere et seni locum dederunt. Hoc factum probantibus Atheniensibus, unus e legatis dixit, ‘Athenienses quidem sciunt recta facere, sed facere nolunt.’
text.eng: 36.— Lysander is said to have remarked to the Lacedaemonians; ‘Elderly people can live best in Sparta.’ Nowhere else is old age given so much respect, nowhere is it more honored. Once, at Athens, when public games were being held, an elderly man came into the theater, and no seat was given to him by his fellow citizens; then he approached the Spartan envoys; they all rose and gave the old man a seat. When the Athenians approved this action, one of the envoys said, ‘Athenians indeed know what is right, but they refuse to do it.’

text.lat: Diogenes.
text.eng: Diogenes.

text.lat: 37.— Diogenes moriens dixit: ‘Proiicite me, ne in sepulcro posueritis.’ Tum amici: ‘Volucribusne et feris?’ ‘Minime vero,’ inquit, ‘sed telum propter me ponitote: hoc feras a me abigam.’ ‘Quomodo poteris?’ illi responderunt: ‘non enim senties.’ ‘Quid igitur mihi nocebunt ferarum dentes et volucrum rostra, nihil sentienti?’
text.eng: 37.— Diogenes, dying, said: ‘Throw me away, do not put me in a tomb.’ Then his friends: ‘To the birds and beasts?’ ‘Certainly not,’ he said, ‘but place a stick next to me, with which I will drive them away.’ ‘How can you do this?’ they replied: ‘For you will not feel anything.’ ‘Then how will the teeth of wild animals and the beaks of birds harm me, when I feel nothing?’

text.lat: Anaxagoras.
text.eng: Anaxagoras.

text.lat: 38.— Praeclarum fuit responsum illud Anaxagorae philosophi. Is enim, Lampsaci moriens, quaerentibus amicis, ‘Visne in patriam auferri?’ inquit: ‘Minime: undique enim ad Inferos eadem est via.’
text.eng: 38.— The answer of the philosopher Anaxagoras was famous. Indeed, he was dying at Lampsacus, and when his friends asked him, ‘Do you want to be carried back home?’ he said: ‘No: for from all places, the road to the underworld is the same.’

text.lat: Lysander at Sardis.
text.eng: Lysander at Sardis.

text.lat: 39.— Cyrus minor, princeps Persarum praestans ingenio atque imperii gloria, Lysandrum Lacedaemonium, virum summae virtutis, Sardibus olim hospitio excepit. Huic quemdam agrum diligenter cultum ostendit. Miranti autem Lysandro arbores, et humum cultam et bene dispositos ordines, Cyrus respondit: ‘Ego omnia illa disposui: mei sunt ordines; multae etiam illarum arborum mea manu sunt satae.’ Tum Lysander, videns ornatum eius multo auro eximium, dixit: ‘Recte vero te, Cyre, beatum ferunt, virtuti enim tuae divitiae additae sunt.’
text.eng: 39.— Cyrus the Younger, a leader of the Persians, distinguished in ability and in glory of command, hosted Lysander the Lacedaemonian, a man of highest virtue, at Sardis one time. He showed him a certain field diligently cultivated. When Lysander admired the trees and the well-cultivated earth and nicely arranged rows, Cyrus replied: ‘I arranged all these: the rows are mine; many of those trees were planted by my own hand.’ Then Lysander, seeing his adornment with much distinguished gold, said: ‘Indeed they truly call you, Cyrus, blessed, for riches have been added to your virtue.’

text.lat: Contempt of death.
text.eng: Contempt of death.

text.lat: 40.— Quam magno animo fuit Theramenes! Olim enim in carcerem ex mandato triginta tyrannorum coniectus, venenum bibit, et reliquum e poculo in vas emisit. Sonitu autem reddito, ridens inquit, ‘hoc pulcro Critiae.’ Critias autem in eum crudelissimus fuerat. Graeci enim in epulis poculum alicui tradituri, eum nominare solent.
text.eng: 40.— How great was the spirit of Theramenes! For once, thrown into prison by order of the thirty tyrants, he drank the poison, and poured the remainder from the cup into the vessel. Then, with a sound given, laughing he said, ‘To the beautiful Critias.’ For Critias had been most cruel to him. For the Greeks, when about to pass a cup to someone at banquets, are accustomed to name him.

text.lat: Socrates.
text.eng: Socrates.

text.lat: 41.— In eundem carcerem paucis post annis Socrates iit, eodem scelere iudicum. Qui est igitur eius sermo apud iudices? ‘Lubenter,’ inquit, ‘morti obviam ibo. Alterum enim de duobus fiet: aut sensus omnino omnes mors auferet, aut in alium quendam ex his locis abibimus. Itaque aut somno fruemur, aut cum optimo quoque cive loqui poterimus et versari.’
text.eng: 41.— Socrates went to the same prison a few years later, on the same charge by the judges. What then was his speech before the judges? ‘Willingly,’ he said, ‘I will go to meet death. For one of two things will happen: either death will entirely take all senses, or we shall depart to another place. Therefore, we shall enjoy sleep, or we will be able to talk and associate with every best citizen.’

text.lat: The Spartans.
text.eng: The Spartans.

text.lat: 42.— Pari animo Lacedaemonii Thermopylis ceciderunt. Quid illorum dux Leonidas dicit? 'Pergite animo forti, Lacedaemonii: hodie apud inferos coenabimus.’ Nonne etiam Lacaena pariter fortis fuit? Haec enim, filii morte nuntiata, ‘In hunc finem peperi filium,’ dixit.
text.eng: 42.— The Lacedaemonians fell at Thermopylae with equal spirit. What did their leader Leonidas say? ‘March on with a brave heart, Lacedaemonians: today we will dine with the dead.’ Was not even a Spartan woman equally brave? For when notified of her son's death, she said, ‘I bore a son for this purpose.’

text.lat: Theodorus.
text.eng: Theodorus.

text.lat: 43.— Cyrenaeum Theodorum philosophum praeclarissimum nonne miramur? Lysimacho regi crucem minanti, ‘Istis,’ inquit, “ista crudelia minare primoribus tuis: haec ad Theodorum nihil attinent: humi putrescere aut in aere, idem est.’
text.eng: 43.— Do we not admire Theodorus the Cyrenaean philosopher as most famous? To Lysimachus the king threatening him with the cross, he said, ‘Threaten these cruel things to your nobles: these things make no difference to Theodorus: to rot on the ground or in the air, it is the same.’
X.— THE LABOURS OF HERCULES.
text.lat: X.— LABORES HERCULIS.
The Nemean lion.
text.eng: Leo Nemeaeus.

text.lat: 55.— In valle Nemeae leo ingens vivebat, et pecora hominesque quotidie interficiebat. Eurystheus, rex Tirynthis, Herculem ad se advocavit, eique dixit: ‘Curae tibi sit hunc leonem quam celerrime interficere.’ Statim proficiscitur Hercules. Clava sagittisque frustra usus, impetu facto, leonem manibus interfecit. Tum ad Eurystheum reversus est, mortuum leonem humeris impositum ferens.
text.eng: 55.— In the valley of Nemea lived a huge lion, and every day it killed cattle and people. Eurystheus, king of Tiryns, summoned Hercules to him and said: ‘Your task is to kill this lion as quickly as possible.’ Hercules sets out immediately. Having used club and arrows in vain, with a rush, he killed the lion with his hands. Then he returned to Eurystheus, carrying the dead lion on his shoulders.

text.lat: The Lernean Hydra.
text.eng: Hydra Lernaea.

text.lat: 56.— Olim in palude versabatur hydra. Haec novem capita habebat. Capita vero octo abscidit Hercules, nonum autem vulnerare non poterat; immortale enim erat. Abscisso quoque capite, bina statim enascebantur. His tandem igne consumptis, caput immortale sub saxo ingenti condidit Hercules. Belua ita devicta, sagittas venenato sanguine tinxit.
text.eng: 56.— Once in a swamp dwelt a hydra. It had nine heads. Hercules cut off eight of the heads, but he could not wound the ninth; for it was immortal. When any head was cut off, two new ones grew immediately. When Hercules finally destroyed these with fire, he buried the immortal head under a huge rock. With the monster thus conquered, he dipped his arrows in its poisonous blood.

text.lat: The Erymanthian boar.
text.eng: Aper Erymanthius.

text.lat: 57.— Exstitit in monte Erymantho aper mira magnitudine. Hunc capere iussus Hercules statim profectus est. Per nives diu insecutus aprum, tandem laqueis implicatum capere potuit, et ad Eurystheum rettulit.
text.eng: 57.— On Mount Erymanthus appeared a boar of remarkable size. Hercules was ordered to capture it and set out immediately. After pursuing the boar through the snow for a long time, he was finally able to capture it with nets and took it to Eurystheus.

text.lat: The Arcadian stag.
text.eng: Cervus Arcadicus.

text.lat: 58.— In Arcadia cervus erat aureis comibus, pedibus vero aeneis. Hunc sequi Hercules ab Eurystheo iussus erat. Frustra per totum annum cervum insecutus est; tandem sagitta vulneratum cepit.
text.eng: 58.— In Arcadia there was a stag with golden antlers and bronze hooves. Hercules was ordered by Eurystheus to pursue it. He pursued the stag the entire year in vain; finally, he captured it wounded with an arrow.

text.lat: The stables of Augeas.
text.eng: Stabula Augeae.

text.lat: 59.— Augeas, rex Elidis, tria millia boum habebat. Horum stabula per triginta annos non erant lota. Hercules Augean adiit, eique dixit: ‘Uno die haec stabula lavabo. Visne mihi, hoc facto, decimam boum partem dare?’ Respondit Augeas: ‘Dabo lubenter.’ Tum Hercules, converso per stabula amne, opus facillime intra unum diem peregit.
text.eng: 59.— Augeas, king of Elis, had three thousand cattle. Their stables had not been cleaned for thirty years. Hercules approached Augeas, and said: ‘I will clean these stables in one day. Will you give me a tenth of your cattle for this task?’ Augeas replied: ‘I will gladly give.’ Then Hercules, by diverting a river through the stables, completed the task very easily in one day.

text.lat: The Stymphalian birds.
text.eng: Aves Stymphalides.

text.lat: 60.— Vivebant olim in lacu ad Stymphalum in Arcadia aves pedibus et rostris et pennis aeneis: utebantur autem pennis suis pro sagittis, et carne hominum vescebantur. Aves adortus Hercules, sistro aeneo exterruit, tum fugere conantes sagittis interfecit.
text.eng: 60.— In a lake near Stymphalus in Arcadia once lived birds with bronze feet, beaks, and wings: they used their wings as arrows and fed on human flesh. Hercules attacked the birds, frightened them with a bronze rattle, and then killed them with arrows as they tried to flee.

text.lat: The Cretan bull.
text.eng: Taurus Creticus.

text.lat: 61.— Bovem mirae magnitudinis et eximiae formae e mari emisit Poseidon. Hunc sacrificare Minos, Cretae rex, iussus erat; captus autem bovis specie, alium eius vice sacrificavit. Poseidon vero iratus, bovem in furorem egit. Tum bos per totam insulam magnam hominum stragem edebat, et opera agrestia corrumpebat. Hunc tandem captum Hercules ad Eurystheum portavit.
text.eng: 61.— A bull of extraordinary size and beauty was sent from the sea by Poseidon. Minos, king of Crete, was ordered to sacrifice it; however, captivated by the appearance of the bull, he sacrificed another in its place. Angry, Poseidon drove the bull mad. Then the bull wreaked havoc across the entire island, destroying crops and property. Hercules finally captured the bull and brought it to Eurystheus.

text.lat: The mares of Diomedes.
text.eng: Equae Diomedis.

text.lat: 62.— Diomedes, Bistonum rex, equas carne hominum pascebat. Hercules vero equas clam abstulit, et ad mare duxit. Hic autem Bistones eum adorti sunt. Diu pugnatum est. Devictis tandem Bistonibus, Hercules regem interfecit, et corpus equabus dedit. Tum reversus est incolumis equas secum ducens. Hae vero mansuefactae sunt carne domini sui pastae.
text.eng: 62.— Diomedes, king of the Bistones, fed the mares with human flesh. Hercules secretly took the mares and led them to the sea. But here the Bistones attacked him. The fight lasted a long time. After finally defeating the Bistones, Hercules killed the king and gave his body to the mares. Then he returned unharmed, leading the mares. They became tame, fed on the flesh of their master.

text.lat: The girdle of Hippolyte.
text.eng: Zona Hippolytes.

text.lat: 63.— Hippolyte, Amazonum regina, zonam pulcherrimam habebat. Hac autem potiri volebat Admete, Eurysthei filia: itaque Hercules eam asportare iussus est. Tandem ad Amazonum terram pervenit. Ibi primum benigne excepit Hippolyte, zonamque promisit, sed coorta rixa, contra Herculem Amazones manus conseruerunt. His victis et occisa Hippolyte Hercules zona potitus est.
text.eng: 63.— Hippolyte, queen of the Amazons, possessed a very beautiful girdle. Admete, daughter of Eurystheus, wished to obtain this; hence Hercules was ordered to take it. Finally, he reached the land of the Amazons. There, at first, Hippolyte received him kindly and promised the girdle, but when a conflict arose, the Amazons fought against Hercules. When they were defeated and Hippolyte was killed, Hercules gained possession of the girdle.

text.lat: The oxen of Geryones.
text.eng: Boves Geryonis.

text.lat: 64.— Geryones gigas triplici corpore in insula Erythia habitabat, multos boves habebat idem, a gigante Eurytione et a cane bicipite custoditos. Hercules his potiri volebat, itaque in Libyam et Hispaniam profectus est. Ibi ad utrumque latus maris columnas statuit: his igitur nomen Herculeis columnis datum est. Calore solis lacessitus in Helion tela coniecit: hic vero audaciam miratus, eum aurea cymba donavit: itaque Erythiam pervenire potuit. Interfecto Geryone cum Eurytione et cane, cum bobus reversus est.
text.eng: 64.— Geryones, a giant with a triple body, lived on the island of Erythia, and he had many oxen, guarded by the giant Eurytion and by a two-headed dog. Hercules wanted to gain possession of these, so he set out for Libya and Spain. There, he set up columns on either side of the sea: hence they were named the Pillars of Hercules. Stirred by the sun's heat, he hurled his weapons at Helios: the latter, impressed by his audacity, granted him a golden cup: thus he could reach Erythia. After killing Geryon along with Eurytion and the dog, he returned with the oxen.

text.lat: The apples of the Hesperides.
text.eng: Mala Hesperidum.

text.lat: 65.— Mox opus difficilius Herculi imperatum est; mala scilicet Hesperidum iussus est asportare, non enim locum sciebat. In monte autem Atlante habitabant Hesperides. Ibi cum serpente ingenti mala aurea custodiebant. Locum tandem nactus Hercules, Atlanti dixit: ‘Visne mihi mala aurea auferre? Hoc te faciente caelum humeris impositum tui vice sustinebo.’ Cum malis reversus Atlas Herculi dixit: ‘Nunc tibi licet caelum humeris semper sustinere, ipse autem abibo.’ Tum Hercules per dolum onere humeris Atlantis iterum imposito, cum malis recessit.
text.eng: 65.— Soon a more difficult task was imposed on Hercules; namely, he was ordered to carry off the apples of the Hesperides, for he did not know the place. The Hesperides lived on Mount Atlas. There, with a huge serpent, they guarded the golden apples. Hercules finally found the location and said to Atlas: ‘Would you like to take the golden apples for me? While you do this, I will bear the heavens on my shoulders instead of you.’ Atlas returned with the apples and said to Hercules: ‘Now you may always carry the heavens on your shoulders, but I will go.’ Then Hercules, by a trick, having placed the burden on Atlas's shoulders again, left with the apples.

text.lat: Cerberus.
text.eng: Cerberus.

text.lat: 66.— His laboribus peractis, opus difficillimum Herculi imperatur. Erat in Tartaris canis triceps, nomine Cerberus. Hic aditum in Tartara custodiebat. Hunc in terram ferre iussus est. In Tartara profectus est cum Herma et Athena. Tum summo labore Cerberum manibus captum in terram secum portavit. His laboribus functus Hercules servitute ab Eurystheo liberatus est.
text.eng: 66.— With these labors completed, a most difficult task was laid upon Hercules. In Tartarus was a three-headed dog named Cerberus. This creature guarded the entrance to Tartarus. He was ordered to bring it to the earth. He went into Tartarus with Hermes and Athena. Then, with great effort, he captured Cerberus with his hands and carried it to the earth with him. With these labors finished, Hercules was freed from servitude to Eurystheus.
XI.— SAYINGS OF ARISTIPPUS.
text.lat: XI.—DICTA ARISTIPPI.

67.— Olim Aristippo Corinthum iter faciente, ingens procella coorta est. Dixerat autem aliquis: ‘Nos nautae nihil timemus: vos vero philosophi omnia timetis.’ Contra Aristippus, ‘Non est mirum,’ inquit, ‘non enim similes animi peribunt.’ Quidam pro eodem caussam dixerat, eumque criminis absolverat. Tum Aristippum his verbis interrogavit : ‘Quidnam boni a Socrate percepisti?’ Ei philosophus respondit: ‘Haecce percepi: de me multa bona dixisti, et vera sunt.’
text.eng: 67.— Once, when Aristippus was making a journey to Corinth, a great storm arose. Someone had said: ‘We sailors fear nothing: but you philosophers fear everything.’ Aristippus replied, ‘It is not surprising,’ he said, ‘for not similar minds will perish.’ Someone had spoken in favor of him in a case and had acquitted him of the charge. Then he asked Aristippus in these words: ‘What good have you learned from Socrates?’ To him, the philosopher replied: ‘This I have learned: you said many good things about me, and they are true.’
XII.— SPARTAN MEALS.
text.lat: XII.— CONVIVIA SPARTANA.

68.— Spartani in publico loco coenabant. Singulis mensis plures homines utebantur. Singulis mensibus, frumentum, vinum, fructus, lac, quisque afferebat. Diu in publico coenare coacti sunt. Olim rex ipse Agis, bene gesto bello reversus, cum uxore domi coenare voluit. Ne tum quidem hoc passi sunt Ephori. Ob hanc caussam iratus rex sacra post victoriam solita facere noluit; itaque pecunia eum multaverunt.
text.eng: 68.— The Spartans dined in a public place. Several people used a single table. Each month, everyone brought grain, wine, fruits, milk. They were forced to dine in public for a long time. Once King Agis himself, having returned from a well-conducted war, wished to dine at home with his wife. Not even then did the Ephors allow this. For this reason, the angry king refused to perform the customary sacrifices after victory; therefore they fined him.

text.lat: XIII.— THE OLDEST NATION.
text.eng: XIII.— ANTIQUISSIMA GENS

text.lat: 69.— Psammetichus, Aegypti imperio potitus antiquissimam mundi gentem reperire voluit; tali igitur artificio usus est. Duos pueros nuperrime natos servo tradidit, eique dixit: ‘Ne coram his vocem ullam edideris, lac modo praebe.’ Haec per duos continuos annos fecit servus. Tandem portam aperienti pueri ‘becos’ clamabant. Hoc servus primum audiens, celavit: sed saepius idem verbum dictitantibus pueris, regi nuntiavit, eiusque mandato in conspectum adduxit. Panis autem Phrygio sermone becos dicitur. Itaque Phryges omnium populorum antiquissimi ab Aegyptiis habiti sunt.
text.eng: 69.— Psammetichus, having gained the rule of Egypt, wished to discover the oldest nation in the world; thus he used the following artifice. He entrusted two newly-born children to a servant, and told him: ‘Do not utter any word in their presence, only provide milk.’ The servant did this for two continuous years. Finally, the boys shouted ‘becos’ as he opened the door. Hearing this for the first time, the servant kept it secret: but as the boys often repeated the same word, he reported it to the king, and at the king's command, he brought them into his presence. However, in the Phrygian language, bread is called becos. Therefore, the Phrygians were considered by the Egyptians the oldest of all peoples.
XIV.— EGYPTIAN NOTES.
text.lat: XIV.— NOTAE AEGYPTIAE.

text.eng: Doctors.
text.lat: Medici.

70.— Ars medica apud Aegyptios in hunc modum distributa est: singulorum morborum singuli sunt medici, nec plura morborum genera unus idemque curat. Suntque apud illos alii oculorum medici, capitis alii, alii dentium, alii occultorum morborum.
text.eng: 70.— The art of medicine among the Egyptians is distributed in this manner: there are separate doctors for each disease, and no single doctor treats several types of diseases. Among them are doctors for the eyes, others for the head, others for teeth, and others for hidden diseases.
Mourning for the Dead.
text.lat: Lamenta mortuis.

71.— Lamenta et sepulturae in hunc modum instituuntur. Ex domo quavis mortuo homine, mulieres ex ea domo omnes luto oblinunt caput aut ipsum etiam os, deinde relicto domi cadavere, ipsae per urbem currunt gementes, et cum his propinquae omnes. Alia ex parte gemunt viri. His factis, cadaver ad condiendum efferunt.
text.eng: 71.— Mourning and burials are instituted in this manner. From any house with a dead man, all the women from that house cover their head or even the face with mud, then leaving the body at home, they run through the city wailing, and with them all the relatives. On the other side, the men lament. Having done this, they carry the body out for embalming.
Mummies.
text.lat: Condiciones.

72.— Quidam autem homines artem condiendi mortuos exercent. Allato cadavere, primum ferro per nares extrahunt cerebrum. Tum, extractis visceribus, corpus vino lavant, iterumque tritis odoribus purgant. Deinde corpus myrrha et casia aliisque odoribus, ture excepto, explent. His ita factis cadaver per dies septuaginta condiunt: nec enim licet diutius. Peractis septuaginta diebus, lavant cadaver, et pannis tegunt. Tum propinqui arcam hominis figura conficiunt; hanc in arcam cadaver ponunt, et in sepulcro, ad murum statuentes, relinquunt.
text.eng: 72.— Certain men practice the art of embalming the dead. First, they remove the brain with an iron through the nostrils. Then, having removed the viscera, they wash the body with wine and purify it with powdered spices again. Then they fill the body with myrrh, cassia, and other spices, excluding incense. After doing this, they embalm the body for seventy days: for it is not allowed to go on longer. After the seventy days, they wash the body, and cover it with cloths. Then the relatives prepare a box in the shape of a human; they place the body in this box and leave it in a tomb, standing it against the wall.
The victims of the Nile.
text.lat: Victimae Nilo.

73.— Homines autem, sive Aegyptii, sive peregrini, a crocodilo abrepti, aut ipso flumine interempti magno honore afficiuntur. Eiectum enim cadaver incolae eius loci, quam maxima cura sepeliunt: neque alii cuiquam, nec propinquo, nec amico, tangere licet tale cadaver: sed soli sacerdotes Nili sepeliunt.
text.eng: 73.— People, whether Egyptians or foreigners, who are carried off by a crocodile or killed by the river itself, are treated with great honor. For the locals of that place bury the cast out body with utmost care: nor is it allowed for anyone else, neither relative nor friend, to touch such a body: but only the priests of the Nile bury it.
Mosquitoes.
text.lat: Culices.

74.— Adversus culices hoc faciunt. Turres aedificant praealtas; in has dormituri ascendunt, nam vento prohibentur culices. Homines autem circa paludes habitantes, pro turribus hac ratione se muniunt. Quisque vir rete habet: hoc per diem pisces venatur, noctu autem utitur in aedibus: lectulo imponit rete, deinde sese insinuans, sub illo dormit. Culices enim per vestes mordere possunt: per rete vero, ne conantur quidem.
text.eng: 74.— Against mosquitoes they do this. They build very tall towers; they ascend into them to sleep, for mosquitoes are kept away by the wind. But people living near swamps protect themselves in this way instead of towers. Each man has a net: with this he fishes during the day, but at night he uses it in the house: he puts the net over the bed, then crawling under it, he sleeps. For mosquitoes can bite through clothes, but through the net they do not even try.
A visit to the infernal regions.
text.lat: Visitatio ad Inferos.

75.— Rhampsinitus, Aegyptiorum rex, dicitur vivus sub terram descendisse, et apud Inferos cum Cerere aleam lusisse, et partim victor evasisse, partim etiam ab illa victus fuisse: denique iterum inde reversus, munus ab eadem retulisse pallium aureum. Propter hoc Rhampsiniti iter ad Inferos, epulas agunt Aegyptii. Unus e sacerdotibus pallium induit, eodem die ab illis confectum: huic reliqui pileo tegunt oculos, eumque in viam ducunt ad Cereris templum ferentem: tum ipsi retro discedunt. Tum sacerdos, a duobus lupis ad templum Cereris, rursusque in eundem locum duci dicitur.
text.eng: 75.— Rhampsinitus, king of the Egyptians, is said to have descended alive to the underworld, and in the presence of Ceres, played dice, and partly emerged victorious, and partly was defeated by her: finally having returned again from there, he is said to have brought back a golden robe as a gift from her. Because of this journey of Rhampsinitus to the Inferiors, the Egyptians hold feasts. One of the priests wears the robe, crafted by them on the same day: the rest blindfold his eyes with a cap and lead him on the road towards the temple of Ceres, then withdraw themselves back. Then the priest is said to be led to the temple of Ceres by two wolves, and back again to the same place.
The transmigration of souls.
text.lat: Transmigatio animarum.

76.— Primis omnium Aegyptiis anima hominis immortalis esse visa est. De anima autem haec dicunt: intereunte corpore in aliud animal anima intrat: circuitu per omnia terrestria animalia et marina et volucria absoluto, tum rursus in hominis corpus redit: circuitus autem ille tribus annorum millibus absolvitur. Hac vero sententia nonnulli e Graecorum philosophis postea usi sunt.
text.eng: 76.— First of all, the Egyptians believed the soul of man was immortal. About the soul they say this: with the body perishing, the soul enters another animal: when the cycle through all terrestrial, sea, and winged animals is completed, then it returns again to the human body: the cycle itself is completed in three thousand years. Some of the Greek philosophers later used this belief.
XV.—CYRUS.
text.lat: XV.—CYRUS
His youth.
text.eng: Iuventus eius.

text.lat: 77.— Cyaxari, Medorum regi, successit filius Astyages. Hic Mandanen filiam, ob somnium sibi oblatum, homini Persae, nomine Cambysi, in matrimonium dedit. Mandane postea filium peperit. Hunc puerum, alio somnio exterritus, Astyages Harpago cuidam tradidit necandum. Harpagus autem puerum servo tradidit exponendum in montibus: sed ille suum puerum mortuum exposuit, Cyrumque pro suo educavit. Postea vero Cyrus Persarum rex factus, Astyagen bello devicit, imperioque Medorum potitus est.
text.eng: 77.— Cyaxares, king of the Medes, was succeeded by his son Astyages. He gave his daughter Mandane in marriage to a Persian man named Cambyses, because of a dream presented to him. Mandane later bore a son. Terrified by another dream, Astyages delivered the boy to a certain Harpagus to be killed. However, Harpagus handed the boy to a servant to be exposed in the mountains, but he exposed his own dead child and raised Cyrus as his own. Later, Cyrus became king of the Persians, defeated Astyages in war, and gained control over the empire of the Medes.

text.lat: Solon and Croesus.
text.eng: Solon et Croesus.

text.lat: 78.— Solon Atheniensis peregre profectus, in Aegyptum se contulit ad Amasin, atque etiam Sardes ad Croesum. Ibi in regia domo hospitio exceptus est a Croeso. Tum tertio aut quarto post die, iubente Croeso, ministri regis circumduxerunt Solonem thesauros omnes ostentantes. Tum tali modo eum percontatus est Croesus: ‘Hospes Atheniensis,’ inquit, ‘multa ad nos de te fama pervenit, quum sapientiae tuae caussa, tum itinerum: sapientiae enim studio deditus multas terras spectandi caussa adiisti. Nunc igitur ingreditur in me cupido ex te sciscitandi. Quemnam adhuc vidisti omnium hominum beatissimum?’ Videbatur autem sibi omnium beatissimus esse.
text.eng: 78.— Solon of Athens, having set out abroad, traveled to Egypt to Amasis, and also to Sardis to Croesus. There he was received with hospitality by Croesus in the royal house. Then on the third or fourth day afterward, by the order of Croesus, the king’s servants led Solon around, showing all the treasures. Croesus then asked him in this manner: ‘Athenian guest,’ he said, ‘much fame about you has reached us, both for your wisdom and your travels: devoted as you are to the pursuit of wisdom, you have visited many lands to observe. Now, therefore, arises in me a desire to inquire from you. Whom have you seen of all men as the most blessed?’ It seemed to him that he was the most blessed of all.

text.lat: Tellus the Athenian.
text.eng: Tellus Atheniensis.

text.lat: 79.— At Solon, nulla usus assentatione respondit: ‘Ego vero, beatissimum vidi Tellum Atheniensem.’ Hoc dictum miratus Croesus quaerit: ‘Qua tandem ratione Tellum beatissimum iudicas?’ Cui Solon: ‘Tellus,’ inquit, ‘florente civitate, filios habuerat bonos viros honestosque, filiorumque filios liberos, eosque omnes superstites: idemque vitae finem habuit praeclarum: nam in pugna pro patria fortissime pugnans, devictis hostibus, interfectus est: tum in eodem loco ab Atheniensibus sepultus est, virum praestantissimum laudantibus.’ Tum Croesus inquit: ‘Quemnam secundum ab illo vidisti beatissimum?’
text.eng: 79.— But Solon, using no flattery, responded: ‘Indeed, I saw Tellus the Athenian as the most blessed.’ Amazed at this answer, Croesus asked: ‘By what reasoning do you judge Tellus the most blessed?’ To which Solon replied: ‘Tellus,’ he said, ‘in a flourishing city, had good and honest sons, and his sons' sons free, and all survived: he also had a glorious end in life: for in a battle for his country, fighting most bravely, he was slain after defeating the enemy: then in the same place he was buried by the Athenians, who praised him as a most outstanding man.’ Then Croesus asked: ‘Whom did you see as the second most blessed after him?’

text.lat: Cleobis and Biton.
text.eng: Cleobis et Biton.

text.lat: 80.— At ille inquit: ‘Cleobin et Bitonem. His enim satis victus erat, et magnae corporis vires. Dicuntur etiam matrem, iugum ipsi subeuntes, curru in templum Iunonis traxisse, boves enim ex agro non aderant. Hoc facto, vitae fine praeclarissimo functi sunt. Laudantibus enim omnibus iuvenum vires, et mulieribus matrem filiorum talium felicem dicentibus: tum mater stans ante simulacrum, deam precata est his verbis: ‘O dea, Cleobi et Bitoni filiis meis, munus optimum praebe.’ Sacris factis, epulati iuvenes somno se dederunt, et mane mortui inventi sunt. Eorundem delude statuas, ut hominum praestantissimorum, in deae aede cives posuerunt.’
text.eng: 80.— And he said: ‘Cleobis and Biton. They had sufficient sustenance and great strength of body. It is said that they, placing themselves under the yoke, dragged their mother in a chariot to the temple of Juno, as the oxen were not present from the field. This done, they met with the most glorious end of life. For with all praising the strength of the youths and the women saying that their mother was fortunate for having such sons, then the mother, standing before the statue, prayed to the goddess with these words: ‘O goddess, provide the best gift to my sons, Cleobis and Biton.’ Sacrifices completed, the youths feasted and gave themselves to sleep, and in the morning were found dead. Thereafter, the citizens placed their statues, as of the most outstanding men, in the temple of the goddess.

text.lat: The fall of Croesus foretold.
text.eng: Cadere Croesi praedictum.

text.lat: 81.— Cyrus, Persarum rex, in Croesum expeditionem susceperat. Interim tale prodigium Croeso oblatum est. Apparuit ad urbem ingens serpentum multitudo. Horum equi, omisso solito cibo, copiam ingentem edebant. Id Croeso prodigium esse videbatur: itaque statim homines consulere haruspices iussos misit. His dixerunt haruspices: ‘Exercitus peregrinus ingredietur terram Croesi, et incolas opprimet: serpentes enim sunt terrae filii, equi autem hostes et peregrini.' Et haec quidem responderunt haruspices, Croeso iam capto, sed ignari adhuc ipsi eventus.
text.eng: 81.— Cyrus, king of the Persians, had undertaken an expedition against Croesus. Meanwhile, such a prodigy was presented to Croesus. A vast multitude of serpents appeared near the city. The horses, having abandoned their usual food, devoured a great amount of them. It seemed to Croesus to be a prodigy: therefore he immediately sent men to consult the soothsayers. The soothsayers told them: ‘A foreign army will enter the land of Croesus and oppress the inhabitants: for the serpents are sons of the land, but the horses are foreigners and enemies.’ And they indeed answered these things to Croesus, who was already captured, but still themselves ignorant of the outcome.

text.lat: The capture of Babylon.
text.eng: Babylon capta.

text.lat: 82.— Cyrus, universa continente inferioris Asiae potestati suae subiecta, Assyrios aggressus est. Sunt autem Assyriae quum aliae urbes praestantes multae, tum praeclarissima omnium et munitissima, Babylon. Erant autem moenia ducenos pedes alta. Propius urbem accedente Cyro, proelio cum eo conflixerunt Babylonii: victi autem in urbem repulsi sunt. Tum Cyrus, derivato fluvio, per alveum Euphratis, nescientibus incolis, in urbem ingressus est. Capta autem est Babylon Labyneto rege.
text.eng: 82.— Cyrus, having subjected the whole continent of Lower Asia to his power, attacked the Assyrians. In Assyria, however, there were many notable cities, but the most famous and fortified of all was Babylon. The walls were two hundred feet high. As Cyrus approached closer to the city, the Babylonians engaged him in battle: but they were defeated and driven into the city. Then Cyrus, having diverted the river, entered the city through the bed of the Euphrates, unbeknownst to the inhabitants. Thus, Babylon was captured while Labynetus was king.

text.lat: The islanders of the Araxes.
text.eng: Araxis incolae.

text.lat: 83.— In flumine Araxe sunt insulae multae. In his habitantes homines aestate radicibus vescuntur cuiusque generis: fructus autem arborum servant, iisque per hiemem vescuntur. Fructus nonnullos in ignem coniiciunt; horum odore ebrii fiunt, ut Graeci vino: maiore vero copia fructuum incensa, magis ebrii fiunt: denique ad saltandum surgunt et ad canendum. His talis est vitae ratio.
text.eng: 83.— In the river Araxes there are many islands. In these the inhabitants during summer feed on the roots of each kind: but they preserve the fruits of trees, and with these they feed during the winter. Some fruits they throw into the fire; they become intoxicated by the smell of them, just as Greeks do with wine: with a greater quantity of fruits burned, they become even more intoxicated: finally, they rise to dance and to sing. Such is their way of life.

text.lat: The fate of Cyrus.
text.eng: Cyrus fata.

text.lat: 84.— Erat eo tempore Massagetarum imperium penes mulierem; hanc mortuus rex viduam reliquerat. Tomyris reginae nomen fuit. Hanc Cyrus missis legatis voluit sibi despondere, cupiens in matrimonio habere. Tomyris autem Cyrum sprevit. Post haec Cyrus, exercitu ad Araxem ducto, aperto bello Massagetas adortus est. Multos interfecere et cepere Persae: quum alios, tum reginae filium. Hic autem se ipse interemit. Sed Tomyris, collectis copiis, pugna cum Persis conflixit. Diu pugnatum est: tandem superiores Massagetae evasere. Inter alios et ipse Cyrus periit. Tum Tomyris Cyri caput in vase cruore repleto suspendit; mortuo his verbis irridens ait: ‘Tu me vivam, tuique victricem, perdidisti: filium enim meum interfecisti: te vero ego cruore satiabo.’
text.eng: 84.— At that time the Massagetae empire was in the hands of a woman; the deceased king had left her a widow. The name of the queen was Tomyris. Cyrus, having sent envoys, wished to betroth her to himself, desiring to have her in marriage. But Tomyris rejected Cyrus. After this, Cyrus, having led his army to the Araxes, openly attacked the Massagetae in war. The Persians killed many and captured others, including the son of the queen. However, he killed himself. But Tomyris, after gathering her troops, fought the Persians. The battle lasted a long time: in the end, the Massagetae became victorious. Among others, Cyrus himself perished. Then Tomyris hung Cyrus' head in a vessel filled with blood; mocking the dead she said: ‘You destroyed me, alive and victorious over you: for you killed my son: but I will satisfy you with blood.’
XVI.— SPARTAN BREVITY.
text.lat: XVI.— LACONICA BREVITAS.

85.— Samii olim, a Polycrate expulsi, Spartam venerunt. Introducti apud Ephoros multa fecerunt verba, opem orantes. At illi responderunt: ‘Priora verba obliti sumus, posteriora non intelligimus.’ Post haec iterum introducti, saccum ferentes nihil aliud dixerunt, nisi haec verba: ‘Saccus frumento eget.’ His Spartani responderunt: ‘Nunc intelligimus: opem vobis praestabimus.’
text.eng: 85.— Once, the Samians, expelled by Polycrates, came to Sparta. Introduced to the Ephors, they made many words, begging for aid. But they replied: 'We have forgotten the earlier words, we do not understand the latter.' After this, introduced again, carrying a sack, they said nothing else but these words: 'The sack lacks grain.' To this the Spartans replied: 'Now we understand: we will provide help to you.'
XVII.— THE BATTLE OF THE WHIPS.
text.lat: XVII.— PUGNA FLAGELLORUM.

86.— Olim servi contra Scythas seditione facta, aciem commisere. Diu pugnatum est. Tandem unus e Scythis talia dixit: ‘Quid tandem facimus, Scythae? Cum servis nostris pugnantes interficimur ipsi: his etiam interfectis, pauciores deinde habebimus. Itaque omissis hastis et sagittis, capiamus flagella, et in servos impetum faciamus: putant enim se nobis aequales et similes; sumptis vero flagellis, servitutem recordabuntur.’ His dictis paruerunt Scythae: servi autem flagella videntes, in fugam se recepere.
text.eng: 86.— Once upon a time, slaves, having started a rebellion against the Scythians, drew up a battle line. The fight was prolonged. Finally, one of the Scythians said the following: ‘What are we doing, Scythians? Fighting against our own slaves, we are being killed ourselves: even with them killed, we will have fewer anyway. So let us abandon spears and arrows, and take up whips, and make an attack on the slaves: for they consider themselves equal and similar to us; but once the whips are taken up, they will remember their servitude.’ The Scythians obeyed these words: but the slaves, seeing the whips, took flight.
XVIII— THE MAGIC RING.
text.lat: XVIII— ANNULUS MAGICUS.

87.— Gyges olim quidam, hiante terra post magnos quosdam imbres, descendit in illum hiatum, aeneumque equum conspexit. Huius in lateribus fores erant: his apertis, hominis mortui vidit corpus mira magnitudine, annulum aureum in digito habentis. Annulum ipse induit (erat autem servus regis), tum in concilium se servorum recepit. Ibi palam eius annuli in manum convertens, a nullo videbatur; ipse autem omnia videbat: idem annulum in locum restituit, tum rursus videbatur. Itaque, hac occasione annuli usus, regem dominum interfecit, et inimicos sustulit: nec in his facinoribus eum quisquam videre potuit. Sic annuli ope rex Lydiae factus est.
text.eng: 87.— A certain Gyges once, as the ground gaped open after some great rains, descended into this chasm and noticed a bronze horse. In its sides were doors: upon opening these, he saw the body of a dead man of remarkable size, bearing a golden ring on its finger. He himself put on the ring (he was a slave of the king), then entered the gathering of the servants. There, by turning the bezel of that ring in his hand, he was seen by no one; yet he saw everything himself: he restored the ring to its place and was then seen again. So, using this advantage of the ring, he killed the king, his master, and removed his enemies; yet no one could see him committing these crimes. By the ring's power, thus, he became the king of Lydia.
XIX.— TIT FOR TAT.
text.lat: XIX.—PAR PRO PARI.

88.— Scipio Nasica Ennio poeta amicissimo utebatur. Olim ad eum venit, et ad portam de eo quaesivit: ministra autem inquit: ‘Ennius domi non est.’ Videbat autem Ennium Nasica: nihil tamen dixit, sed domum reversus est. Paucis post diebus ad Nasicam venit Ennius. Huic ipse Nasica exclamavit, ‘Non sum domi’ Tum Ennius: ‘Quid? nonne cognosco vocem tuam?’ Nasica autem respondit: ‘Homo es impudens; ego enim ministrae tuae credidi: tu non mihi credis ipsi.’
text.eng: 88.— Scipio Nasica used to frequent the very friendly poet Ennius. One day he came to him and asked at the door for him: the servant, however, said: ‘Ennius is not at home.’ But Nasica saw Ennius: yet he said nothing, but returned home. A few days later Ennius came to Nasica. Nasica himself exclaimed to him, ‘I am not at home’ Then Ennius: ‘What? Do I not recognize your voice?’ Nasica, however, replied: ‘You are shameless; for I believed your servant: you do not believe me.’
XX.— A DISTINCTION WITHOUT A DIFFERENCE.
text.lat: XX.— DISTINCTIO SINE DIFFERENTIA.

89.— Alexander, Macedoniae rex, latronem captum his verbis interrogavit: ‘Quo tandem iure mare lacessis?’ Latro nihil timens respondit: ‘Ego et tu eodem iure utimur; unam autem parvam navem habeo; latro igitur vocor: tu autem magnis classibus et exercitibus praees; itaque victor vocaris.’
text.eng: 89.— Alexander, king of Macedonia, asked the captured robber with these words: 'By what right do you harass the sea?' The robber, fearing nothing, replied: 'You and I use the same right; however, I have one small ship; therefore I am called a robber: you, however, command large fleets and armies; thus you are called a victor.'
XXI.— SOLON’S PRECEPTS.
text.lat: XXI.— SOLONIS PRAECEPTA.

90.— Solon iuvenes haec praecepta docuisse dicitur. ‘Fidem pluris quam iusiurandum habetote: ne unquam mentiti sitis: rebus magnis operam date; ne amicitias ocius contraxeritis, contractas ne absolveritis; parere imperio edocti, ipsi aliis imperate. Ne suavissima consilia dederitis, sed optima; duci parete rationi: cum malis habitare nolite: deos colitote, patres matresque ne neglexeritis.’
text.eng: 90.— Solon is said to have taught the youth these precepts. ‘Hold faith more important than an oath: never lie: give attention to great matters; do not form friendships too hastily and do not break those you have formed; having learned to obey authority, command others yourselves. Do not give the sweetest advice, but the best; follow reason; do not live with wicked people: worship the gods, do not neglect your father and mother.’
I.— THE STORY OF POLYCRATES.
text.lat: I.— FABULA POLYCRATIS.
His riches.
text.eng: Divitiae eius.

text.lat: 91.— Polycrates, qui seditione facta Samum occupavit, primum trifariam distributam civitatem una cum fratribus administravit. Dein, altero occiso, et natu minore ex insula eiecto, universam Samum imperio tenebat. Quo in imperio cum Amasi, Aegypti rege, hospitium contraxit, donis ei missis, et vicissim ab illo acceptis. Brevi tempore magnopere auctae res sunt Polycratis, et per universam Ioniam reliquamque Graeciam celebratae sunt. Etenim quocumque cum exercitu proficiscebatur, omnia ei feliciter cedebant. Habebat autem centum actuarias naves quinquaginta remorum, et mille sagittarios: cunctosque homines nullo discrimine facto invadens, agebat ferebatque omnia. Aiebat enim, ‘Magis amico gratificabor, ea quae eripui restituens, quam ab initio nihil eripiens.’ Multas igitur insulas ceperat, multa item continentis oppida. In his Lesbios navali pugna superatos cepit, qui deinde fossam, murum Sami ambientem, vincti foderunt.
text.eng: 91.— Polycrates, who seized Samos after a revolution, first administered the city divided into three parts together with his brothers. Then, after one was killed and the younger was expelled from the island, he held the entire Samos under his rule. During this rule, he established a friendship with Amasis, king of Egypt, by sending him gifts, and receiving them in return. In a short time, Polycrates' affairs greatly increased and were celebrated throughout Ionia and the rest of Greece. For wherever he marched with his army, everything succeeded happily for him. He had a hundred fifty-oared galleys, and a thousand archers: attacking all men without any distinction, he carried and bore off everything. He used to say, ‘I will more gratify a friend by restoring what I have taken than by taking nothing from the beginning.’ Thus he had taken many islands, and also many cities of the mainland. Among these, he captured the Lesbians, defeated in a naval battle, who then, in chains, dug a trench surrounding the wall of Samos.

text.lat: The advice of Amasis.
text.eng: Consilium Amasis.

text.lat: 92.— Felicitas Polycratis Amasi placebat; sed ea res illi curae erat. Missis igitur literis haec ad eum perscripsit: ‘Amasis Polycrati salutem dicit. Placet valde mihi felicitas tua. At mihi non placent tuae res nimium secundae. Invidum est numen deorum qui mundum regunt. Itaque omnes, qui nimium florentibus rebus usi sunt, postremo pessimum finem habuerunt. Tu ergo, meum secutus consilium, adversus illam tuam nimiam felicitatem, fac hocce. Illud abiice, quod maximi tibi est pretii.’ His perlectis Polycrates, amici monitis paruit. Erat ei annulus, quem gestabat, auro vinctus, ex smaragdo lapide, Theodori opus, artificis praeclari. In navem conscendit, et detractum de manu annulum, conspicientibus cunctis qui in navi erant in mare proiecit. Hoc facto domum navigavit. At quinto aut sexto die postea res ei accidit huius modi. Piscator quidam ingentem piscem, quem ceperat, regi dedit. Famuli vero, qui piscem coquebant, in eius ventre Polycratis annulum reperiunt.
text.eng: 92.— The happiness of Polycrates pleased Amasis; but that matter was a concern to him. Therefore, sending letters, he wrote to him thus: ‘Amasis sends greetings to Polycrates. Your happiness pleases me greatly. But your very favorable fortunes do not please me. The divine will of the gods who govern the world is jealous. Therefore, all who have experienced excessive prosperity have ultimately had a very bad end. Therefore, following my advice, against your excessive happiness, do this. Throw away that which is of greatest value to you.’ Having read this, Polycrates obeyed his friend's advice. He had a ring, which he wore, bound in gold, with an emerald stone, a work of Theodorus, a renowned artist. He boarded a ship, and removing the ring from his hand, threw it into the sea, with all who were on the ship watching. Having done this, he sailed home. But on the fifth or sixth day after, this happened to him. A certain fisherman gave the king a large fish he had caught. The servants, who were cooking the fish, found the ring of Polycrates in its stomach.

text.lat: The fate of Polycrates.
text.eng: Fatum Polycratis.

text.lat: 93.— Tum rex in Aegyptum ad Amasin literas de facto misit. Amasis autem lectis literis valde commotus est. Itaque misso praecone Samum dissolvit hospitium, quod habebat cum Polycrate, iram deorum veritus. Polycrates vero brevi tempore postea ab Oroete, Lydiae satrape, interficitur, et cadaver in cruce suspenditur. Ita nimiam felicitatem morte expiavit.
text.eng: 93.— Then the king sent letters to Amasis in Egypt about the matter. Amasis, having read the letters, was greatly moved. Therefore, sending a herald, he dissolved the friendship with Samos, which he had with Polycrates, fearing the wrath of the gods. Polycrates, however, shortly afterward, was killed by Oroetes, the satrap of Lydia, and his body was hung on a cross. Thus he atoned for excessive happiness with death.
II.— THE STORY OF RHAMPSINITUS AND THE THIEF.
text.lat: II.— FABULA DE RHAMPSINITO ET FURE.

text.eng: The Temple of Vulcan.
text.lat: Templum Vulcani.

94.— Proteo in regnum Aegypti successit Rhampsinitus; qui monumenta sui reliquit propylaea templi Vulcani, occidentem spectantia. Ex adverso propylaeorum duas posuit statuas, viginti quinque cubitorum magnitudine: quarum illam quae stat a septentrione, Aestatem appellant Aegyptii; alteram, quae a meridie, Hiemem: et illam quidem, quam Aestatem vocant, adorant et donis placant; adversus illam, quae Hiems nominatur, contrarium faciunt.
text.eng: 94.— Rhampsinitus succeeded Proteus in the kingdom of Egypt; who left behind him monuments in the form of the propylaea to the temple of Vulcan, facing west. Opposite the propylaea, he set up two statues, each twenty-five cubits in height: of these, the one standing to the north the Egyptians call Summer; the other, to the south, Winter: and the one which they call Summer, they adore and appease with offerings; towards the one called Winter, they do the opposite.
The king’s treasure-house.
text.lat: Thesaurum regis.

95.— Hic rex magnas opes habebat, immensamque vim argenti. Itaque in tuto reponere suas pecunias cupiens, aedes aedificandas curavit lapideas. Is cui mandatum opus erat, pecuniam petens, hoc machinatus est. Ex lapidibus unum paravit, qui e muro facile eximi potuit, a duobus vel etiam ab uno homine. Absoluto aedificio, rex in illo divitias suas deposuit.
text.eng: 95.— This king had great wealth, and an immense amount of silver. Therefore, wishing to store his money safely, he caused a stone building to be erected. He to whom the construction was entrusted devised this plan. He prepared one stone among the others that could be easily removed from the wall by two or even by one man. When the building was completed, the king placed his wealth in it.
Two robbers spoil the treasures.
text.lat: Duo fures thesauros spoiliant.

96.— Interiecto autem tempore is, qui aedificium aedificaverat, prope vitae finem fuit. Advocatis igitur filiis duobus exposuit artificium. Perspicue illos lapidis speciem mensuramque docuit. Hoc igitur vita functo, filii haud multo postea operi admoverunt manus. Noctu ad aedificium accedentes, lapidem removerunt, et multum pecuniae extulere.
text.eng: 96.— In course of time, the man who had built the edifice neared the end of his life. Therefore, having called his two sons, he disclosed the trick. He clearly showed them the shape and measurement of the stone. Thus, after his death, the sons soon took action. Approaching the building by night, they removed the stone and took away a lot of money.
One of them is caught.
text.lat: Unus ex eis captus est.

97.— Postea rex aedificium aperuit, viditque valde diminutas pecunias; sigilla tamen ianuae salva erant, et aedificium clausum. Iterum autem et tertio aperiens, minus pecuniae in dies invenit. Itaque hoc fecit: laqueos statim paravit, eosque circa vasa, in quibus inerat pecunia, collocavit. Venerunt ut antea fures; alter, ad vas accedens, continuo captus est laqueis.
text.eng: 97.— Afterwards, the king opened the building, and observed that the money was greatly diminished; yet the seals of the door were intact, and the building was closed. Opening it a second and third time, he found less money each day. Therefore, he did this: he immediately prepared snares and placed them around the vessels that contained the money. The thieves came as before; one, approaching the vessel, was immediately caught in the snares.
A plan to avoid detection.
text.lat: Consilium ad evitandam detectionem.

98.— Frater vero caput fratris abscidit, adaptatoque iterum lapide domum abiit, caput secum ferens. Mane ingressus rex in aedificium obstupuit, conspecto corpore furis in laqueo constricti: videbat enim illaesum aedificium, nullumque vel exitum vel introitum. Itaque haerens animo hoc fecit. Cadaver furis ex muro suspendit, et custodes collocavit. His brother carries off the body.
text.eng: 98.— The brother, however, cut off his brother's head, replaced the stone, and went home, carrying the head with him. In the morning, the king entered the building and was astonished at the sight of the thief's body in the snare: for he saw the building intact, with no exit or entrance. Therefore, perplexed, he did this. He hung the thief's body from the wall and set guards around it. His brother carries off the body.
The reward of audacity.
text.lat: Praemium audaciae.
