100.— Regi factum renuntiatum est; quam rem primo aegerrime tulit; postea autem, et audacia et arte hominis attonitus, veniam et magna dona promisit. Fur edicto fidem adhibens, ad regem accessit, qui magna admiratione hominis ductus, filiam ei in matrimonium dedit.
text.eng: 100.— The deed was reported to the king; at first, he was very angry; but later, amazed by the courage and skill of the man, he promised pardon and great gifts. Trusting in the proclamation, the thief approached the king, who, struck by admiration for the man, gave him his daughter in marriage.
III.— OIL WELLS.
text.lat: III.— PUTEI OLEI.

101.— Sunt haud procul ab urbe Ardericca putei, qui tres diversas rerum species exhibent. Nam et asphaltus et sal et oleum ex illis hauriuntur, hoc modo. Hauriunt ope tollenonis, cui vas alligatum est; quod extulerunt e puteo, id in magnum vas infundunt; ex quo rursus in aliud receptaculum transvehitur, atque ita in triplicem formam convertitur. Et asphaltus quidem et sal concrescunt; oleum vero in vas colligunt: est autem illud nigrum, et gravem odorem spirat.
text.eng: 101.— There are wells near the city Ardericca, which produce three different types of substances. For asphalt, salt, and oil are drawn from them in this manner. They draw with the help of a crane, to which a vessel is attached; what they lift from the well, they pour into a large tank; from which it is transferred into another container, and thus it is converted into a threefold form. And indeed asphalt and salt solidify; but the oil is collected in a vessel: it is black, and emits a strong smell.
IV.— THE BODY-GUARD OF XERXES.
text.lat: IV.— CUSTODES CORPORIS XERXIS.

102.— Xerxem, Persarum regem, sequebantur mille pedites, fortissimi nobilissimique Persarum, erectas lanceas tenentes: deinde alii mille equites ex Persis selecti: et post equites, peditum decem millia e reliquis Persis selectorum: quorum mille in hastis, pro imis cuspidibus, aurea habebant mala punica, et reliquos includebant; novies mille vero, qui intra hos erant, argentea mala punica habebant. Aurea vero mala punica habebant etiam illi, qui lanceas in terram conversas tenebant; et mala aurea hi, qui Xerxem proxime sequebantur.
text.eng: 102.— Xerxes, the king of the Persians, was followed by a thousand foot soldiers, the bravest and noblest of the Persians, holding upright spears: then a thousand horsemen selected from the Persians: and after the horsemen, ten thousand foot soldiers selected from the remaining Persians: of whom a thousand held spears with gold pomegranates at the lower ends, enclosing the rest; and nine thousand within them, had silver pomegranates. Those who held their spears turned to the ground also had gold pomegranates; and those who followed closest to Xerxes also had gold pomegranates.
V.— A WEALTHY SUBJECT.
text.lat: V.— DIVES SUBJECTUS.

text.eng: His offers to the King.
text.lat: Suas offeras Regi.

103.— Olim Xerxem per Asiam iter facientem excepit Pythius quidam magnificis epulis, pecuniasque pollicitus est. Qui ubi pecunias obtulit, Xerxes ministros suos rogavit: ‘Quisnam hominum est Pythius, et quantas habet divitias?’ Cui illi responderunt: ‘Idem hic est, Rex, qui patri tuo Dario auream platanum, aureamque vitem dono dedit: estque post te, quos novimus, omnium hominum ditissimus.’ Miratus rex ipse deinde Pythio dixit: ‘Quantas habes divitias?’ Tum inquit Pythius: ‘Sunt mihi argenti talenta bis mille, auri vero maxima copia. Has ego pecunias tibi do: est enim mihi ex mancipiis atque agris satis victus.’
text.eng: 103.— Once, as Xerxes was traveling through Asia, a certain Pythius received him with magnificent feasts and promised money. When he offered the money, Xerxes asked his servants: 'Who is Pythius, and how great is his wealth?' They replied: 'This is the same man, King, who gave your father Darius a golden plane tree and a golden vine as a gift: and he is, after you, the richest of all men we know.' The amazed king then said to Pythius himself: ‘How much wealth do you have?’ Then Pythius said: ‘I have two thousand talents of silver, and a very large quantity of gold. I give this money to you: for I have sufficient sustenance from my slaves and fields.’
A kingly recompense.
text.lat: Regia merces.

104.— His ab illo dictis delectatus Xerxes respondit: ‘Pythi, nullum adhuc, praeter te, hominum reperi talia offerentem. Tu vero magnifice me excepisti, et pecunias ingentes polliceris. Tibi ergo invicem ego dona haecce tribuo: in meorum hospitum numero te repono: do tibi etiam magnum auri pondus. Perge vero retinere quae acquisivisti, ac semper talem te virum praesta. Haec facientem, neque nunc, nec in posterum te poenitebit.’
text.eng: 104.— Delighted by these words from him, Xerxes replied: ‘Pythius, I have found no man yet, besides you, offering such things. You have indeed received me splendidly, and promise vast sums of money. Therefore, in return, I bestow these gifts upon you: I place you in the number of my guests: I also give you a great weight of gold. Go on to keep what you have obtained, and always show yourself a man of such worth. Doing these, you will not be sorry now, nor in the future.’

text.lat: VI.— A BALD PEOPLE.
text.eng: VI.— A CALVUS POPULUS.

text.lat: 105.— Radices altorum montium habitant homines, qui calvi sunt omnes, mares pariter atque feminae, et simo naso. Vestem gestant Scythicam, ceterum arborum fructu vitam sustentant. Ponticum nomen arboris est, qua aluntur; fico admodum similis est. Fructum autem fert fabae similem, nucleum intus habentem. Maturos fructus pannis custodiunt, et, qui ab iis defluit niger et crassus, liquorem et lingunt, et lacte mixtum bibunt. Ex faece massas conficiunt, quibus vescuntur. Pecoram non magna illis copia est. Quilibet paterfamilias sub arbore habitat. Hieme quidem arborem tegunt tegmine e lana facto. His hominibus nemo iniuriam infert: sacri enim habentur; nec arma ulla bellica habent; iidem et finitimorum controversias dirimunt. His nomen est Argipaeis.
text.eng: 105.— At the roots of high mountains live the people, all of whom are bald, both males and females, and have a flat nose. They wear Scythian clothing, and they sustain their life with the fruit of trees. The name of the tree is Pontic, which they are nourished by; it is very similar to a fig. However, it bears a fruit similar to a bean, having a kernel within. They preserve the ripe fruits with cloths, and the liquid which flows from them, black and thick, they both lick and mix with milk to drink. They make cakes from the residue, which they eat. They do not have a large abundance of cattle. Each head of the family lives under a tree. Indeed, in winter, they cover the tree with a covering made of wool. No one does harm to these people: for they are considered sacred; nor do they have any warlike weapons; and they also settle the disputes of their neighbors. Their name is Argipaeis.
VII— THE FIRST WOODEN LEG.
text.lat: VII— PRIMUS CRUS LIGNEUM.

106.— Erat olim Hegesistratus quidam, quem Spartani in vincula coniecerant. Ille vero, hac calamitate circumventus, non modo capitis imminente poena, sed ante mortem etiam multos exspectans dolores, facinus commisit dictu incredibile. Ferreum forte instrumentum nactus, partem pedis sibi abscidit. Quo facto, perfosso pariete e carcere effugit, noctu iter faciens, interdiu vero inter fruticeta latens. Audacia hominis stupefacti sunt Spartani, qui videbant abscissum pedem humi iacentem, hominem autem reperire non poterant. Ille vero, sanato vulnere, ligneum pedem sibi ascivit.
text.eng: 106.— There was once a certain Hegesistratus, whom the Spartans had thrown into chains. He, however, surrounded by this calamity, with the death penalty impending, and expecting many pains before death, committed an act incredible to tell. Having obtained an iron tool by chance, he cut off part of his foot. Having done this, by making a hole in the wall he escaped from prison, traveling by night and hiding among bushes by day. The Spartans were astounded by the man's audacity, who saw the cut-off foot lying on the ground, but could not find the man. However, after healing his wound, he adopted a wooden foot.
I.— SYLOSON’S CLOAK.
text.lat: I.— SYLOSONIS PALLIUM.

text.eng: A seasonable gift.
text.lat: Donum tempestivum.

107.— Samum cepit rex Darius ob hanc caussam. Quo tempore Cambyses expeditionem in Aegyptum suscepit, plurimi Graeci in Aegyptum venerant; alii negotiandi caussa, alii ut regionem spectarent. Horum in numero erat Syloson, frater Polycratis, Samo exsulans. Huic Sylosonti talis quaedam fortuna oblata est. Quum rutilum pallium sumpsisset, hoc circumdatus obambulabat Memphi in foro. Quem ubi conspexit Darius, qui satelles tunc erat Cambysis, cupidine pallii captus, adiit Sylosontem ut illud emeret. Syloson divino quodam instinctu ait: ‘Equidem hoc pallium nullo pretio vendo: do tibi gratis.’ Quo laudato responso, Darius pallium accipit.
text.eng: 107.— King Darius took Samos for this reason. At the time when Cambyses undertook an expedition to Egypt, many Greeks had come to Egypt; some for the purpose of trade, others to see the region. Among these was Syloson, the brother of Polycrates, exiled from Samos. To this Syloson a certain fortune was offered. When he had taken up a red cloak, he walked around Memphis in the market, wearing it. When Darius, who was then a bodyguard of Cambyses, noticed Syloson, seized by a desire for the cloak, he approached Syloson to buy it. Syloson, driven by a certain divine impulse, said: ‘Indeed, I sell this cloak for no price: I give it to you for free.’ With this laudable response, Darius received the cloak.

text.lat: An idea strikes Syloson.
text.eng: Conceptus Sylosoni obitus.

text.lat: 108.— Interiecto vero tempore, postquam mortuo Cambyse adversus Magum coniuraverant septem viri, et ex septem virorum numero Darius imperio potitus erat, Syloson donum recordatus est. Itaque Susa adiit, sedensque in vestibulo aedium regiarum, ait, ‘Ego de Dario bene merui.’ Quod ubi audivit portae custos, renuntiavit regi. Darius miratus ait, ‘Quis tandem Graecus de me bene meruit?’ Vix unus aut nullus adhuc ex ilia gente ad me ascendit. Verum tamen producite eum.’
text.eng: 108.— After some time, when Cambyses had died and seven men had conspired against the Magus, and from the number of the seven men, Darius had gained power, Syloson remembered the gift. Thus, he went to Susa, and sitting in the vestibule of the royal palace, he said, ‘I have done a service to Darius.’ When the gatekeeper heard this, he reported it to the king. Darius, surprised, said, ‘What Greek has done a service to me?’ Scarcely any one or none from that nation has come up to me yet. Nonetheless, bring him.’
He obtains his reward.
text.lat: Mercedem recipit.

109.— Introducit ianitor Sylosontem, stantemque in medio interrogant interpretes: ‘Quis est? quove facto bene de rege meruisti?’ Exponit igitur rem omnem ad pallium pertinentem. Tum rex ait, ‘O liberalissime hominum, tune ergo ille es, qui mihi, quum nullam potestatem haberem, pallium dedisti? Itaque tibi ingens auri argentique pondus reddo, ne te doni poeniteat.’ Ad haec Syloson: ‘Ne mihi aurum neu argentum dederis. Sed patriam meam Samum mihi redde: quam nunc, postquam frater meus Polycrates ab Oroete interfectos est, servus noster tenet. Hanc mihi da, a caedibus et servitute liberatam.’ His auditis, Darius exercitum misit, ducemque Otanen, ut omnia faceret quae Syloson oraverat.
text.eng: 109.— The doorkeeper introduced Syloson, and standing in the middle, the interpreters ask: ‘Who is he? and for what deed have you done a service to the king?’ Then he explained all the matter concerning the cloak. Then the king said, ‘O most generous of men, are you therefore he who gave me the cloak when I had no power? Therefore, I give you a great weight of gold and silver, lest you regret your gift.’ To this Syloson replied: ‘Do not give me gold or silver. But give back my native land Samos to me: which, now that my brother Polycrates was killed by Oroetes, our servant holds. Grant this to me, freed from slaughter and servitude.’ On hearing this, Darius sent an army, and the leader Otanes, to do all that Syloson had asked.
II.— THE STORY OF ZOPYRUS.
text.lat: II.— FABULA ZOPYRI.

110.— Postquam classis Samum erat profecta, Babylonii a Persis defecerunt, rebus omnibus bene praeparatis. Nam quo tempore Magus regnavit, et adversus eum septem viri insurrexerunt, ut tolerarent obsidionem, sese praeparaverant. In quaque domo, omnes mulieres suffocaverunt, exceptis matribus, et una uxore, quamcunque quisque vir eximi voluerat: unam autem, quam dixi, eximebat quisque quae panem conficeret. Suffocarunt autem illas, ne frumentum consumerent.
text.eng: 110.— After the fleet had set out for Samos, the Babylonians revolted from the Persians, having prepared all things well. For at the time when the Magus reigned, and seven men rose against him, they prepared themselves to endure a siege. In each house, they suffocated all the women, except mothers and one wife, whichever each man chose to keep: but the one, which I mentioned, was kept by each to make bread. They suffocated them, moreover, so as not to consume the grain.
The townsmen deride the besiegers.
text.lat: Urbes incolae obsidentes irrident.

111.— His rebus cognitis Darius, contractis universis suis copiis, adversus eos profectus est; admotoque exercitu, urbem obsedit. At obsidionem parvi faciebant Babylonii; nam in propugnacula muri ascendentes tripudiabant, irridebantque Dario et eius exercitui. Unus etiam ex iis dixit: ‘Cur hic sedetis, Persae? cur non abitis? tunc enim nos capietis, quum mulae pepererint.’ Hoc dixit, quod mulae non pariunt ut cetera animalia.
text.eng: 111.— When these things were known to Darius, he gathered his entire forces and set out against them; and having advanced the army, he besieged the city. But the Babylonians made little of the siege; for ascending the towers of the walls they capered and mocked Darius and his army. One of them even said: ‘Why do you sit here, Persians? Why don't you leave? For then you will take us, when mules give birth.’ He said this because mules do not give birth like other animals.
Obstinate defence of the city.
text.lat: Tenax urbis defensio.

112.— Integer annus iam et septem menses erant elapsi, taedioque affectus erat Darius exercitusque, quod expugnare urbem non valebant. Omnibus enim artificiis omnibusque machinamentis adhibitis, nihil Darius profecerat. Tentaverat autem et alia artificiorum genera, et illud etiam quo Cyrus urbem ceperat: per alveum scilicet Euphratis in urbem ingredi conatus; sed ita diligenter custodias agebant Babylonii, ut capi nullo pacto possent.
text.eng: 112.— A whole year and seven months had already passed, and Darius and the army were wearied because they could not capture the city. For with all the arts and devices applied, Darius achieved nothing. He had tried also other kinds of arts, and even that by which Cyrus had taken the city: namely, attempting to enter through the channel of the Euphrates into the city; but the Babylonians so diligently guarded that they could not be captured in any way.
Coming events cast their shadow before.
text.lat: Ventura praenuntias apparent.

113.— Ibi tum, quum vicesimus ageretur mensis, Zopyro cuidam tale prodigium obtigit: una ex ipsius mulabus peperit. Recordatus igitur Babylonii illius verbum, qui dixerat, ‘Tunc Babylon capietur, quum mulae pepererint,’ magnopere gavisus est. Darium adiens quaesivit ex eo, ‘Nonne vis Babylonem capere?’ Cui rex, ‘Maximi equidem hoc facio.’
text.eng: 113.— Then, when the twentieth month was being completed, such a prodigy befell a certain Zopyrus: one of his mules gave birth. Therefore, recalling the word of the Babylonian who had said, ‘Then Babylon will be taken, when mules give birth,’ he greatly rejoiced. Approaching Darius, he asked him, ‘Do you not wish to capture Babylon?’ To which the king replied, ‘I certainly do value it greatly.’
Zopyrus mutilates himself.
text.lat: Zopyrus se mutilat.

114.— Tum Zopyrus secum deliberavit: volebat enim urbem per se ipsum capere: nam apud Persas res bene gestae maximis honoribus rependuntur. Hoc autem nulla alia ratione fieri posse videbatur, nisi si se ipse mutilasset, atque ita ad Babylonios transfugisset. Ibi tum, parvi hoc pendens, abscissis naribus auribusque, flagellis laceratus, regem adit.
text.eng: 114.— Then Zopyrus deliberated with himself: for he wished to capture the city by himself, as well-doing is repaid with great honors among Persians. However, this seemed possible in no other way, except if he had mutilated himself, and thus fled to the Babylonians. Then, caring little for this, having cut off his nose and ears, and lacerated by whips, he approached the king.
He presents himself before the king.
text.lat: Regi se sistit.

115.— Darius, quum virum nobilissimum ita mutilatum vidisset, vehementer motus, e solio subsiliens dixit, ‘Quis te ita mutilavit, quaque de caussa?’ Cui Zopyrus respondit, ‘O rex, hoc ipse feci, indignatus Assyriis Persas deridentibus.’ Tum Darius: ‘Quo vero pacto, stulte, ob hanc caussam citius in potestatem hostes redigentur? Anne mente es alienatus, qui te ita perdidisti?’
text.eng: 115.— Darius, having seen such a noble man mutilated, was very moved, and jumping from the throne said, ‘Who has mutilated you thus, and for what cause?’ To which Zopyrus replied, ‘O king, I did this myself, indignant at the Assyrians mocking the Persians.’ Then Darius: ‘How indeed, fool, shall the enemies be taken more quickly because of this cause? Are you of sound mind, having destroyed yourself thus?’
Zopyrus’ plan.
text.lat: Consilium Zopyri.

116.— Respondit Zopyrus: ‘O rex, ad murum me conferam: dicam etiam, “Hoc fecit Darius:” tum hostes exercitum mihi committent. Tu vero, decimo inde die de illa copiarum parte, cuius iacturam minime aegre feres, mille homines contra portam colloca, quae Semiramidis vocatur. Deinde rursus post aliquot dies, alios bis mille contra Niniam, ut vocatur, portam colloca. Nec vero priores, neque hi, aliud habeant praeter gladios: hoc uno telo armati sint. Nam ut equidem puto, quum praeclara facta edidero, et reliqua meae fidei committent Babylonii, et portarum obices. Tum ego urbem tibi tradere potero.’
text.eng: 116.— Zopyrus replied: ‘O king, I will go to the wall and say, “Darius did this:” then the enemies will entrust the army to me. But you, on the tenth day from hence, place a thousand men, whose loss you will least mind, against the gate called the Gate of Semiramis. Then again after some days, place another two thousand against the gate called Ninian. Neither those before, nor these, should have other arms but swords: they should be armed with this one weapon. For I believe indeed, when I have performed splendid deeds, the Babylonians will entrust the rest to my faith and the bars of the gates. Then I shall be able to deliver the city to you.’
He goes to the city and tells his story.
text.lat: Ad urbem it et fabulam suam narrat.

117.— Quum haec mandavisset, ad portam perrexit. Quem ubi conspexerunt ii qui in turribus speculandi caussa stationem habebant, raptim descendunt, et interrogant, ‘Quisnam es, et cur huc venis?’ Ille contra, ‘Mihi nomen est Zopyro, et ad vos ut transfuga venio.’ Quibus auditis, portae custodes in curiam ducunt. Ibi coram senatu constitutus, sortem suam deplorans, ait, ‘A Dario haec passus sum. Nunc ad vos, Babylonii, venio, maximo vobis commodo futurus; Dario autem Persisque maximo detrimento. Nec enim impune hoc fecit, qui me ita mutilavit. Exploratas habeo omnes vias consiliorum.’
text.eng: 117.— Having delivered these orders, he went to the gate. When they saw him, those who were stationed in the towers for the purpose of watching, they quickly descended and asked, ‘Who are you, and why do you come here?’ He replied, ‘My name is Zopyrus, and I come to you as a deserter.’ Having heard this, the guards of the gate led him into the council. There, standing before the senate, he bewailed his fate and said, 'I suffered these things from Darius. Now I come to you, Babylonians, to be of the greatest advantage to you; but to Darius and the Persians, a great harm. For he, who mutilated me thus, did not do this with impunity. I have all ways of planning explored.'
He obtains command of their troops.
text.lat: Imperium copiarum obtinet.

118.— Quae quum locutus esset, Babylonii videntes virum inter Persas nobilissimum, naribus auribusque mutilatum, ut socium Zopyrum acceperunt. Postulabat autem armatorum manum; itaque copiis praefectus est. Tum vero, postquam copias impetravit, ea facere instituit, de quibus cum Dario convenerat.
text.eng: 118.— When he had spoken these things, the Babylonians seeing a man most noble among the Persians, mutilated in nose and ears, accepted Zopyrus as an ally. He then demanded a band of armed men; thus he was put in command of the troops. Then indeed, after he obtained the troops, he began to do those things concerning which he had agreed with Darius.
The city is taken.
text.lat: Urbs capitur.

119.— Decimo die, educto Babyloniorum exercitu, mille illos, quos certo loco Darius constituit, circumdatos interfecit. Tum iterum copias eduxit, et bis mille illos, quos supra memoravi, Darii milites interfecit. Quibus rebus gestis, imperii summa et muri custodia eidem permissa est. Tum Zopyrus aperta porta Persas intra murum recepit. Hoc igitur modo urbs Babylon capta est.
text.eng: 119.— On the tenth day, having brought out the Babylonian army, he surrounded and killed the thousand Darius had placed at a fixed place. Then he again led out the troops and killed the two thousand Darius soldiers I mentioned above. With these things done, the supreme command and the guardianship of the wall were entrusted to him. Then Zopyrus opened the gate and admitted the Persians inside the wall. Thus in this way, the city of Babylon was captured.
III.—PERSIAN COURIERS.
text.lat: III.—CURSORES PERSICI.

120.— Apud Persas, quum aliquid nuntiare volunt, hoc faciunt. Quot dierum est universum iter, tot dispositi et equi et viri in quaque diurna statione parati stant; quos nec imber, nec nox, nec aestus, nec nix impedit quominus suum quisque cursum quam celerrime conficiat. Nempe, qui primus currit, is secundo tradit mandata, secundus tertio; atque sic deinceps, alii atque alii tradita, mandata per singulos transeunt.
text.eng: 120.—Among the Persians, when they want to announce something, they do this. As many days as the whole journey takes, so many horses and men are stationed at each daily post, ready; whom neither rain, nor night, nor heat, nor snow prevents from completing each one's course as quickly as possible. Indeed, he who runs first delivers the orders to the second, the second to the third; and thus successively, others hand over the commands, and the orders pass through each one.
IV.— A MIRACLE.
text.lat: IV.— MIRACULUM.

121.— Spartanus quidam uxorem habuit longe formosissimam omnium quae Spartae erant mulierum: quae quidem formosissima ex deformissima evaserat. Etenim quum turpis fuisset aspectu, nutrix illius, puellam ita deformem videns, quae opulenti patris filia erat, quia valde dolebat ob turpem filiae formam, tale inivit consilium.
text.eng: 121.— A certain Spartan had the most beautiful wife of all the women who were in Sparta: for she had indeed become most beautiful from being most deformed. For when she had been ugly in appearance, her nurse, seeing the child so deformed, who was the daughter of a wealthy father, because she was very grieved by the ugly form of the daughter, devised such a plan.

text.lat: Quotidie gestabat eam in Helenae templum: quoties autem eo gestasset, statuebat ante deae simulacrum, supplexque deam ita alloquebatur: ‘O dea, deformitate puellam libera. Ne tam turpem formam passa sis.’
text.eng: Every day she carried her into the temple of Helen: whenever she had carried her there, she would place her before the statue of the goddess and humbly speak to the goddess thus: 'O goddess, free the girl from deformity. Do not allow her to endure such an ugly form.'

text.lat: Iam die quodam, quum templo egrederetur nutrix, apparuisse ei dicitur mulier, quaerens ex ea: ‘Quid in ulna gestas?’ Cui quum illa respondisset, ‘Puellam gesto,’ dixit mulier, ‘Mihi puellam monstra.’ Neganti nutrici, dicentique, ‘Tam turpis est, ut nemini monstrare velim,’ institit mulier dictitans, ‘Mihi puellam monstra.’ Denique ostendit nutrix.
text.eng: One day, when the nurse was leaving the temple, it is said a woman appeared to her, asking her: 'What do you carry in your arm?' When she had replied, 'I carry a girl,' the woman said, 'Show me the girl.' To the nurse who refused and said, 'She is so ugly that I wish to show her to no one,' the woman insisted, repeatedly saying, 'Show me the girl.' Finally, the nurse showed her.

text.lat: Mulier autem, tacto puellae capita, dixit, ‘Formae praestantia superabit haec Spartanas omnes mulieres.’ Atque inde ab illo ipso die, forma puellae mutata est.
text.eng: The woman, however, having touched the girl's head, said, 'This one will surpass all Spartan women in excellence of form.' And from that very day, the girl's form was changed.
V.— THE SPICE TRADE.
text.lat: V.— COMMERCIUM AROMATUM.

text.eng: Frankincense and cassia.
text.lat: Tus et casia.

122.— Extrema habitatarum regionum Arabia est. In hac vero una omnium regionum tus nascitur, et myrrha, et casia, et cinnamomum. Haec quidem omnia, myrrham si excipias, non sine labore nanciscuntur Arabes. Tus quidem colligunt quum styracem adoluerunt, qui in Graeciam a Phoenicibus importatur. Styrace incenso tus nanciscuntur; arbores enim turiferas custodiunt alati serpentes, exiguo corpore, variegata specie, ingenti numero arborem quamque circumsedentes. Nulla vero alia re nisi styracis fumo, hi ab arboribus illis abiguntur. Dei autem providentia vere est sapiens. Nam, et quae timidae indolis sunt animalia, et quae esculenta, ea omnia fecunda fecit, ne genus eorum intereat; quae vero prava et malefica, parum fecunda. Tus igitur ista ratione Arabes nanciscuntur: casiam vero hoc modo. Toto corpore atque facie, solis oculis exceptis, bubulis aliisve coriis tecti, exeunt ut casiam colligant. Nascitur haec autem in palude non admodum alta, circa quam vivunt bestiae alatae, vespertilionibus maxime similes, diro modo stridentes, et viribus praevalentes. Has quum ab oculis abegerunt, casiam metunt.
text.eng: 122.— Arabia is at the extremity of the inhabited regions. In this land alone of all regions, frankincense is found, and myrrh, and cassia, and cinnamon. Indeed, these all, except myrrh, are obtained by the Arabians not without labor. Indeed, they gather frankincense when they have kindled styrax, which is imported to Greece by Phoenicians. By burning the styrax, they obtain frankincense; for the fragrant trees are guarded by winged serpents, of small body, variegated appearance, surrounding each tree in great numbers. They are driven away from those trees by nothing but the smoke of styrax. But indeed the providence of God is truly wise. For, those animals which are of timid nature, and which are for eating, He made all fruitful, that their kin may not perish; but those which are wicked and harmful, are unfruitful. Thus, therefore, the Arabians obtain frankincense: and cassia as follows. With the whole body and face, except only the eyes, covered with ox or other skins, they go out to collect cassia. This grows in a not very deep marsh, around which dwell winged creatures, very similar to bats, shrieking in a dire manner, and prevailing in strength. When they have driven them away from their eyes, they harvest the cassia.
How to procure cinnamon.
text.lat: Quomodo cinnamomum obtineatur.

123.— Cinnamomum vero mirabiliori etiam modo colligunt. In iis regionibus nasci creditur, in quibus Bacchus educatus est. Narrantur autem ingentes aves afferre hos bacillos, quos nos a Phoenicibus edocti cinnamomum vocamus. Hi bacilli inferuntur ab illis avibus in nidos, e luto astructos ad montium praecipitia, ne quis homini accessus pateat. Tali igitur artificio utuntur Arabes. Boum et asinorum aliorumque iumentorum cadavera, in frusta grandi magnitudine dissecta, congerunt in haec loca. Haec quum in vicinia nidorum deposuerunt, procul inde recedunt: tum volucres descendentes iumentorum illorum membra tollunt et in nidos comportant. Hi autem, quum sustinere onus non possint, rumpuntur et in terram decidunt. Tunc accurrentes homines, cinnamomum colligunt, quod in alias regiones portatur.
text.eng: 123.— They gather cinnamon in an even more remarkable way. It is believed to grow in those regions where Bacchus was nurtured. It is said that huge birds bring these twigs, which we, having learned from the Phoenicians, call cinnamon. These twigs are carried into nests by these birds, constructed of clay on mountain precipices, to which no access is open to man. Thus, therefore, the Arabians employ such an artifice. The carcasses of the oxen and donkeys and other beasts, cut into pieces of large size, they pile in those places. When they have deposited these near the vicinity of the nests, they retreat far away: then the birds descending take up these pieces of beasts and carry them into the nests. But these, since they cannot bear the weight, break and fall to the ground. Then running men collect the cinnamon, which is carried into other regions.
VI.— THE GOLD ANTS.
text.lat: VI.— FORMICAE AUREAE.

124.— Nonnulli sunt Indi Caspatyro urbi finitimi. Hi sunt Indorum bellicosissimi, iidemque qui ut colligant aurum proficiscuntur. Est enim ibi deserta regio propter arenam: et in hac arena sunt formicae, magnitudine non quidem tanta quanta canum, sed tamen maiores vulpibus. Hae igitur formicae, sub terra habitantes, fodiunt arenam eodem modo quo in Graecia formicae, quibus etiam specie corporis simillimae sunt. Arena autem, quae ab illis eiicitur, aurifera est. Itaque ut hanc colligant, profecturi Indi iungunt quisque tres camelos, funalem utrinque marem; in medio feminam, data opera ut a pullis quam nuperrime abstracta iungatur: hanc ipse conscendit. Sunt enim cameli equis velocitate non inferiores, insuper vero ad onera ferenda multo validiores: feminae autem a pullis abstractae celerrimae sunt. Camelus in posterioribus cruribus quatuor habet femora et quatuor genua. Hoc igitur modo, talique utentes vectura, ut colligant aurum proficiscuntur Indi. Colligunt autem aurum ea diei hora, qua ferventissimi sunt aestus: fervente enim aestu sub terra conduntur formicae. Postquam ad locum Indi pervenerunt, saccis quos secum attulere arena completis, et in camelos mares impositis, sese recipiunt quam celerrime possunt. Protinus enim formicae, odore, ut aiunt Persae, illos sentientes, persequuntur. Velocitate autem haec bestia alias omnes ita superat ut nisi, dum congregantur formicae, viam interim Indi praeciperent, nullus eorum salvus evasurus esset. Maiorem igitur auri partem hac ratione, ut quidem Persae narrant, nanciscuntur Indi; aliud rarius est aurum quod ex metallis effoditur.
text.eng: 124.— Some are Indians neighboring the city of Caspatyrus. These are the most warlike of the Indians, and also those who go to collect gold. For there is a deserted region because of the sand there: and in this sand are ants, not indeed as large as dogs, but larger than foxes. These ants, dwelling underground, dig the sand in the same manner as ants in Greece, to which they are also very similar in body shape. The sand, however, which is thrown out by them, is gold-bearing. Therefore, in order to collect this, the Indians prepare by attaching three camels each, a tethered male on each side; in the middle, a female, with care taken that she is yoked just after being separated from her young: he mounts her. For camels are not inferior to horses in speed, and furthermore are much stronger for carrying burdens: females, however, separated from their young, are very swift. The camel has four thighs and four knees in its hind legs. Thus, using such transportation, the Indians set out to collect the gold. They gather the gold at the hour of the day when the heat is most intense: for in the heat the ants are buried underground. After the Indians have reached the place, with the sacks they brought filled with sand, and loaded onto the male camels, they withdraw as quickly as possible. For immediately the ants, sensing them by smell, as the Persians say, pursue them. This creature, however, surpasses all others in speed so that unless the Indians take the road while the ants are gathering, none of them would escape safely. Therefore, the Indians acquire the greater part of the gold by this method, as the Persians indeed relate; other gold is rarer, which is dug from mines.
VII.— LIBYA.
text.lat: VII.— LIBYA.

text.eng: A curious kind of oxen.
text.lat: Mirum genus boum.

125.— In Libya habitant homines, quibus nomen est Garamantibus. Horum in terra nascuntur boves qui retro gradientes pasci dicuntur. Hoc autem faciunt, quod cornua habent in anterius curvata; qua de caussa retro gradientes pascuntur: nam progredientes pasci non possunt, quoniam, priusquam progredi possint, cornua in terram impinguntur. Ab aliis bobus nil differunt, nisi hoc ipso, et corii crassitudine, duritieque.
text.eng: 125.— In Libya dwell people called the Garamantes. In their land are born oxen said to graze walking backwards. They do this because they have horns curving forwards; therefore, they graze walking backwards: for they cannot graze walking forwards, as their horns strike the ground before they can step forward. They differ in nothing from other oxen except in this and the thickness and hardness of their hide.
The cave-dwellers.
text.lat: Incolae antrorum.

126.— Iidem Garamantes quadrigis venantur Troglodytas Aethiopas. Troglodytae autem vocantur, quod in antris vivunt; troglus autem dicitur antrum. Sunt enim hi Troglodytae pedibus pernicissimi omnium hominum, de quibus unquam audivimus. Vescuntur autem Troglodytae serpentibus atque lacertis, et eius modi reptilibus: sermone vero utuntur nulli alii simili, sed strident veluti noctuae.
text.eng: 126.— The same Garamantes hunt the Ethiopian Troglodytes with chariots. They are called Troglodytes because they live in caves; for a cave is called troglus. These Troglodytes are indeed the swiftest on foot of all people we have ever heard of. The Troglodytes feed on serpents and lizards, and such reptiles: they use speech unlike any other, but screech like owls.
VIII.— THE SPARTAN KINGS.
text.lat: VIII.— REGES SPARTANIS.

127.— Honores et privilegia regibus Spartanis tributa haec sunt. Sacerdotia duo, Iovis Lacedaemonii et Iovis Caelestis: tum belli inferendi potestas: cui potestati intercedere nemo potest quin capitis damnetur. Quum in bellum proficiscuntur, primi incedunt reges, postremi redeunt: a delectis viris centum in exercitu custodiuntur. Victimis utuntur in expeditionibus, quotcumque volunt; et omnium immolatarum pecudum et pelles et terga accipiunt.
text.eng: 127.— The honors and privileges granted to the Spartan kings are these. Two priesthoods, of Jupiter Lacedaemonian and of Jupiter Celestial: then the power to declare war: no one can interfere with this power without being sentenced to death. When they set out for war, the kings go first, they return last: they are guarded in the army by one hundred chosen men. They use as many sacrifices in expeditions as they want; and they receive the skins and backs of all the slaughtered animals.
Their honours in time of peace.
text.lat: Eorum honores in tempore pacis.

128.— In pace eisdem honores et praemia concessa sunt. Si quis publicum facit sacrificium, primi in coena sedent reges; et ab his fit distribuendorum ciborum initium; ita quidem ut utrique regi duplex portio tribuatur. In omnibus ludis sedes optimas habent. Rex uterque duos nominat Pythios: sunt autem Pythii cives qui Delphos mittuntur oracula consultum. Quando ad coenam non veniunt reges, utrique domum cibus et vinum mittuntur; praesentibus vero duplex portio tribuitur. Iudicant soli reges de omnibus rebus.
text.eng: 128.— In peace, the same honors and rewards are granted. If anyone makes a public sacrifice, the kings are the first to sit at the table; and from them begins the distribution of food; indeed, each king is given a double portion. In all games, they have the best seats. Each king nominates two Pythii: these are citizens sent to Delphi to consult the oracle. When the kings do not attend dinner, both are sent food and wine home; when present, however, a double portion is granted. Only the kings judge all matters.
Respect paid to them when dead.
text.lat: Reverentia eis mortuis.

129.— Ista igitur viventibus regibus praemia tribuuntur: mortuis vero haecce. Nuntiant equites mortem regis per totam Laconiam: in urbe vero circumeuntes mulieres lebetem pulsant. Quo facto ex quaque domo vir et femina luctu squalent: id ni faciunt, gravem multam incurrunt. Mortuo rege omnes undique coeunt cives ad funus prosequendum. Quod si in bello mortuus est, eius simulacrum effingunt, et pulchre strato lectulo impositum efferunt. Sepulto rege per decem dies fit ingens luctus. Mortui regis successor in regni sui auspiciis aere alieno liberat quemlibet Spartanum.
text.eng: 129.— These awards are given to the living kings: to the dead, however, the following. Knights announce the king's death throughout all Laconia: in the city, indeed, women walk around striking a cauldron. By this act, each household has a man and a woman dirty with mourning: if they do not do this, a severe penalty is incurred. When the king dies, all citizens gather everywhere to follow the funeral. If he has died in war, they make a representation of him and carry it with honors on a beautifully adorned couch. With the king buried, there is great mourning for ten days. The successor of a dead king, under his auspices, frees any Spartan from debt.
Hereditary professions.
text.lat: Professio hereditarium.

130.— Cum Aegyptiis vero hoc commune Lacedaemonii habent; apud illos praecones et tibicines et coqui in patrias artes succedunt: et tibicen filius est tibicinis, coquus coqui, praeco praeconis: neque praeconis filium alius, ob vocis claritatem munus hoc ambiens, excludit: sed quilibet negotium suum patrio more exsequitur. Atque haec ita se habent.
text.eng: 130.— However, with the Egyptians, this is common among the Lacedaemonians; among them, heralds, flute players, and cooks succeed in their ancestral crafts: and the son of a flute player is a flute player, a cook is the son of a cook, a herald is the son of a herald: no one excludes the son of a herald, desiring this role for the clarity of his voice: but everyone performs his business in the manner of their father. And thus these things are so.
IX.— THE FAMILY OF THE ALCMAEONIDAE.
text.lat: IX.— ALCMAEONIDARUM FAMILIA.

text.eng: Its canny founder.
text.lat: Astutus conditor.

131.— Fuit autem Athenis iam antiquitus illustris Alcmaeonidarum familia; nam inde ab Alcmaeone ipso, exstitere in hac domo nobilissimi viri. Olim Alcmaeon a Croeso Lydiae rege missus erat, ut oraculum Delphicum consuleret. Cuius in se merita quum Croesus cognosset, Sardes eum ad se invitavit; et postquam advenit, tanto auri pondere eundem donavit, quantum suo corpore asportare semel posset. Tunc Alcmaeon ad accipiendum donum in hunc modum comparatus accessit. Grandi indutus tunica, in qua magnus erat sinus relictus, et cothurnis, quos repererat amplissimos, calceatus, in thesaurum intravit. Ibi quum in acervum ramentorum auri incidisset, primum circa crura, quantum auri capiebant cothurni, infersit; deinde completo toto sinu, et coma ramentis conspersa, denique aliis in os sumptis, thesauro egressus est, aegre trahens cothurnos. Quem quum conspexisset Croesus, risum non tenuit, dedit autem non haec modo, sed alia etiam adiecit. Ita magnis divitiis aucta est haec domus, idemque Alcmaeon, equos alens quadrigis iungendos; Olympicam victoriam reportavit.
text.eng: 131.— In Athens, there was from ancient times an illustrious family of the Alcmaeonidae; for from Alcmaeon himself, very noble men emerged from this house. Once, Alcmaeon had been sent by Croesus, king of Lydia, to consult the Delphic oracle. When Croesus recognized his merits, he invited him to Sardis; and after Alcmaeon arrived, Croesus gave him as much gold as he could carry on his body at one time. Then Alcmaeon, prepared in this way to receive the gift, went in. Wearing a large tunic with a big pouch left free and wearing the largest boots he could find, he entered the treasury. Once he had fallen into the heap of gold dust, he first tucked as much gold as the boots could hold around his legs; then, with his entire pouch filled and his hair sprinkled with gold dust, and finally holding some in his mouth, he left the treasury, barely dragging the boots. When Croesus saw this, he could not hold back his laughter, and not only gave these things but also added others. Thus, this house was increased with great riches, and the same Alcmaeon, maintaining horses to be joined to chariots, won the Olympic victory.
Wanted, a husband.
text.lat: Quaerebatur, maritus.

132.— Deinde vero, sequente aetate, eandem familiam Clisthenes, Sicyonis tyrrannus, ita praeclaram fecit, ut multo etiam splendidior inter Graecos fieret, quam antea fuerat. Clisthenes autem, quum esset ei filia nomine Agariste, in matrimonium hanc dare decreverat iuveni, quemcunque reperisset Graecorum omnium praestantissimum. Quumque essent ludi Olympici, in quibus curriculo quadrigarum vicit Clisthenes, nuntiari per praeconem iusserat; ‘quisquis Graecorum dignum sese iudicat qui gener fiat Clisthenis, is ad sexagesimum diem, aut etiam ante id tempus, Sicyonem adeat: exacto enim anno ab illo sexagesimo die, ratas filiae nuptias habebit Clisthenes.’ Tunc igitur convenere proci, quotquot e Graecia vel sua vel patriae praestantia superbiebant: hisque Clisthenes et curriculum et palaestram, quibus inter se certarent, parata habebat.
text.eng: 132.— Then, in the following age, Clisthenes, the tyrant of Sicyon, made the same family so illustrious, that it became much more splendid among the Greeks than it had been before. Clisthenes, however, since he had a daughter named Agariste, decided to give her in marriage to the most outstanding young man among all the Greeks. And when there were the Olympic games, in which Clisthenes won the chariot race, he ordered it to be announced by a herald; ‘whoever among the Greeks judges himself worthy to become the son-in-law of Clisthenes, let him come to Sicyon on the sixtieth day or even before that time; for Clisthenes will confirm the marriage of his daughter after the end of the year from that sixtieth day.’ Then indeed suitors gathered, as many as boasted of the superiority of themselves or their country in Greece, and Clisthenes had prepared both a racecourse and a wrestling ground for them to compete with each other.
Trial of the applicants.
text.lat: Certamen procorum.

133.— Maximus igitur numerus procorum convenit, et in his Megacles, Alcmaeonis filius qui apud Croesum fuerat, et Hippoclides, divitiis et corporis forma praeclarus inter Athenienses. Qui quum ad diem dictum convenissent, Clisthenes primum patrias eorum sciscitatus est, et genus cuiusque, deinde per anni spatium eos retinens, pertentavit fortitudinem, et animi impetum, et culturam ingenii, et mores; modo cum singulis congressus, modo cum universis; et, qui ex illis iuniores erant, hos in gymnasia ducens: maxime vero inter epulas eos pertentabat. Placuerunt ei autem fere prae ceteris hi qui Athenis advenerant; et ex his magis ei probabatur Hippoclides.
text.eng: 133.— Thus the greatest number of suitors gathered, among them Megacles, son of Alcmaeon who had been with Croesus, and Hippoclides, renowned among the Athenians for wealth and appearance. When they had gathered on the appointed day, Clisthenes first inquired about their fatherlands and the lineage of each, keeping them for the span of a year, testing their strength, spirit, cultivation of mind, and manners; sometimes meeting individually, sometimes with all; and leading those who were younger among them into gymnasiums: but he especially examined them during feasts. Among them, those who had come from Athens pleased him most; and among these, Hippoclides was more approved by him.
An unfortunate dance.
text.lat: Infaustus saltus.

134.— Die dicto, Clisthenes mactatis centum bobus, et ipsos procos et cunctos Sicyonios lautis epulis excepit. Peracta coena, proci et canendo et sermonibus in medio propositis inter se contendebant. Procedente vero compotatione, Hippoclides tibicinem iussit cantos canere ad saltum accommodatos; tum saltare instituit. At spectanti Clistheni res displicebat. Deinde, brevi interposita mora, mensam sibi inferri iussit Hippoclides; quae ubi illata est, conscensa mensa primum Laconicos modulos saltavit; deinde alios Atticos; postremo, caput in mensam innixus, cruribus gesticulabatur. Et Clisthenes, quum ad primum et secundum saltum sese continuisset, nunc quoniam se ultra continere non potest, ait: ‘O fili Tisandri, saltando uxorem tu quidem perdidisti.’ At ille inquit, ‘Nil curat Hippoclides.’ Hinc ortum est proverbium.
text.eng: 134.— On the appointed day, Clisthenes, having sacrificed a hundred oxen, received the suitors and all the men of Sicyon with splendid feasts. After dinner was completed, the suitors competed with each other with songs and conversations presented in between. As the drinking continued, Hippoclides ordered the flutist to play dances suitable for dancing; then he began to dance. But the affair displeased Clisthenes as he watched. Then, after a short delay, Hippoclides ordered a table to be brought in; when it was brought in, he mounted the table and first danced Spartan figures; then others of Attica; finally, leaning his head on the table, he gestured with his legs. Clisthenes, while restraining himself during the first and second dances, now since he could no longer restrain himself, said: ‘O son of Tisander, by dancing you indeed lost a wife.’ But he said, 'Hippoclides does not care.' Hence the saying originated.
The fortunate suitor.
text.lat: Felix procus.

135.— Tum Clisthenes, facto silentio, haec dixit: ‘Viri, filiae proci meae! Ego cunctos vos laudo, et omnibus, si fieri posset, placere vellem. At quoniam fieri non potest, ut, quum de una virgine deliberem, omnium votis simul satisfaciam; iis e vestro numero, quibus uxor non datur, talentum argenti do unicuique, quod et dignati estis meam filiam in matrimonium petere, et domibus vestris peregre abfuistis; Megacli vero, Alcmaeonis filio, meam filiam Agaristen despondeo ex Atheniensium legibus.’ Quumque Megacles dixisset, ‘Accipio conditionem,’ ratum matrimonium Clisthenes habuit. Ita Alcmaeonidae per universam Graeciam laudem maximam habuerunt.
text.eng: 135.— Then Clisthenes, having silenced the room, said: 'Men, suitors of my daughter! I praise all of you, and if it were possible, I would wish to please all. But since it cannot be done, that while deliberating on one maiden, I satisfy the wishes of all; to those among your number whom a wife is not given, I give a talent of silver to each, because you have deemed my daughter worthy to seek in marriage, and have stayed away from your homes abroad; but to Megacles, son of Alcmaeon, I betroth my daughter Agariste according to the laws of the Athenians.' And when Megacles said, 'I accept the condition,' Clisthenes confirmed the marriage. Thus the Alcmaeonidae received the greatest praise throughout all of Greece.
I.— SOME BARBAROUS CUSTOMS.
text.lat: I.— QUAEDAM BARBARAE CONSERVATIONES.

136.— Certior factus sum esse in Asia gentes, quae talibus institutis utantur. Quem primum ex hostibus occidit vir, eius sanguinem potat. Quotquot in proelio interfecit, horum capita ad regem perfert: allato enim capite, fit praedae particeps: non allato, partem nullam capit. Dicunt autem caput pelle nudari hoc modo: cutem in orbem circumcidere solent circa aures: dein excutere de capite: tum, postquam carnem deterserunt, subigere pellem manibus: atque ita mollita uti tanquam mantili, et ex freno equi, ubi venantur, suspendere. Nam qui plurima mantilia ex hostium pellibus habet, is fortissimus censetur. Narrant etiam multos excoriare totos homines, et super ligno extentos equis circumducere.
text.eng: 136.— I have been informed that in Asia there are tribes that follow such customs. The man who first kills an enemy drinks his blood. Whosoever he kills in battle, he brings their heads to the king: for by bringing the head, he becomes a sharer in the spoils: if he does not, he takes no share. They say moreover that they strip the skin from the head in this manner: they are accustomed to cut the skin in a circle around the ears: then strip it from the head: then, after they have scraped the flesh, they soften the skin with their hands: and thus softened, they use it as a napkin, and suspend it from the horse's bridle, where they ride. For he who has most napkins from enemies’ skins is deemed the bravest. They also say many skin whole men, and having stretched them on wood, lead them around on horses.
Cannibals and other curious people.
text.lat: Cannibales et alii curiosi homines.

137.— Narrant autem habitari montes in Scythica terra ab hominibus capripedibus: tum ultra hos vivere alios homines, qui per sex menses dormiant. Issedonas autem huiusmodi uti institutis narrant. Quando cuipiam pater mortuus est, propinqui cuncti adducentes pecudes ad eum conveniunt. Quibus mactatis et in frusta concisis, mortuum etiam patrem hominis in frusta concidunt, mixtisque cunctis carnibus epulas exhibent. Dicunt etiam caput depilatum expurgatumque inaurare, eoque pro sacro vase uti, quum magna sacrificia peragant. Issedones autem narrant esse homines unoculos, et gryphas, qui auri thesauros custodiant in montibus.
text.eng: 137.— They say that mountains in Scythian land are inhabited by men with goat feet: then beyond these live other men who sleep for six months. They report the Issedones follow such customs. When one’s father has died, all the relatives gather with their cattle. After killing and cutting them into pieces, they also cut the dead father of the man into pieces, and with all the flesh mixed together, they hold a feast. They also say the scalp, cleaned and gilded, is used as a sacred vessel when they conduct great sacrifices. The Issedones also say there are one-eyed men, and griffins, who guard gold treasures in the mountains.
II.— THE SIEGE OF BARCA.
text.lat: II.— OBSESSIO BARCAE

text.eng: Mines and countermines.
text.lat: Metalla et contraria metalla.

138.— Narrant Persas obsidione cinxisse urbem Barcam, postulantes ut viri nonnulli traderentur, qui facinus aliquod fecissent: sed conditionem non accepisse oppidanos, quorum universa multitudo particeps caedis esset. Itaque Barcam oppugnarunt novem continuos menses, cuniculis actis, ut in urbem intrarent, et in murum saepius facto impetu. Sed cuniculos indagavit faber aerarius aeneo scuto. Circumtulit enim scutum intra murum, et pavimento urbis admovit. Iam alia loca, ubi illud admovebat, surda erant; qua parte vero erant cuniculi, ibi sonum edebat aes scuti. Itaque ibidem ex adverso cuniculum agentes oppidani Persas interficiebant terram fodientes.
text.eng: 138.— They say that the Persians surrounded the city of Barca with a siege, demanding that some men be handed over, who had committed some crime: but the townspeople did not accept the condition, since the entire population was complicit in the murder. Therefore, they attacked Barca for nine continuous months, by digging tunnels to enter the city, and frequently assaulting the walls. But a brass craftsman detected the tunnels with a bronze shield. For he moved the shield around inside the wall, and placed it on the city's pavement. Now other places, where he placed it, were silent; but where the tunnels were, there the bronze of the shield made a sound. Therefore, there in opposition, the townspeople dug counter tunnels, killing the Persians digging in the earth.

text.lat: Equivocation.
text.eng: Equivocation.

text.lat: 139.— His rebus quum multum tereretur temporis, multique utrinque caderent, dux Persarum hoc consilium capit. Intelligens vi capi Barcam non posse, haec facere instituit. Noctu latam fodit fossam, cui ligna parum valida instravit, superque ligna humum ingessit, ita ut superficies reliquae terrae aequalis esset. Die orto, Barcaeos ad colloquium invitavit. Ad extremum, super occulta fossa sacrificantes, duces utrinque dixerunt: ‘Dum illa terra firma maneret, mansurum esse iusiurandum: Barcaeos promittere se pecuniam regi soluturos: Persas nihil novi in Barcaeos facturos.’
text.eng: 139.— As much time was being wasted and many on both sides were falling, the leader of the Persians adopted this plan. Realizing that Barca could not be taken by force, he decided to do the following. At night he dug a wide ditch, laid weak wood in it, and covered the wood with earth, so that the surface was level with the surrounding ground. At dawn, he invited the Barcans to a meeting. At the end, sacrificing over the hidden ditch, leaders on both sides said: 'As long as that ground remained firm, the oath would remain valid: the Barcans promised to pay money to the king: the Persians would do nothing new to the Barcans.'
Treachery.
text.lat: Proditio.

140.— Icto foedere, Barcaei ipsi egrediebantur urbe, et hostibus, ut intra murum ingrederentur, permittebant; at Persae, disrupto occulto ponte, in urbem irruebant. Persae autem hac caussa pontem, quem fecerant, ruperunt, ut starent iureiurando, quod fecerant cum Barcaeis, ‘tamdiu ratum fore foedus, quamdiu terra maneret firma.’ Rupto autem ponte, non amplius ratum foedus manebat.
text.eng: 140.— With the treaty concluded, the Barcans themselves were leaving the city and allowed the enemies to enter within the walls; but the Persians, breaking the hidden bridge, rushed into the city. The Persians broke the bridge in order to uphold the oath they made with the Barcans, 'as long as the earth remained firm, the treaty would remain valid.' But once the bridge was broken, the treaty no longer held.
III.— ANECDOTES.
text.lat: III.— ANECDOTAE.

text.eng: A neat compliment.
text.lat: Complimentum elegans.

141.— Darius exercitui praefecit Megabazum, virum Persam: quem magnopere honoraverat, hoc in eum verbo coram Persis dicto. Mala punica comedere cupiverat Darius: qui postquam primum aperuit malum, quaesivit ex eo frater Artabanus, ‘quidnam esset, cuius tantum sibi numerum esse cuperet, quantus numerus granorum in malo esset?’ Cui Darius respondit: ‘Velle se tot Megabazos habere; hoc enim malle, quam Graeciam suae potestati subiectam.’
text.eng: 141.— Darius appointed Megabazus, a Persian man, over the army: whom he had greatly honored, by saying this in front of the Persians. Darius had wished to eat pomegranates: after he had opened the first pomegranate, his brother Artabanus asked him, ‘What is it that he wished to have as many of, as there are seeds in the pomegranate?’ To which Darius replied: ‘He wished to have as many Megabazuses; for he preferred this over having Greece subject to his power.’
The gold trade.
text.lat: Auraria commercia.

142.— Narrant Carthaginienses esse locum Libyae extra Herculeas columnas, hominesque ibi habitantes: quos quando ipsi mercandi caussa adeant, expositas e navi merces in ipso maris litore a se disponi: tunc se, conscensis rursus navibus, excitare fumum. Indigenas, conspecto fumo, accedere ad mare, et deposito pro mercibus auro rursus procul a litore discedere. Tum Carthaginienses navibus egressos, rem inspicere; et si satis magnam auri copiam repererint, ablato auro abire: sin minus, redire in naves, donec satis auri repertum sit.
text.eng: 142.— The Carthaginians tell of a place in Libya beyond the pillars of Hercules, where people inhabit: to whom, when they themselves go for the sake of trading, they arrange the goods from their ship on the very shore of the sea: then they, having boarded their ships again, raise a smoke. The natives, seeing the smoke, approach the sea and leave gold for the goods, then withdraw far from the shore. Then the Carthaginians disembark from the ships, inspect the matter; and if they find a sufficient amount of gold, they take the gold and leave: if not, they return to the ships, until a sufficient amount of gold is found.
An odd remedy for a cold.
text.lat: Remedium peregrinum frigoris.

143.— Narrant Nomadas Libyae hoc facere. Quum pueri quartum annum compleverunt, tunc illis venas in vertice capitis lana ovium urunt, nonnulli etiam venas temporum. Idque hac caussa faciunt, ne insequente tempore unquam morbo ullo capitis afficiantur. Hanc ob caussam aiunt optima se frui valetudine. Revera enim Libyes prae omnibus hominibus, quos novimus, firmissima utuntur valetudine. Num hac de caussa hoc fiat, equidem pro certo non dico: sunt autem utique fortissimi. Refero autem quae ab ipsis Afris narrantur.
text.eng: 143.— The Nomads of Libya are said to do this. When boys have completed their fourth year, then they burn the veins on the top of their head with sheep's wool, and some also the veins of the temples. And they do this for this reason, so that they may never be afflicted with any disease of the head in the future. For this reason they say they enjoy the best health. In reality, indeed, the Libyans use the strongest health of all people known to us. Whether this comes about as a result of this, I do not say with certainty: but they are certainly the strongest. I report, however, what is told by the Africans themselves.
IV.—  THE FIRST INVASION OF EUROPE.
text.lat: IV.— PRIMA INVASIO EUROPAE.

text.eng: Darius invades Scythia.
text.lat: Darius Scythiam invadit.

144.— Darius Persarum rex bellum Scythis intulit. Istrum igitur flumen ponte iunxit, pontemque Graecis Ionibus custodiendum tradidit. Tum in Scythas cum omnibus copiis profectus est. Scythae autem aciem committere nolebant. Ita quum tempus extraheretur, neque finis ullus appareret, Darius, misso equite ad Scytharum regem, interrogavit, ‘Cur semper fugeret?’ Dixit etiam, ‘debere eum aut pugnam committere, aut terram et aquam ferentem, in colloquium venire.’
text.eng: 144.— Darius, king of the Persians, made war on the Scythians. Therefore, he joined the river Ister with a bridge, and handed it over to the Ionic Greeks for guarding. Then he set out against the Scythians with all his forces. However, the Scythians were not willing to join battle. Thus, when time was being wasted, and no end appeared, Darius, sending a horseman to the king of the Scythians, asked, 'Why do you always flee?' He also said, 'you should either engage in battle or come to talks bringing earth and water.'
The message and gifts of the Scythian king.
text.lat: Nuntius et dona regis Scytharum.

145.— Ad haec Scytharum rex haec respondit: ‘Nolle se pugnare, qui nec oppida nec culta arva haberent, quae defendere deberent. Pro autem terra et aqua, quas postulasset, dona alia missurum. In malam crucem proinde abiret.’ Illud igitur responsum praeco ad Darium retulit. Tandem Scythae praeconem miserunt, qui dona ferebat, avem et murem et ranam et quinque sagittas. Haec dona afferentem interrogarunt Persae, quaenam esset mens mittentium. Respondit praeco: ‘Nihil aliud sibi mandatum esse, nisi ut his datis quam primum abiret; ipsos autem Persas, si sapientes essent, posse cognoscere, quidnam ista dona significarent.’
text.eng: 145.— To this, the king of the Scythians replied: 'We do not wish to fight, who have neither towns nor cultivated fields, which they must defend. But in place of earth and water, which he asked, he will send other gifts. Go to a bad cross.' Therefore, the herald brought back this answer to Darius. Finally, the Scythians sent a herald who carried gifts, a bird, a mouse, a frog, and five arrows. The Persians asked him what these gifts meant. The herald replied: 'Nothing else was instructed to me, except that having given these, he should leave soonest; but the Persians themselves, if wise, could understand what those gifts meant.'
Interpretations of the meaning of the gifts.
text.lat: Interpretationes donorum significatus.

146.— Darius quidem putabat, ‘Scythas sese et terram et aquam tradere: quod mus in terra viveret, rana in aquis, avis autem similis esset equo: denique tela tradere, tanquam suam fortitudinem.’ Gobrias autem, unus e septemviris qui Magos oppresserant, putabat dona haec significare: ‘Nisi aves facti Persae evolarent, aut in mures conversi terram subirent, aut ut ranae in paludes insilirent, sagittis interfectum iri.’
text.eng: 146.— Darius indeed thought, 'The Scythians surrender themselves, and the earth and water: because the mouse lives in the earth, the frog in the waters, and the bird is like a horse: likewise they surrender arms, as if their strength.' But Gobrias, one of the seven men who had overcome the Magi, thought these gifts meant: 'Unless the Persians became birds and flew away, or turned into mice and went underground, or as frogs leaped into swamps, they would be killed by arrows.'
The Scythian tactics.
text.lat: Scytharum artes bellandi.

147.— Scythae vero, audito servitutis nomine, iram non tenuere. Nuntios miserunt ad Istrum, quibus imperaverunt ut in colloquium venirent Ionibus, qui pontem custodirent. Constituerunt autem de improviso impetum in Persas facere, quum cibum caperent. Equitatus quidem semper in fugam vertebat equitatum Persarum: tum recedebant Scythae, peditatum metuentes. Similes vero impetus noctu Scythae faciebant.
text.eng: 147.— The Scythians, having heard the name of servitude, could not contain their anger. They sent messengers to the Ister, instructing them to come to a meeting with the Ionians who were guarding the bridge. They decided to make an unexpected attack on the Persians while they were taking food. The cavalry always put to flight the cavalry of the Persians: then the Scythians retreated, fearing the infantry. Similar attacks were also made by the Scythians by night.
The allies of the Persians.
text.lat: Socios Persarum.

148.— Erat tunc Persis utilis, Scythis vero iniqua, res dictu admodum mira: nempe vox asinorum, et mulorum species. Etenim nec asinum nec mulum fert Scythica terra. Itaque vox asinorum et mulorum species territabat Scytharum equitatum. Constat autem, quum in Persas impetum facerent, equos audientes asinorum vocem, et mulos videntes, saepe in fugam sese recepisse.
text.eng: 148.— It was then useful for the Persians, but unfavorable for the Scythians, indeed a remarkable thing: namely, the voice of donkeys and the appearance of mules. For neither donkey nor mule is found in Scythian land. Therefore, the voice of donkeys and the appearance of mules terrified the Scythian cavalry. It is known, however, that when they made an attack on the Persians, the horses, upon hearing the voice of the donkeys and seeing the mules, often took flight.
The Scythians tamper with the Ionian Greeks.
text.lat: Scythae cum Graecis Ionibus congrediuntur.

149.— Dum haec geruntur, nuntii Scytharum ad Istrum perveniunt, et custodibus pontis ita dixerunt: ‘Venire se, ut libertatem illis pollicerentur, si pontem relinquere vellent. Solverent pontem et domum abirent. Ita interfectum iri Persas, libertatem autem Ionibus datum iri.’ Haec quum se facturos Iones polliciti essent, Scythae abierunt: rebantur enim Iones promissa servaturos esse.
text.eng: 149.— While these things were happening, the messengers of the Scythians came to the Ister and spoke thus to the guardians of the bridge: 'We come to promise you freedom if you are willing to leave the bridge. Free the bridge and go home. Thus, the Persians will be killed, and freedom will be given to the Ionians.' When the Ionians promised that they would do this, the Scythians left: for they believed that the Ionians would keep their promises.
The retreat of the Persians.
text.lat: Retrocessus Persarum.

150.— Interim Darius constituit ad pontem cum exercitu proficisci: videbat enim Scythas invictos esse. At, quum maior pars Persici exercitus pedestris esset, Scythicus autem exercitus esset equester, Scythae multo prius quam Persae ad pontem pervenerunt. Itaque Ionibus, qui in navibus erant, haec dixere: ‘Nunc quidem solvite pontem, et ocius abite, recuperata libertate. Fugientes Persas exercitus noster sequitur.’
text.eng: 150.— Meanwhile, Darius decided to march to the bridge with the army: for he saw the Scythians were invincible. But, as the larger part of the Persian army was on foot, while the Scythian army was cavalry, the Scythians reached the bridge much earlier than the Persians. Therefore, they said to the Ionians who were in the ships: ‘Now indeed, break the bridge, and go away quickly, having regained your freedom. Our army follows the fleeing Persians.’
Deliberations of the Ionians.
text.lat: Deliberationes Ionum.

151.— Itaque de his deliberarunt Iones. Et Miltiadis quidem Atheniensis, haec erat sententia: ‘Parerent Scythis, et Ioniam liberarent.’ Contra vero suadebat Histiaeus Milesius ut manerent. Huius vicit sententia. Itaque pontis parte, quae Scytharum ripam spectabat, ad teli iactum soluta, ut aliquid facere viderentur, et ne Scythae tentarent vim afferre, ita Histiaeus Scythas allocutus est: ‘Viri Scythae, faciemus quae vultis. Pons solutus est. Nunc Persas interficere potestis.’ Tum Scythae decepti reversi sunt, ut Persas adorirentur.
text.eng: 151.— So the Ionians deliberated on these things. And Miltiades the Athenian, indeed, had this opinion: 'To obey the Scythians, and to liberate Ionia.' But against this, Histiaeus the Milesian advised to stay. His opinion won. Therefore, the part of the bridge, which looked toward the Scythian bank, was loosened to the range of a missile, as they seemed to do something, and in order that the Scythians might not attempt to bring violence, thus Histiaeus addressed the Scythians: ‘Men of Scythia, we will do as you wish. The bridge is loosened. Now you can kill the Persians.’ Then the Scythians, deceived, returned to attack the Persians.
Darius and his army escape.
text.lat: Darius et exercitus eius effugium.

152.— Interim advenit Persicus exercitus; sed quum pontem solutum vidissent, magnopere timebant ne ab Ionibus desererentur. Erat tunc apud Darium vir Aegyptius, omnium hominum maxima voce praeditus. Hunc Darius iussit, in ripa stantem, vocare Histiaeum Milesium. Quod ubi fecit, Histiaeus statim, navibus omnibus ad traiiciendum exercitum paratis, pontem iunxit. Ita Persae e Scytharum manibus effugerunt.
text.eng: 152.— Meanwhile, the Persian army arrived; but when they saw the bridge loosened, they greatly feared that they might be deserted by the Ionians. Then there was with Darius an Egyptian man, possessed of the loudest voice of all men. Darius ordered him, standing on the bank, to call Histiaeus the Milesian. When he did this, Histiaeus immediately, with all the ships prepared for crossing the army, joined the bridge. Thus the Persians escaped from the hands of the Scythians.
V.— A HAIRBREADTH ESCAPE.
text.lat: V.— PERICULUM EFFUGIS.

153.— Olim Sandoces quidam urbi Cymae praefectus erat. Hunc Darius rex, quum invenisset, eum, quum iudex fuisset, accepta pecunia iniustam sententiam pronuntiasse, in crucem agi iussit. Et iam suspensus erat; quum Darius, rationem secum iniens rerum ab illo gestarum, reperit multo plura esse eius merita in regiam domum quam malefacta. Quod postquam reperit, agnoscens properantius a se quam sapientius actum esse, solvi hominem iussit. Ita supplicium a Dario decretum effugit, superstesque fuit.
text.eng: 153.— Once upon a time, Sandoces was governor of the city Cyme. When King Darius found that he had given an unjust judgment after receiving money when he was a judge, he ordered him to be crucified. And he was already suspended; when Darius, considering the deeds done by him, found that his merits to the royal house were much greater than his crimes. After discovering this, acknowledging that he had acted more hastily than wisely, he ordered the man's release. Thus he escaped the punishment decreed by Darius and survived.
VI.— OROETES AND POLYCRATES.
text.lat: VI.— OROETES ET POLYCRATES.

text.eng: The cause of Oroetes’ jealousy of Polycrates.
text.lat: Causa invidiae Oroetis in Polycratem.

154.— Oroetes Persa, Sardium praeses constitutus a Cyro, facinus animo agitavit nefarium: etenim Polycratem Samium, a quo nec facto ullo nec dicto quoquam iniurioso fuerat laesus, quemque non viderat unquam antea, capere et interficere cupivit: idque, ut plerique tradunt, talem ob caussam. Ad regis portam quum sedisset hic Oroetes, et alius Persa, cui nomen Mitrobati fuit, hi ambo in verborum contentionem dicuntur incidisse. Narrant autem Mitrobaten, quum de virtute inter se disceptarent, Oroetae haec dixisse: ‘Tune vir es, qui Samum insulam tuae praefecturae proximam, in Regis potestatem non redegisti? quum sit subactu ita facilis ut indigenarum aliquis, cum quindecim armatis insurgens, ea potitus sit atque etiam nunc in ea dominetur!’ Dicunt igitur, Oroeten his auditis, aegre ferentem exprobrationem, cupivisse non tam vindictam capere de eo qui haec sibi dixisset, quam omnino Polycratem perdere, propter quem male exprobratus esset.
text.eng: 154.— Oroetes the Persian, appointed governor of Sardis by Cyrus, conceived a wicked crime: indeed, he desired to seize and kill Polycrates the Samian, by whom he had neither been injured in deed nor word, whom he had never seen before: and, as most relate, for this reason. When Oroetes was sitting at the king's gate, and another Persian named Mitrobates was there, they are said to have engaged in a verbal dispute. They say that Mitrobates, when they were arguing about valor, said this to Oroetes: 'Are you a man, who did not bring the island of Samos, so near to your prefecture, under the power of the King? when it is so easy to subdue that some native, with fifteen armed men, seized it and even now rules over it!' Therefore, they say, Oroetes, offended by this reproach, wished not so much to take revenge on him who had said this to him, as to destroy Polycrates wholly, because of whom he was reproached badly.
Another account.
text.lat: Aliud narratur.

155.— Sunt pauciores nonnulli qui tradunt, misisse Oroeten praeconem Samum, nescio quid petiturum: (nec enim hoc memoriae proditur:) Polycratem autem tunc in exedra forte decubuisse, et affuisse ei Anacreontem Teium; atque quum accedens Oroetae praeco verba fecisset, Polycratem ad murum tunc forte conversum, nec aspexisse hominem paullisper nee responsum dedisse. Sic caussa mortis Polycratis duplici modo traditur.
text.eng: 155.— There are some fewer who tell that Oroetes sent a herald to Samos, to demand something unknown: (for this is not recorded in memory:) but Polycrates happened to be reclining in a colonnade then, and Anacreon of Teos was with him; and when the herald of Oroetes approached and spoke, Polycrates happened to have turned towards the wall, neither looking at the man for a while nor giving him an answer. Thus the cause of Polycrates' death is related in two ways.
The machinations of Oroetes.
text.lat: Insidiae Oroetis.

156.— Oroetes vero, qui Magnesiae habitabat, Lydum quendam misit nuntium ferentem quo Polycratis animum exploraret. Polycrates autem magnam spem habebat fore ut Ioniae et insularum imperio potiretur. Oroetes, intelligens hoc eum animo agitare, misso nuntio, haec dixit: ‘Oroetes Polycrati salutem dicit. Intellexi te magnas res moliri; parum autem pecuniae tibi esse. Nunc tu, si hocce feceris, et tuas res augebis, et me quoque servabis. Mortem mihi meditatur Cambyses. Tu ergo et me ipsum ex hac terra educas, et pecunias meas exportes. Harum quidem partem tu tene, partem me tenere patere: harum ope Graeciae imperio potieris. Quod si fidem mihi non habueris, mitte civem, quemcunque fidelissimum habes, cui ego pecunias monstrabo.’
text.eng: 156.— Oroetes, who lived in Magnesia, sent a certain Lydian messenger to test Polycrates' mind. Polycrates, however, entertained great hopes of acquiring dominion over Ionia and the islands. Oroetes, understanding this ambition in him, sent a messenger, saying: 'Oroetes sends greetings to Polycrates. I understand you are planning great things; but you have little money. Now, if you do this, you will increase your resources and also save me. Cambyses is planning my death. Therefore, you bring me out of this land and take my money away. Allow yourself to hold part of these riches, and allow me to hold part: with the help of these, you will gain dominion over Greece. But if you do not trust me, send whatever most trustworthy citizen you have, to whom I will show the money.'
He deceives the messenger of Polycrates.
text.lat: Ipsum Polycratis nuntium decipit.

157.— His auditis gavisus Polycrates, accepit conditionem. Primum igitur misit speculandi caussa Maeandrium, qui scriba eius erat. Oroetes postquam cognovit exspectari speculatorem, hoc fecit. Cistas octo lapidibus complevit, brevi spatio excepto circa oras, super lapides vero aurum coniecit: tum obsignatas cistas in parato habuit. Et Maeandrius, ubi advenit spectavitque, renuntiavit Polycrati. Ita omnino deceptum esse Polycratem narrant.
text.eng: 157.— Polycrates, delighted by this news, accepted the condition. Therefore, he first sent Maeandrius, who was his secretary, for the purpose of spying. Oroetes, once he knew a spy was expected, did this. He filled eight chests with stones, leaving a small space empty around the edges, and poured gold on top of the stones: then he had the sealed chests ready. And when Maeandrius arrived and observed, he reported back to Polycrates. Thus they say Polycrates was completely deceived.
The dreams of Polycrates’ daughter.
text.lat: Somnia filiae Polycratis.

158.— Tum ille, quamvis vates dissuaderent ei, ipse eo proficisci paravit. Ad haec filia eius dormiens tale viderat insomnium. Visus ei erat pater in aere sublimis esse, et lavari a Iove, inungi vero sole. Hoc quum ei oblatum esset visum, vehementer contendebat, ne ad Oroeten pater proficisceretur; atque etiam, dum ille actuariam navem conscendebat, illum ominosis verbis prosecuta est. Tum ille minatus est: ‘quando salvus rediisset, multos annos illam sine marito mansuram:’ et illa precata est, ‘ut rata haec fierent: malle se enim sine marito esse, quam patre privari.’
text.eng: 158.— Then he, although seers dissuaded him, prepared to go himself. Meanwhile his daughter, while sleeping, had seen such a dream. Her father seemed to be high in the air, and to be washed by Zeus, but anointed by the sun. When this vision was presented to her, she earnestly contended that her father should not set out to Oroetes; and moreover, as he was boarding the ship with quickness, she accompanied him with ominous words. Then he threatened: 'when he returned safely, she would remain without a husband for many years:' and she prayed 'that these things would happen: for she preferred to be without a husband than without a father.'
The murder of Polycrates.
text.lat: Caedes Polycratis.

159.— Itaque Polycrates, spreto omni consilio, ad Oroeten navigavit, quum alios multos comites secum ducens, tum Democedem medicum praeclarum. Quum vero Magnesiam Polycrates pervenisset, misere periit, supplicio nec regia potestate digno, nec ingenio: nam exceptis Syracusanorum tyrannis, ne unus quidem ex aliis tyrannis Graecis dignus est qui magnificentia cum Polycrate comparetur.
text.eng: 159.— Therefore, Polycrates, dismissing all advice, sailed to Oroetes, taking with him many other companions, including the renowned doctor Democedes. When Polycrates reached Magnesia, he miserably perished, by a punishment neither worthy of his royal power nor of his talent: for except for the tyrants of Syracuse, not even one of the other Greek tyrants is worthy to be compared with Polycrates in magnificence.
The fulfilment of fate.
text.lat: Fati impletio.

160.— Turpi modo et narratu indigno occisum, cruci eum Oroetes affixit: quicunque vero ex comitibus Samii erant, hos dimisit, gratiam sibi habere iubens quod libertatem servarent; quotquot autem peregrini aut servi erant, hos vinctos mancipiorum loco habuit. Sic Polycrates ex cruce suspensus universum filiae somnium explevit: lavabatur enim a Iove, quando pluebat: et inungebatur sole, humorem ipse e corpore emittens. Itaque suprema Polycratis felicitas hunc habuit finem, quemadmodum ei Amasis Aegypti rex ominatus erat. Oroetes autem haud multo post a Dario, rege Persarum, capitis condemnatus est. Tali igitur modo Oroeten persecutae sunt dirae Polycratis Samii ultrices.
text.eng: 160.— Killed in a vile manner and in a tale undeserved, Oroetes nailed him to the cross: whoever of the Samian companions were there, he released, ordering them to be grateful as they kept their freedom; but all foreigners or slaves he kept bound as captives. Thus, hanging from the cross, Polycrates fulfilled entirely the dream of his daughter: for he was washed by Zeus when it rained, and anointed by the sun, emitting moisture from his body. Thus the supreme happiness of Polycrates ended as king Amasis of Egypt had foreshadowed. Oroetes, however, not much later, was condemned by Darius, king of the Persians, to death. Thus, the dire avengers of Polycrates the Samian pursued Oroetes.
VII.— DARIUS AND DEMOCEDES.
text.lat: VII.— DARIUS ET DEMOCEDES.

text.eng: Darius meets with an accident.
text.lat: Darius casum subit.

161.— Quum Oroetae res familiaris Susa esset transportata, accidit ut Dario regi, inter venandum ex equo desilienti, pes distorqueretur. Et graviori quodam modo distortus est, nam astragalus ex articulis exierat. Itaque medicis Aegyptiis, quos praestantissimos in arte medicorum putabat, usus est. At illi, torquentes pedem vimque magnam afferentes, malum auxerunt.
text.eng: 161.— When Oroetes' property had been transported to Susa, it happened that King Darius, while dismounting from his horse during the hunt, twisted his foot. It was twisted in a rather severe manner, for the ankle bone had dislocated from the joints. Therefore, he used Egyptian doctors, whom he considered to be very skilled in the art of medicine. But they, twisting the foot and applying great force, increased the injury.
The captive surgeon.
text.lat: Chirurgus captivus.

162.— Quum igitur totos septem dies septemque noctes insomnes egisset; octavo die graviter laboranti Dario nuntiat quispiam, se olim Sardibus Democedis artem forte audivisse laudari: rexque imperavit, ut ad se quam primum adduceretur. Qui ubi inter Oroetae mancipia repertus est, producitur in medium, compedes trahens, et laceros pannos indutus.
text.eng: 162.— Therefore, when he had spent seven whole days and nights without sleep, on the eighth day someone announced to the suffering Darius that he had once heard Democedes' skill praised at Sardis: and the king ordered that he be brought to him as soon as possible. When he was found among the slaves of Oroetes, he was brought forward, dragging chains and clothed in tattered rags.
He cures the king.
text.lat: Rex curatur.

163.— In medio stantem interrogavit rex num arte medica calleret; at ille negavit, veritus ne, si cognosceretur, nulla spes reliqua foret in Graeciam redeundi. Darius vero intelligens dissimulare hominem, et gnarum esse artis, flagella et stimulos in medium proferri iussit. Tum ille professus ait, accurate quidem se artem non doctum esse, sed aliquantulam eius notitiam habere ex amicitia quam cum medico quodam habuisset.
