Deinde, quum rex se illi permisisset, Graecis adhibitis medicamentis et lenibus post vehementiora admotis, effecit ut et somnum caperet rex, et brevi tempore sanum incolumemque praestitit, quum nunquam rectum pedis usum se recepturum sperasset.
text.eng: 163.— Standing in the middle, the king asked if he was skilled in the medical art; but he denied it, fearing that if his knowledge were revealed, there would be no hope left of returning to Greece. Darius, however, understanding that the man was feigning, and knowing the art, commanded whips and goads to be brought forth. Then he confessed, stating that he was not precisely trained in the art, but he knew a little through a friendship he had once with a certain doctor. Then, when the king entrusted himself to him, applying Greek remedies and gentle treatments after harsher ones, he caused the king to sleep and shortly made him sound and whole, when he had never hoped to regain the proper use of his foot.
His reward.
text.lat: Praemium eius.

164.— Inde duabus aureis compedibus donatus a Dario Democedes quaerit ex rege, ‘num consulto duplex malum reddat, quod sanum illum praestiterit?’ Quo verbo delectatus Darius, ad uxores suas eum ablegavit; quibus servi, eum producentes, dixerunt, ‘esse hunc qui vitam regi praestitisset.’ Tum earum unaquaeque phiala aurum e cista hauriens, tam largo munere auri Democeden donavit, ut famulus, qui eum sequebatur, cui nomen erat Scitoni, ex stateribus qui in terram deciderant, ingentem auri vim sibi colligeret.
text.eng: 164.— Then, having been presented with two golden chains by Darius, Democedes asked the king, ‘Do you provide a double punishment for making him healthy?’ Pleased with the word, Darius sent him to his wives; and the servants, bringing him forward, said, ‘This is he who restored the king's life.’ Then each of them, taking gold from a casket with a bowl, gave Democedes such a generous gift of gold that the servant who followed him, whose name was Scitoni, gathered a huge amount of gold from the coins that had fallen to the ground.
VIII.— A THRACIAN SUTTEE.
text.lat: VIII.— SUTTI THRACICA.

165.— Apud Thracas hic mos instituitur. Uxores quisque vir plures habet. Mortuo autem viro, magna fit inter uxores disceptatio, quaenam ex uxoribus carissima fuerit marito. Deinde, quae talis esse iudicata est, illa, a viris et mulieribus collaudata, iugulatur super tumulo ab propinquis: tum una cum marito sepelitur Reliquae vero magnae sibi calamitati id esse arbitrantur.
text.eng: 165.— Among the Thracians, this custom is established. Each man has several wives. When a man dies, a great dispute arises among the wives as to which of them was most beloved by the husband. Then, the one judged to be so, praised by the men and women, is sacrificed over the grave by the relatives: then she is buried with the husband. The others think it a great calamity for themselves.
IX.— A LAKE VILLAGE.
text.lat: IX.— LACUSTRIS PAGUS.

166.— Lacum Prasiadem gens incolit tali modo. Stant in medio lacu tabulata, altis palis instrata, quae angustum habent ex continente aditum. Unusquisque vir super tabulatis illis tugurium habet, in quo vitam agit. Parvulos autem pueros puellasque funibus ex pede alligant, veriti ne imprudentes in aquam decidant.
text.eng: 166.— The people inhabit Lake Prasiades in this manner. Platforms stand in the middle of the lake, laid on high piles, which have a narrow entrance from the mainland. Each man has a hut on these platforms, in which he spends his life. However, they tie small boys and girls by the foot with ropes, fearing they may fall into the water unwisely.
X.— A WAY OUT OF A DIFFICULTY.
text.lat: X.— VIA EX DIFFICILITATE

167.— Aristagoras Milesius conatus est persuadere Cleomeni Spartanorum regi ut expeditionem susciperet adversus Persas. Qui quum nesciret quo modo rem detrectaret; quaesivit ex Aristagora, quot dierum esset iter a mari Ionio ad regem? Et Aristagoras, alioquin callidus homo, et eum pulcre decipiens, coactus est respondere, trium mensium esse iter. Tum vero Cleomenes, praecidens reliquum sermonem, quem de itinere illo facturus erat Aristagoras, ait: ‘Hospes Milesie, excede Sparta ante solis occasum: non enim sermonem dicis audiendum Spartanis, qui eos cupias trium mensium viam abducere a mari.’ His dictis Cleomenes domum abiit.
text.eng: 167.— Aristagoras of Miletus tried to persuade Cleomenes, the king of the Spartans, to undertake an expedition against the Persians. Since he did not know how to refuse the matter, he asked Aristagoras how many days' journey it was from the Ionian sea to the king. And Aristagoras, otherwise a cunning man, cleverly deceiving him, was forced to reply that it was a journey of three months. Then indeed Cleomenes, cutting off the rest of the conversation, which Aristagoras was going to make about that journey, said: 'Guest of Miletus, leave Sparta before sunset: for you do not speak the kind of speech that the Spartans should hear, notably because you wish to lead them on a journey of three months away from the sea.' Having said this, Cleomenes went home.
A noble child.
text.lat: Nobilis puer.

168.— Tum vero Aristagoras sumpto oleae ramo domum adiit Cleomenis, et ingressus supplex illum precatus est, ut, dimissa filiola, sese audiret: astabat enim forte Cleomeni filia, cui nomen erat Gorgo, unica illius proles, annorum octo aut novem puella. Iussit illum Cleomenes dicere quae vellet, nec cessare puellae caussa. Ibi Aristagoras decem incepit talenta ei polliceri, si ea, quae petiisset, sibi effecta dedisset: abnuente Cleomene, progressus est augendo subinde pecuniae summam, donec postremo, quum quinquaginta talenta pollicitus esset, exclamavit puella: ‘Pater, corrumpet te hic hospes, nisi ocius hinc abscesseris.’ Tum delectatus Cleomenes puellae monito, abiit, et Aristagoras Sparta omnino excessit, neque ei licuit de itinere ad regem plura commemorare.
text.eng: 168.— Then indeed Aristagoras, having taken a branch of olive, went to the house of Cleomenes, and having entered, humbly prayed him to hear him, dismissing the little daughter: for indeed Cleomenes' daughter was standing nearby, whose name was Gorgo, his only child, a girl of eight or nine years. Cleomenes ordered him to say what he wanted, not ceasing to do so because of the girl. Then Aristagoras began to promise him ten talents, if he granted him what he asked: as Cleomenes refused, he continued to increase the amount of money offered, until finally, having promised fifty talents, the girl exclaimed: 'Father, this guest will corrupt you, unless you leave quickly.' Then, delighted by the girl's warning, Cleomenes departed, and Aristagoras completely left Sparta, nor was he allowed to speak more on the journey to the king.
XI.—THE ADVANTAGES OF A REPUBLIC.
text.lat: XI.—COMMODA RES PUBLICAE.

169.— Athenae diu a tyrranis oppressae erant. His tandem coactis ut exsulatum abirent, auctae sunt Athenarum opes: civitasque florentissima facta est. Apparet autem, non hoc solum exemplo, sed ubique, quam praeclara res sit iuris aequalitas. Nam et Athenienses, quamdiu sub tyrannis erant, nullis ex finitimis populis bello fuerunt superiores; tyrannis autem liberati, longe primi facti sunt. Quae res declarat, quoad a tyrannis essent oppressi, illos minus fortiter rem gessisse, quippe pro domino non pro se: postquam vero in libertatem sunt restituti, unusquisque pro se ipse studiose dabat operam ut recte rem gereret.
text.eng: 169.—Athens had long been oppressed by tyrants. When they were finally compelled to go into exile, the power of Athens increased: the city became very flourishing. It appears, however, not only from this example, but everywhere, how splendid a thing is the equality of rights. For the Athenians, as long as they were under tyrants, were superior to no neighboring peoples in war; but once freed from the tyrants, they became by far the first. This fact shows that, so long as they were oppressed by tyrants, they managed affairs less bravely, indeed for their master, not for themselves: but after they were restored to liberty, each diligently took care for himself to manage affairs rightly.
XII.— THE SHORTEST WAY TO ABSOLUTE POWER.
text.lat: XII.— BREVIS VIA AD ABSOLUTUM IMPERIUM.

170.— Periander, rex Corinthi, initio quidem mitis erat; sed, ex quo per nuntios commercium habuit cum Thrasybulo, Milesiorum tyranno, crudelis et sanguinolentus factus est. Misso ad Thrasybulum praecone, quaesivit ex illo, ‘quo pacto, rebus omnibus firmissime constitutis, optime praeesset civitati?’ Thrasybulus, homine qui a Periandro missus erat extra urbem educto, ingressus est arvum quoddam satum, ambulansque per segetem, sciscitansque ex eo cur ad se Corintho missus esset, detruncabat interim quamque spicam super alias eminentem, donec pulcherrimam et pinguissimam segetis partem tali modo corrupit; denique, postquam agrum ita pervagatus est, dimisit legatum, nullum verbum ei praecipiens. Ubi Corinthum rediit legatus, cupidus erat Periander cognoscendi praecepta Thrasybuli. Respondit legatus: nihil sibi mandasse Thrasybulum. Tum renuntiavit, quid agentem Thrasybulum vidisset. At Periander, intelligens factum, reputansque moneri se a Thrasybulo ut eminentiorem quemque civem interimeret, tum vero omnem adversus cives nequitiam exercere incepit. Mox, interfectis omnibus primoribus, omnia facere, quae vellet, facile potuit.
text.eng: 170.— Periander, king of Corinth, was initially mild; but, after having correspondence with Thrasybulus, tyrant of the Milesians, through messengers, he became cruel and bloodthirsty. Sending a herald to Thrasybulus, he inquired from him 'in what way, with all things firmly established, he might best rule the state?' Thrasybulus, leading the man who had been sent by Periander outside the city, entered a certain sown field and, walking through the crop, while asking him why he had been sent from Corinth, he was cutting down every stalk standing above the rest, until he ruined the finest and fattest part of the crop in such a way; finally, after having wandered through the field in this way, he dismissed the envoy, instructing him with no word. When the envoy returned to Corinth, Periander was eager to learn Thrasybulus's advice. The envoy replied: Thrasybulus had instructed him with nothing. Then he related what he had seen Thrasybulus doing. But Periander, understanding the deed, and considering that he was being advised by Thrasybulus to kill every prominent citizen, then indeed began to exercise all wickedness against the citizens. Soon, with all the chiefs killed, he was able to do everything he wished easily.
XIII.— THE IONIC REVOLT.
text.lat: XIII.— DE IONICA REBELLIONE.

text.eng: The burning of Sardis.
text.lat: Incendium Sardium.

171.— Clones, auctore Aristagora, a Dario defecerunt. Itaque viginti naves Athenienses Miletum advenerunt, quas sequebantur quinque triremes Eretriensium, Ionibus auxilio. Tum Aristagoras expeditionem adversus Sardes suscepit. Urbem capiunt: quominus vero captam diripere possent, haec res fuit impedimento. Erant Sardibus pleraeque domus ex arundine constructae. Harum unam quum incendisset quidam ex militibus, ab illo initio cetera consumens ignis, universam urbem depascebat. Tum Persae, ex arce impetu facto, hostes adorti sunt. Acriter pugnatum est. Iones ingenti clade victi sunt. Constat magnum numerum eorum a Persis interfectum esse.
text.eng: 171.— The Clones, led by Aristagoras, revolted from Darius. Therefore, twenty Athenian ships arrived at Miletus, followed by five triremes of the Eretrians, as aid to the Ionians. Then Aristagoras undertook an expedition against Sardis. They capture the city: however, this was a hindrance to them ransacking the captured city. In Sardis, most houses were built of reed. When one of the soldiers set one of these on fire, the igniting flame spread, consuming the entire city. Then the Persians, making an assault from the citadel, attacked the enemies. A fierce battle was fought. The Ionians were defeated with great slaughter. It is said a large number of them were killed by the Persians.
The anger of Darius against the Athenians.
text.lat: Ira Darai contra Athenienses.

172.— Interim Dario nuntiatur, Sardes incensas ab Atheniensibus Ionibusque, illiusque tumultus auctorem, cuius auxilio haec suscepta sint, Aristagoram esse Milesium. Quo accepto nuntio, nulla ratione habita Ionum, quos noverat poenam certam daturos, dicitur rex quaesivisse, ‘quinam essent Athenienses?’ deinde, quum audivisset, poposcisse arcum, et sagittam arcui impositam emisisse in caelum, exclamans, ‘Proh Iupiter, contingat mihi poenas sumere ab Atheniensibus!’ His dictis mandavit uni e ministris, ut quoties coena ipsi apponeretur, ter diceret, ‘Domine, memento Atheniensium!’
text.eng: 172.— Meanwhile, it was reported to Darius that Sardis had been burned by the Athenians and Ionians, and that the author of that disturbance, by whose assistance this was undertaken, was Aristagoras the Milesian. Upon receiving this message, regarding the Ionians, whom he knew would certainly suffer punishment, he is said to have asked, 'Who are these Athenians?' Then, when he heard, he demanded a bow, placed an arrow on the bow and shot it into the sky, exclaiming, 'By Jupiter, may I be granted revenge on the Athenians!' Having said these words, he instructed one of his servants, whenever dinner was served to him, to say three times, 'Master, remember the Athenians!'
XIV.— THE CAMPAIGN IN CYPRUS.
text.lat: XIV.— EXPEDITIO IN CYPRO.

text.eng: Preparations of the Insurgents.
text.lat: Insurgentium praeparationes.

173.— Interim in Cypro haec gesta sunt. Onesilo duci Cypriorum nuntiatur, Artybium Persam cum classe et ingenti Persarum exercitu affuturum esse in Cyprum. Quo cognito Onesilus Cyprius praeconem dimisit per Ioniam, auxilio Ionas advocans: nec diu re deliberata, affuerunt Iones cum magna classe. Eodem tempore quo Iones advenere, Persae etiam, quum navibus e Cilicia traiecissent, pedestri itinere Salaminem contenderunt: navibus autem Phoenices circumnavigarunt promontorium quae Claves Cypri vocantur.
text.eng: 173.— Meanwhile, in Cyprus these things were done. It is announced to Onesilus, leader of the Cypriots, that Artybius the Persian, with a fleet and a great army of Persians, will arrive in Cyprus. Having learned this, Onesilus, the Cypriot, sent a herald through Ionia, calling the Ionians for aid: and not long after deliberation, the Ionians arrived with a great fleet. At the same time as the Ionians arrived, the Persians also, having crossed from Cilicia by ship, advanced on Salamis by a land route: meanwhile, the Phoenicians sailed around the cape called the Keys of Cyprus.
They hold a council of war.
text.lat: Concilium belli habent.

174.— Quae quum ita essent, Cyprii tyranni convocatos Ionum duces ita allocuti sunt: ‘Vobis, Iones, nos Cyprii permittimus ut eligatis cum utris velitis confligere; cum Persis, an cum Phoenicibus. Quod si pedestri pugna cum Persis vultis congredi, oportet vos, nulla interposita mora, navibus egressos, pedestrem instruere aciem; nos vero, conscensis navibus vestris, Phoenicibus nos opponere. Sin cum Phoenicibus tentare fortunam mavultis; utramcunque partem elegeritis, operam dare necesse est, ut, quantum per vos fieri potest, liberae sint et Ionia et Cyprus.’ Ad haec Iones responderunt: ‘Nos Ionia misit ut mare custodiamus; non ut naves nostras tradentes Cypriis, ipsi cum Persis pedestri acie confligamus. Nos igitur, qua parte locati sumus, in ea utilem praestare operam conabimur: vos autem, memores qualia Persis parentes passi ab illis sitis, fortes viros esse oportet.’ Post haec, quum Persae in Salaminiorum advenissent campum, aciem instruxerunt reges Cypriorum: ita quidem ut ceteros Cyprios hostium ceteris militibus opponerent, Persis autem fortissimos e Salaminiis selectos. Contra Artybium vero, ducem Persarum, lubens stetit Onesilus.
text.eng: 174.— When these things were thus, the tyrants of Cyprus addressed the assembled Ionian leaders thus: 'We Cypriots permit you, Ionians, to choose with whom you wish to fight; with the Persians, or with the Phoenicians. If you wish to engage in a land battle with the Persians, it is necessary for you, without delay, to disembark from your ships and form a line of battle; we will oppose the Phoenicians by boarding your ships. But if you prefer to try your fortune with the Phoenicians, whatever side you choose, you must strive so that both Ionia and Cyprus may be free, as far as it depends on you.' To this, the Ionians replied: 'Ionia sent us to guard the sea; not to hand over our ships to the Cypriots and engage in a land battle with the Persians ourselves. Therefore, we will try to show useful effort in the position we have been placed; you, however, must be brave men, remembering what sort of sufferance you as parents have endured from the Persians.' After these words, when the Persians had arrived on the Salaminian plain, the kings of the Cypriots arranged their battle line: in such a way, indeed, that they positioned the other Cypriots against the rest of the enemy soldiers, and the best selected from the Salaminians against the Persians. Against Artybius, however, the leader of the Persians, Onesilus eagerly stood.
The charger of Artybius.
text.lat: Equus Artybii.

175.— Vehebatur Artybius equo, qui erectus stare adversus armatum militem edoctus erat. Qua re cognita Onesilus, quum esset ei armiger genere Car, arte bellica clarus et animi plenus, dixit huic: ‘Artybii equum audio erectum stare, et pedibus atque ore pugnare contra adversarium. Tu igitur ocius delibera tecum, mihique ede, utrum observare et ferire velis equum, an ipsum Artybium?’ Ad haec famulus respondit: ‘Paratus equidem sum, rex, et utrumque facere, et alterutrum, et omnino quidquid tu iusseris: dicam tamen id quod tuis rebus commodissimum mihi videtur. Regem ducemque aio oportere cum rege et duce congredi: nam si tu virum ducem interfeceris, magnum hoc tibi erit: sive, quod dii prohibeant, te ille; ab digno etiam homine occidi, minor calamitas est. Nos vero famulos aio oportere cum famulis congredi, et cum equo; cuius tu artes ne timueris: ego enim tibi polliceor, adversus nullum hominem porro illum se erecturum.’
text.eng: 175.— Artybius was riding on a horse, which was trained to stand upright against an armed soldier. Having learned of this, Onesilus, whose bodyguard was a Carian by race, famous for his military skill and full of spirit, said to him: ‘I hear that Artybius’s horse stands upright, and fights with its feet and mouth against an opponent. Therefore, quickly consider with yourself, and tell me whether you choose to watch and strike the horse, or Artybius himself?’ To this, the servant replied: ‘I am ready, king, to do both, or either, and generally whatever you order: nevertheless, I will say what seems most advantageous for your interests to me. I say that a king and leader ought to fight with a king and leader: for if you kill this man, the leader, it will be great for you: or, which the gods forbid, he for you; even to be killed by a worthy man is a lesser calamity. But I say that we servants ought to fight with servants, and with the horse; fear not his skills: for I promise you, against no man shall he stand upright henceforth.’
The battle.
text.lat: Pugna.

176.— Haec postquam armiger dixit, mox deinde commissa pugna est, et terra, et mari. Et navibus quidem Iones, acriter illo die pugnantes, superaverunt Phoenices: et inter Ionas, Samiorum prae ceteris virtus eminuit. Pedestres vero ubi congressae sunt copiae, magno impetu invicem irruentes pugnarunt. Ab imperatoribus autem utrinque haec gesta sunt. Ubi Artybius, equo quem dixi vectus, adversus Onesilum impetum fecit, Onesilus, quemadmodum ei cum armigero convenerat, ferit ipsum irruentem Artybium: quumque equus scuto Onesili pedes iniiceret, Car falce feriens pedes praecidit equi. Ita Artybius dux Persarum, una cum equo, ibidem cecidit.
text.eng: 176.— After the bodyguard said these things, then the battle was joined, both on land and at sea. And the Ionians indeed, fighting fiercely on that day, overcame the Phoenicians with their ships: and among the Ionians, the valor of the Samians stood out above the others. The foot soldiers, when they met, fought with great rush back and forth. These things were done by the commanders on both sides. When Artybius, whom I mentioned before, charged against Onesilus, Onesilus, as planned with his bodyguard, struck down Artybius charging towards him: and while the horse tried to strike Onesilus's shield with its feet, the Carian, striking with a sickle, cut off the horse's feet. Thus, Artybius the leader of the Persians, fell there together with his horse.
The insurgents are betrayed and defeated.
text.lat: Insurgentes proditi et victi sunt.

177.— Dum vero ceteri etiam acie pugnant, deserit Cyprios Stenosor, unus e ducibus cum non exigua militum manu, quos secum habebat. Postquam Stenosor deseruit socios, protinus Salaminiorum quoque essedarii idem fecerunt. Quo facto superiores Cypriis Persae evaserunt. Quorum exercitu in fugam verso, occiderunt et alii multi, et ipse Onesilus, qui Cypriis auctor fuerat defectionis. Diu restiterunt socii, sed a Persis circumventi tandem fusi fugatique sunt. Magna praeda, magno captivorum numero potiti sunt Persae.
text.eng: 177.— While others were also fighting in battle, Stenosor, one of the leaders, deserted the Cypriots with no small band of soldiers whom he had with him. After Stenosor deserted his comrades, immediately the chariot-fighters of Salamis also did the same. Thus, the Persians overcame the Cypriots. As their army was put to flight, many others were killed, including Onesilus himself, who had instigated the revolt among the Cypriots. The allies resisted for a long time, but being surrounded by the Persians, they were finally scattered and routed. The Persians obtained great booty and a great number of captives.
A strange portent.
text.lat: Portentum insolitum.

178.— Onesili caput Amathusii, quos ipse obsederat, abscissum Amathunta portarunt, et super oppidi portam suspenderunt. Narrant, postquam cavum caput ita suspensum fuerit, apium examen, in illud sese insinuans, favis replevisse. Quod quum accidisset, oraculum consulentibus Amathusiis, ‘quid facerent?’ datur responsum, ‘auferrent caput humarentque; Onesilo vero, ut heroi, annua sacra facerent. Id si fecissent, melius cum ipsis actum iri.’ Hoc fecerunt Amathusii ad meam usque aetatem.
text.eng: 178.— The head of Onesilus, whom the Amathusians themselves had besieged, was taken to Amathus, and hung over the town gate. They say that, after the hollow head was thus suspended, a swarm of bees, entering into it, filled it with honeycombs. When this happened, the oracular response to the Amathusians, who consulted ‘what should they do?’ was 'to remove and bury the head; and to Onesilus, as a hero, they should perform annual sacrifices. If they did this, things would be better for them.' The Amathusians did this even until my time.
The true author of the revolt.
text.lat: Verus auctor defectionis.

179.— Aristagoras, dum oppidum quoddam obsidet, interficitur. Histiaeus vero Mileti tyrannus, qui seditionis auctor fuerat, a Dario dimissus Susis, Sardes profectus erat. Quo ubi advenit, interrogavit eum Artaphernes, Sardium praeses, ‘quanam re inductos Ionas a rege defecissse putaret.’ Id quum se ignorare diceret, mentiri eum videns Artaphernes ait: ‘Ita tibi, Histiaee, haec res se habet: calceum hunc tu confecisti, quem induit Aristagoras.’ Hoc quum dixisset Artaphernes, veritus Histiaeus ne interficeretur, in fugam se recipit. Tum Miletum adit. At Milesii, lubenter Aristagora liberati, eum recipere nolebant. Itaque quum noctu per vim intrare Miletum conatus esset, repulsus est, atque etiam ab aliquo ex Milesiis in femore vulneratus est. Inde Byzantium navigavit, ibique omnes naves, quae praeteribant, capiebat, exceptis eorum navigiis qui se paratos esse Histiaeo parere profiterentur. Mox captus est ab Artapherne, qui corpus suspendit e cruce, caput autem sale conditum, Susa ad Darium misit. Darius autem caput lotum et bene curatum sepeliri iussit, ut viri de se praeclare meriti. Hoc igitur fato Histiaeus functus est.
text.eng: 179.— Aristagoras, while besieging a certain town, was killed. Histiaeus, however, tyrant of Miletus, who was the author of the sedition, was dismissed by Darius from Susa and had set out to Sardis. When he arrived there, Artaphernes, the governor of Sardis, asked him why he thought the Ionians had been induced to defect from the king. When he said he did not know, Artaphernes, seeing he was lying, said: ‘Thus to you, Histiaeus, this matter stands: this sandal you made, which Aristagoras wore.’ When Artaphernes said this, Histiaeus, fearing he might be killed, fled. Then he went to Miletus. But the Milesians, gladly freed from Aristagoras, did not want to receive him. Therefore, when he attempted to enter Miletus by force at night, he was repelled, and even wounded in his thigh by someone of the Milesians. From there, he sailed to Byzantium and captured all the ships passing by, except those of people who declared themselves ready to obey Histiaeus. Soon after, he was captured by Artaphernes, who hanged the body from a cross, and sent the head, salted, to Susa to Darius. But Darius ordered that the head be washed, carefully treated, and given a proper burial, as of a man who had distinguished himself by his merits. Thus died Histiaeus.
XV.— THE BATTLE OF LADE.
text.lat: XV.— PUGNA LADE.

text.eng: The determination of the insurgents.
text.lat: Determination insurrectionum.

180.— Interim ad Miletum ingens et navalis et pedester exspectabatur exercitus. Nam Persarum duces, iunctis copiis, adversus Miletum proficiscebantur. Itaque Iones copias conscribere inceperunt. Convocato concilio placuit ne quis pedester exercitus, qui opponeretur Persis, cogeretur, sed ut muros defenderent ipsi per se Milesii: classis autem rebus omnibus instrueretur, atque quam primum ad Laden occurreret, et pugna navali decerneret. Est autem Lade parva insula, haud procul ab urbe Mileto. Erant autem Ionibus triremes trecentae quinquaginta tres. Naves vero, quas barbari habebant, erant sexcentae.
text.eng: 180.— Meanwhile, a great army, both naval and land forces, was expected at Miletus. For the leaders of the Persians, having joined forces, were advancing against Miletus. And so the Ionians began to enroll forces. It was resolved, upon assembling a council, that no land army should be raised to face the Persians but that the Milesians themselves should defend the walls; however, let the fleet be prepared in all respects, and as soon as possible come to Lade and engage in a naval battle. Lade is a small island, not far from the city of Miletus. The Ionians had three hundred and fifty-three triremes. The ships, however, that the barbarians had numbered six hundred.
The speech of Dionysius.
text.lat: Oratio Dionysio.

181.— Deinde vero, ubi in Lade insula Iones convenere, conciones habitae sunt, et quum alii apud eos verba fecissent, tum Dionysius, unus e ducibus, ita locutus est: ‘Nunc quum in novaculae acie sint res nostrae, utrum liberi simus, an servi; si quidem volueritis labores suscipere, erit id quidem nunc vobis molestum, sed poteritis esse liberi hostibus superatis: sin, disciplina militari intermissa, vos otio dederitis, nullam equidem spem habeo, poenam defectionis effugere vos posse. Sed me audite, mihique vos permittite; et vobis ego polliceor hostes magnam cladem accepturos.’
text.eng: 181.— Then indeed, when the Ionians had assembled on the island of Lade, speeches were delivered, and when others had spoken among them, then Dionysius, one of the leaders, spoke thus: 'Now when our affairs are on the razor's edge, whether we are free or slaves; if indeed you wish to undertake labors, it will indeed be burdensome to you now, but you will be able to be free with the enemies overcome: but if, having abandoned military discipline, you surrender yourselves to ease, I have no expectation that you will be able to escape the punishment of rebellion. But hear me, and allow yourselves to me; and I promise you that the enemies will suffer a great defeat.'
Dissatisfaction in the fleet.
text.lat: Dissatisfactio in classe.

182.— His auditis, Dionysio se permiserunt Iones. Tum ille quotidie, navibus longo ordine eductis, postquam remiges in discurrendo singulis navibus per binas alias exercuerat, et milites iusserat armatos in ponte stare, reliquam diei partem in ancoris tenebat. Et illi quidem ad septimum diem ei parebant; insequente vero die, quum impatientes essent talium laborum, molestiis et solis ardore lacessiti, hosce inter se sermones miscebant: ‘Cur hos exhaurimus labores? nam desipientes nosmet vano iactatori permisimus, qui tres modo naves in commune contulit. Quanto praestat, quidvis aliud, quam haec mala, pati! Agite, ne diutius huic homini pareamus!’ His dictis, nemo amplius mandata facere voluit, sed tanquam pedester exercitus, castris in insula positis, degebant in umbra, naves conscendere exercerique nolentes.
text.eng: 182.— Upon hearing this, the Ionians allowed themselves to Dionysius. Then daily, having led the ships out in a long line, after he had exercised the rowers by running the single ships through others two by two, and had ordered the soldiers to stand armed on the deck, he kept the rest of the day at anchor. And indeed up to the seventh day, they obeyed him; but on the following day, as they were unable to bear such labors, harassed by the discomforts and the heat of the sun, they muttered among themselves: 'Why do we endure these grindings? For we, foolishly, have entrusted ourselves to a vain boaster, who contributed only three ships to the common cause. How much better to suffer anything else than these evils! Come, let us no longer obey this man!' Having said this, no one wished to follow orders any longer, but like an infantry army, settling in camps on the island, they spent their time in the shade, unwilling to board and be exercised on the ships.
Defeat of the Ionians.
text.lat: Clades Ioniorum.

183.— Interim Persae cum classe contra progressi sunt. Tum Iones etiam naves suas longo ordine eduxerunt. Proelio commisso, nonnulli e ducibus, sublatis velis, deserta acie in fugam se receperunt. Reliqui vero, ubi plerosque socios prodere rem communem viderunt, noluerunt fugere, sed pugnarunt discurrentes per hostium naves, easque perrumpentes; donec, quum plures naves cepissent, ipsi suarum maiorem partem perdiderunt. Satis constat Ionas magno cum detrimento devictos esse. Dionysius vero, actum esse de classe intelligens, in Siciliam vela fecit; ex qua coortus praedari incepit: Graecis quidem navibus nunquam insidiatus, sed Carthaginiensibus ac Tyrrhenis.
text.eng: 183.— Meanwhile, the Persians advanced with their fleet. Then the Ionians also led out their ships in a long line. The battle having commenced, some of the leaders, having raised their sails, deserted the line and took to flight. The rest, however, when they saw many allies betray the common cause, did not wish to flee, but fought running through the enemy ships and breaking them; until, although they captured several ships, they themselves lost the greater part of their own. It is quite clear that the Ionians were defeated with great loss. Dionysius, understanding that all was over with the fleet, set sail for Sicily; from where he started plundering: never plotting against the Greek ships, but against the Carthaginians and Tyrrhenians.
Capture of Miletus.
text.lat: Captura Mileti.

184.— Persae, victis pugna navali Ionibus, terra marique Miletum oppugnarunt, et, suffossis muris, admotisque cuiusque generis machinis, cum ipsa arce ceperunt, sexto a defectione Aristagorae anno; captamque in servitutem redegerunt. Ita ea ipsa calamitate devicta urbs Miletus est, quae in illam oraculo praedicta erat.
text.eng: 184.— The Persians, having defeated the Ionians in the naval battle, attacked Miletus by land and sea, and having undermined the walls and brought up machines of every kind, they took it with the citadel itself, in the sixth year from the defection of Aristagoras; and they reduced it to slavery. Thus the city of Miletus was conquered with that very calamity, which had been predicted for it by the oracle.
The prediction of the oracle.
text.lat: Praedictio oraculi.

185.— Quum enim Argivi Delphorum oraculum de suae urbis salute consuluissent, alia de Argivis, alia de Milesiis edidit Pythia. Quae vero ad Miletum attinebant, haecce erant:— Tunc quoque, commentrix operum Milete malorum, Permultis coena et praestantia munera fies, Crinitisque pedes tua pluribus abluet uxor; Templi aliis nostri in Didymis sua cora manebit. Tunc igitur haec Milesiis acciderunt, quando virorum maior pars interfecta est a Persis longos capillos alentibus, et templum in Didymis exspoliatum igne concrematum est.
text.eng: 185.— For when the Argives had consulted the oracle of Delphi about their city's safety, Pythia issued different prophecies about the Argives and the Milesians. But concerning Miletus, these were the words:— Then also, Miletus, the contriver of evil works, You shall become a dinner for many people and splendid gifts will you be, And your wife will wash the feet of many long-haired men; Our temple at Didyma will keep its fate. Then these things happened to the Milesians, when the greater part of the men were killed by the long-haired Persians, and the temple at Didyma was spoiled and burnt with fire.
A too affecting drama.
text.lat: Drama nimis affectans.

186.— Athenienses autem et aliis multis modis monstraverunt, quantum ea Mileti expugnatione luctum perceperint; et, quum Phrynichus, poeta praeclarus, drama scripsisset docuissetque, de Mileti expugnatione, in lacrimas eruperunt omnes spectatores, et mille drachmis multatus est poeta, quod domesticarum calamitatum mentionem fecisset; et lege prohibitum est, ne quis amplius hoc dramate uteretur.
text.eng: 186.— The Athenians, however, showed in many different ways how much grief they felt over Miletus's capture; and when Phrynichus, a famous poet, had written and presented a drama about the capture of Miletus, all the spectators burst into tears, and the poet was fined a thousand drachmas for having mentioned the domestic calamities; and it was prohibited by law for anyone to use this drama anymore.
Failure of Mardonius’ expedition against Greece.
text.lat: Defectio expeditionis Mardonii contra Graeciam.

187.— Darius ob incensas Sardes poenam de Atheniensibus et Eretriensibus sumere constituit. Magnis igitur copiis Mardonium praefecit. Hic navem ipse conscendit, et cum reliquis navibus profectus est: pedestrem vero exercitum alii duces ad Hellespontum duxerunt. Primum Thasios classe aggressi, qui ne manus quidem contra illos sustulerant, sibi subiecerunt: tum pedestri exercitu Macedonas sub iugum miserunt. Dein Athon montem navibus circumvehi instituerunt. Sed maxima coorta tempestate, maximus navium numerus ad montem illisus est. Aiunt trecentas ex navibus periisse, et hominum amplius viginti millia. Pedestrem vero exercitum noctu aggressi Thraces, magnum militum numerum occiderunt. Itaque Mardonius, turpiter re gesta, copias in Asiam ducere coactus est.
text.eng: 187.— Darius, due to the burning of Sardis, decided to exact punishment on the Athenians and Eretrians. He therefore appointed Mardonius over large forces. He himself boarded a ship, and set out with the remaining ships: the other leaders led the land army to the Hellespont. First, they attacked the people of Thasos with the fleet, who did not even raise a hand against them and were subdued: then they subjected the Macedonians with a land army. Then they attempted to sail around Mount Athos with ships. But with a great storm arising, a very large number of ships were dashed against the mountain. They say three hundred ships perished, and more than twenty thousand men. The Thracians, however, attacked the land army by night and killed a large number of soldiers. Therefore Mardonius, having conducted the matter disgracefully, was forced to lead his forces into Asia.
XVI.— SPARTAN BREVITY.
text.lat: XVI.— SPARTANICA BREVITAS.

85.— Samii olim, a Polycrate expulsi, Spartam venerunt. Introducti apud Ephoros multa fecerunt verba, opem orantes. At illi responderunt: ‘Priora verba obliti sumus, posteriora non intelligimus.’ Post haec iterum introducti, saccum ferentes nihil aliud dixerunt, nisi haec verba: ‘Saccus frumento eget.’ His Spartani responderunt: ‘Nunc intelligimus: opem vobis praestabimus.’
text.eng: 85.— Once, the Samians, expelled by Polycrates, came to Sparta. Introduced to the Ephors, they made many words, begging for help. But they replied, 'We have forgotten the former words, we do not understand the latter.' After this, introduced again, carrying a sack, they said nothing else except these words: 'The sack needs grain.' To this the Spartans replied, 'Now we understand: we will provide you with help.'
XVII.— THE LAST DAYS OF MILTIADES.
text.lat: XVII.— ULTIMI DIES MILTIADIS.

text.eng: Miltiades attacks Paros.
text.lat: Miltiades Paron oppugnat.

205.— Post cladem Persis ad Marathonem illatam Miltiades, quum iam magni aestimatus esset apud Athenienses, maiore etiam fuit auctoritate. Itaque, quum petiisset septuaginta naves et exercitum, quamvis nollet dicere contra quam terram ducturus esset, diceret tamen, ‘ditaturum se eos, si sequerentur,’ Athenienses spe erecti instructas ei naves dederunt. Tum Miltiades accepto exercitu Paron navigavit; infensus enim erat Pariis ob Lysagoram quendam, qui eum olim accusaverat. Quum ad insulam pervenisset, Parios intra moenia repulsos obsedit: missoque praecone in urbem centum postulavit talenta, dicens, ‘nisi ea sibi darent, non se abducturum exercitum, donec vi cepisset urbem.’ At Parii omnibus modis operam dabant, ut urbem defenderent. Quem in finem et alia excogitabant, et, ubicunque pars muri expugnatu facilior videretur, ibi eam noctu duplo altiorem, quam prius erat, aedificabant.
text.eng: 205.— After the defeat inflicted on the Persians at Marathon, Miltiades, who was already highly esteemed by the Athenians, was held in even higher authority. Therefore, although he requested seventy ships and an army, he would not say against which land he intended to lead them; he said, however, that he would enrich them if they followed. The Athenians, uplifted by hope, gave him the equipped ships. Then Miltiades, having received the army, sailed to Paros, for he was incensed against the Parians on account of a certain Lysagoras, who had once accused him. When he had reached the island, he besieged the Parians, repulsed within their walls: and after sending a herald into the city, demanded one hundred talents, saying, 'unless they gave them to him, he would not remove the army until he had captured the city by force.' But the Parians exerted every effort to defend the city. To this end, they thought up various means, and wherever any part of the wall seemed easier to assault, they would there build it at night twice as high as it was before.
He meets with an accident.
text.lat: Accidens ferit illum.

206.— Narrant autem, Miltiadi, de incepti exitu dubitanti, in colloquium venisse mulierem captivam, cui nomen Timo, quaeque ministra aedis Dearum Inferarum esset. Hanc, postquam in conspectum venisset Miltiadis, consilium ei dedisse, ut, ‘si magni faceret capere Paron, exsequeretur quicquid ipsa illi esset indicatura.’ Deinde, auditis mulieris huius praeceptis, Miltiadem in tumulum, qui ante urbem esset, se contulisse, et murum aedi Cereris circumductum traiecisse, quum fores aperire non potuisset: tum ad ipsam deae aedem accessisse. Quum vero iam ad fores esset, subito horrore correptum, per eandem viam, qua venisset, rediisse, et desilientem de muro femur luxasse.
text.eng: 206.— They tell that, while Miltiades was doubting the outcome of his undertaking, a captive woman named Timo, who was a servant of the temple of the Infernal Goddesses, came into conversation with him. After she had come into Miltiades' sight, she gave him counsel, that 'if he greatly desired to capture Paros, he should follow whatever she would inform him.' Then, having heard the woman's instructions, Miltiades went to the mound outside the city and passed over the wall surrounding the temple of Ceres, as he could not open the doors. Then he approached the goddess's temple itself. But when he was already at the doors, suddenly seized with dread, he returned by the same path by which he had come, and while leaping down from the wall, he dislocated his thigh.
The voice of Apollo.
text.lat: Apollinis vox.

207.— Itaque Miltiades retro navigavit, neque opes afferens Atheniensibus, nec subacta Paro. Parii autem, obsidione liberati, quum intellexissent Dearum ministram Miltiadi indicasse quid faciendum esset, poenam huius rei caussa sumere voluerunt. Legates igitur Delphos miserunt, qui oraculum consulerent, ‘num ultimo supplicio afficerent Dearum ministram, quae hostibus viam indicasset ut patriam caperent: et sacra, quae viris monstrari nefas esset, Miltiadi aperuisset.’ At negavit Pythia, dicens, ‘non Timo ipsam huius rei caussam esse; sed quum in fatis esset ut vita male fungeretur Miltiades, hanc ei a diis missam esse, ducem malorum.’ Haec quidem Pythia Pariis respondit.
text.eng: 207.— Therefore, Miltiades sailed back, neither bringing wealth to the Athenians nor having subdued Paros. However, the Parians, freed from the siege, when they understood that the servant of the Goddesses had informed Miltiades of what had to be done, wanted to take punishment for this matter. Therefore, they sent ambassadors to Delphi to consult the oracle, whether they should inflict the ultimate punishment on the servant of the Goddesses who had shown the way to the enemies to capture their homeland, and revealed sacred things to Miltiades which were forbidden to be shown to men. But the Pythia denied it, saying, 'Timo is not herself the cause of this matter; but since it was fated that Miltiades should end his life badly, she was sent to him by the gods, as a guide to misfortune.' This indeed the Pythia replied to the Parians.
Disgrace and death of Miltiades.
text.lat: Dedecus et mors Miltiadis.

208.— Miltiadem autem, Paro reversum, quum alii omnes Athenienses accusabant, tum prae ceteris Xanthippus, Ariphronis filius; qui eum capitis reum egit apud populum, ut qui dolo malo Athenienses decepisset. Quam ad accusationem Miltiades ipse, quamvis praesens esset, non respondit: nec enim poterat, femore iam putrescente. Sed dum ille lectulo impositus in medio iacebat, caussam pro eo dixere amici, pugnae Marathoniae multam mentionem facientes. Favente autem illi adeo populo, ut capitis crimine eum absolveret, tamen propter damnum civitati illatum quingentis talentis multaret, Miltiades quidem haud multo post, carie ossium corrupto femore, mortuus est; quingenta autem illa talenta filius eius Cimon solvit.
text.eng: 208.— As for Miltiades, having returned from Paros, although all the other Athenians accused him, Xanthippus, the son of Ariphron, especially did so; who prosecuted him for capital punishment before the people as one who had deceitfully misled the Athenians. To this accusation Miltiades himself, although present, did not respond: for he could not, as his thigh was now rotting. But while he lay placed on a bed in the middle, his friends pleaded his case, making much mention of the battle of Marathon. With the people so favoring him that they acquitted him of the capital charge, nevertheless they fined him five hundred talents because of the damage brought to the state. Miltiades, indeed, died not long after, his thigh corrupted by caries of the bones; but his son Cimon paid those five hundred talents.
XVIII.— EXPEDITION OF CLEOMENES AGAINST ARGOS.
text.lat: XVIII.— EXPEDITIO CLEOMENIS ADVERSUS ARGOS.

text.eng: A subterranean stream.
text.lat: Fluvius subterraneus.

209.— Cleomeni, Spartano regi Delphicum oraculum consulenti, redditum erat responsum, ‘capturum illum Argos.’ Itaque in Argivorum fines cum exercitu profectus est. Postquam vero ad fluvium pervenit Erasinum, quem aiunt ex Stymphalio lacu effluere: (dicunt enim, hunc lacum, postquam in caecam voraginem se infuderit, rursus apparere in Argolide, et exinde hanc aquam vocari Erasinum ab Argivis); hostias flumini immolavit. Quum vero extis monstraretur, infelicem fore transitum, laudare se ait flumen, quod cives non proderet suos; sed ne sic quidem salvos evasuros Argivos.
text.eng: 209.— To Cleomenes, the Spartan king consulting the Delphic oracle, the response was given, 'he will capture Argos.' Therefore, he set out with his army into the territory of the Argives. When he reached the river Erasinus, which they say flows out from the Stymphalian lake (for they say this lake, after pouring into a blind chasm, reappears in Argolis, and thence this water is called Erasinus by the Argives), he sacrificed victims to the river. When it was shown by the entrails that the passage would be unlucky, he praised the river for not betraying its own citizens; but he still declared that the Argives would not escape safely.
The invasion of Argolis.
text.lat: Invasio Argolidis.

210.— Post haec retrogressus, et tauro mari immolato, navibus duxit exercitum in Argivorum fines. Qua re cognita, ad mare properant Argivi, opem suis laturi. Tum castra castris Lacedaemoniorum, haud magno spatio in medio relicto, opposuerunt. Ibi pugnam ex aperto non verebantur, sed ne dolo caperentur; Pythia enim oraculum ediderat his verbis: Verum, quando marem praevertet femina victrix. Inter et Argivos referet praelustris honorem; Tunc Argivarum reddet plerasque gementes; Occidet et telis sinuoso corpore serpens.
text.eng: 210.— After these things, having gone back and sacrificed a bull to the sea, he led his army by ships into the territory of the Argives. When this thing was known, the Argives hurried to the sea to bring aid to their own. Then they placed their camp opposite the camp of the Lacedaemonians, leaving not much space in between. There, they were not afraid of an open fight, but of being caught by a trick; for the Pythia had issued an oracle with these words: 'But when a victorious woman surpasses a man, Between and among the Argives, she will bring back illustrious honor; Then she will render most of the Argive women groaning; And the serpent with a winding body will fall by weapons.'
Turning the tables.
text.lat: Vertit epulas.

211.— Proinde consilium ceperunt utendi hostium praecone: idque ita exsecuti sunt, ut, quoties Spartanus praeco signum aliquod dedisset, Argivi etiam id ipsum facerent. Quos ubi Cleomenes cognovit idem exsequi, quod ipsius praeco significasset; imperat suis, ut, quando prandii signum edidisset praeco, tunc arma caperent, et Argivos adorirentur. Quod fecerunt Lacedaemonii. Nam, dum Argivi ex praeconis imperio prandium capiebant, subito illos adorti, magnum numerum interfecerunt, alios multos, qui in Argi lucum confugerant, circumsedentes ibi custodiverunt.
text.eng: 211.— Therefore, they took the plan to use the enemy's herald: and they executed it in such a way that whenever the Spartan herald gave a signal, the Argives would do the same thing. When Cleomenes noticed that they were doing the same as his herald had signaled, he ordered his men to take up arms and attack the Argives when the herald gave the signal for dinner. The Lacedaemonians did this. For, while the Argives were having lunch according to the herald's order, having suddenly attacked them, they killed a great number, and many others, who had fled into the grove of Argus, they besieged and guarded there.
Broken faith.
text.lat: Fides fracta.

212.— Deinde hoc fecit Cleomenes. Quum e transfugis quibusdam cognosset, quinam essent ex Argivis qui in sacro luco inclusi essent, misso praecone nominatim vocavit singulos, affirmans, ‘se pretium redemptionis illorum accepturum.’ Statutum autem apud Peloponnesios est pretium redemptionis, binae minae pro singulis captivis pendendae. Itaque quinquaginta fere Argivorum vocatos interfecit Cleomenes; quod reliquis, qui in luco erant, ignotum erat: quum enim magnus esset lucus, qui intus erant, non videbant quid faceret. Postremo vero unus illorum conscensa arbore vidit quid gereretur; atque exinde non amplius egrediebantur vocati.
text.eng: 212.— Then Cleomenes did this. When he learned from certain deserters who among the Argives were enclosed in the sacred grove, he sent a herald and called them by name, affirming that he would accept a ransom for them. It is decreed among the Peloponnesians that the ransom price is two minas for each captive. Thus, Cleomenes killed nearly fifty of the Argives who had been called; what was unknown to the rest, who were in the grove, was that, since the grove was large, those inside could not see what was happening. Finally, one of them climbed a tree and saw what was being done; and from that point on, they no longer came out when called.
Sacrilege.
text.lat: Sacrilegium.

213.— Tum vero Cleomenes hilotas omnes iussit materiem circa lucum congerere: quo facto lucum incendit. Iamque dum ardebat lucus, ex transfuga quaesivit, ‘cui deo sacer lucus esset.’ Qui ubi respondit, ‘Argi lucum esse;’ hoc audito Cleomenes, ingentem edens gemitum, ait: ‘O fatidice Apollo, magnopere me decepisti, quum me Argos capturum diceres. Suspicor enim exisse mihi id vaticinium.’ Post haec, maiore exercitus parte Spartam dimissa, ipse cum mille fortissimis ad Iunonis templum se contulit, sacra facturus. Quum autem sacrificare vellet, vetuit sum sacerdos dicens, nefas esse peregrinum sacra ibi facere. At Cleomenes, iussis hilotis abductum ab ara sacerdotem verberare, ipse sacra fecit; quo facto Spartam rediit.
text.eng: 213.— Then Cleomenes commanded all the Helots to gather wood around the grove: having done so, he set fire to the grove. And while the grove was burning, he asked from a deserter to which god the grove was sacred. When he responded that it was sacred to Argive, Cleomenes, hearing this, let out a loud groan, saying: 'O prophetic Apollo, you have greatly deceived me, when you said I would capture Argos. I suspect that the prophecy was meant for me.' After this, having dismissed most of his army to Sparta, he went with a thousand of the bravest to the temple of Juno, to perform sacred rites. When he wanted to sacrifice, the priest forbade him, saying it was unlawful for a foreigner to perform sacred rites there. But Cleomenes, having ordered the priest to be taken away from the altar and beaten by the Helots, performed the rites himself; having done so, he returned to Sparta.
Trial and defence of Cleomenes.
text.lat: Iudicium et defensio Cleomenis.

214.— Spartae vero inimici eum apud ephoros reum egerunt: aiebant enim, ‘pecunia corruptum Argos non cepisse, quum capere facillime potuisset.’ At ille respondit, ‘postquam lucum Argo sacrum cepisset, visum sibi exisse vaticinium dei: quare non tentandam urbem putavisse, priusquam sacris factis cognovisset, utrum traditurus sibi eam Deus esset, an impedimento futurus. Litanti autem sibi in Iunonis aede, ex simulacri pectore effulsisse flammam: itaque intellexisse se, Argos capi non posse: nam, si ex capite simulacri effulsisset flamma, capturum se urbem fuisse: quum vero e pectore effulsisset, effecta esse omnia quae Deus fieri voluisset.’ Itaque criminis absolutus est.
text.eng: 214.— In Sparta, his enemies brought a charge against him before the ephors: they said that he was bribed with money not to capture Argos, when he could have done it very easily. But he replied that after he captured the sacred grove of Argos, he thought the god's prophecy had come true; therefore, he thought the city should not be tried before he discovered, by performing the sacred rites, whether God had decided to surrender it to him or if he would be an obstacle. However, as he was performing rites in the temple of Juno, a flame flashed from the chest of the statue; thus he understood that Argos could not be taken: for if the flame had flashed from the head of the statue, he would have taken the city; but since it flashed from the chest, everything that the God wanted to be done was accomplished. Therefore, he was acquitted of the crime.
Madness and suicide of Cleomenes.
text.lat: Furor et suicidium Cleomenis.

215.— Postea furor eum invasit: nam quoties Spartanus obviam ei veniret, huic sceptrum in faciem infligebat. Quae quum faceret, et alienata mente esset, vinxerunt eum propinqui, et ligno alligaverunt. At ille, ita vinctus, ubi vidit unum custodem, egressis ceteris, solum relictum, cultrum postulavit: quem quum ei statim dare nollet custos, minatus est homini quae deinde illi facturus esset; donec minis territus cultrum dedit. Tum vero, sumpto ferro, Cleomenes, initio a cruribus facto, misere se ipse laceravit. Postremo, ubi ad ventrem perventum est, hunc etiam dissecuit, donec animam efflavit.
text.eng: 215.— Afterwards madness seized him: for whenever a Spartan would meet him, he would strike him in the face with a scepter. When he did this and was of alienated mind, his family bound him and tied him to a wooden beam. But he, thus bound, when he saw one guard, the others having left, was left alone, asked for a knife: but when the guard did not immediately give it to him, he threatened the man with what he would then do to him; until, terrified by threats, the guard gave the knife. Then indeed, having taken the knife, Cleomenes, starting from his legs, miserably lacerated himself. Finally, when he came to his stomach, he even cut it open, until he breathed his last.
Explanations of the act.
text.lat: Explicationes actus.

216.— Argivi aiebant ‘hoc eum fecisse, quoniam Argivos, qui e pugna in lucum Argi se recepissent, inde abductos trucidasset, ipsumque spreta relligione lucum incendisset.’ At Spartani arbitrantur, ‘non in furorem actum fuisse Cleomenem a deo quoquam, sed contraxisse morem bibendi merum, eaque de caussa in furorem incidisse.’ Haec apud Spartanos de Cleomene fama est.
text.eng: 216.— The Argives said 'he did this because the Argives, who had taken refuge in the grove of Argos from the battle, were dragged from there and slaughtered, and he had even burned the grove with religion having been despised.' However, the Spartans believe that Cleomenes hadn’t been driven to madness by any god, but he had contracted the habit of drinking neat wine, and from that cause had fallen into madness. This is the opinion among the Spartans about Cleomenes.
XIX.—  A DIFFICULTY.
text.lat: XIX.— DIFFICULTAS.

text.eng: Which is the eldest?
text.lat: Quis maior natu?

217.— Uxor Aristodemi, regis Spartanorum, peperit gemellos. Aristodemus autem brevi tempore mortuus est. Tum Lacedaemonii decreverunt regem nominandum eum ex filiis qui maior esset natu. Quum vero nescirent, utrum ex illis eligerent, qui similes inter se et aequales erant, matrem interrogarunt. At illa dixit, ‘ne se quidem ipsam internoscere.’ Itaque Lacedaemonii, quum incerti essent, legatos Delphos miserunt, ut consulerent quid fieri deberet. Pythia autem imperavit, ut ‘puerum utrumque regem haberent, sed magis honorarent natu maiorem.’
text.eng: 217.— The wife of Aristodemus, king of the Spartans, gave birth to twins. Aristodemus, however, died in a short time. Then the Lacedaemonians decided that a king should be chosen from the sons who was the eldest. Since they did not know which of them to choose, as they were alike and equal, they asked the mother. But she said, 'not even she herself could distinguish.' Therefore, the Lacedaemonians, since they were uncertain, sent envoys to Delphi to consult what should be done. The Pythia commanded that 'they should have both children as king, but honor the eldest more.'
Another judgment of Solomon.
text.lat: Alterum iudicium Salomonis.

218.— Quo accepto responso, quum nihilominus incerti essent, quo pacto reperirent, uter maior natu esset, consilium dedit vir cui nomen Panitae erat. Is vero suasit Lacedaemoniis, ‘ut observarent matrem, viderentque utrum puerorum lavaret priorem, priorique cibum praeberet.’ Narrant illos, observantes matrem deprehendisse eam semper et in cibo praebendo et in lavando alterum ex pueris praeferentem. Credidisse igitur Lacedaemonios hunc, a matre alteri praelatum, natu esse maiorem. Et hos ipsos fratres per omne vitae tempus discordes inter se fuisse narrant.
text.eng: 218.— Upon receiving this response, although they were still uncertain of how to discover which was the eldest, a man named Panitae gave advice. He suggested to the Lacedaemonians, 'that they observe the mother and see which of the boys she washed first and to whom she gave food first.' They say that by observing the mother, they discovered that she consistently preferred one of the boys both in feeding and washing. Therefore, the Lacedaemonians believed that this one, preferred by the mother, was the elder. And they say that these very brothers were at odds throughout their entire lives.
XX.— A DISTINCTION WITHOUT A DIFFERENCE.
text.lat: XX.— DISTINCTIO SINE DIFFERENTIA.

text.eng: 89.— Alexander, the king of Macedonia, questioned a captured thief with these words: 'By what right do you attack the sea?' The thief, fearing nothing, replied: 'You and I use the same right; yet I have a single small ship; therefore I am called a thief: but you command great fleets and armies; thus you are called a conqueror.'
text.lat: 89.— Alexander, Macedoniae rex, latronem captum his verbis interrogavit: ‘Quo tandem iure mare lacessis?’ Latro nihil timens respondit: ‘Ego et tu eodem iure utimur; unam autem parvam navem habeo; latro igitur vocor: tu autem magnis classibus et exercitibus praees; itaque victor vocaris.’

text.eng: XXI.— ANECDOTES.
text.lat: XXI.— ANECDOTAE.

text.eng: Diligence rewarded.
text.lat: Diligentia remunerata.

264.— Antisthenes philosophus iuvenes monebat ut verbis suis studerent, sed paucissimi ex iis monito parebant. Tandem iratus omnes e conspectu abire iussit. Diogenes tamen philosophi verba audiendi magno studio captus, ad eum saepius veniebat, neque abire volebat. Itaque Antisthenes minatus est se caput eius pulsaturum; quumque vidisset, Diogenem minis non exterreri, hoc fecit.
text.eng: 264.— Antisthenes, the philosopher, was advising the young men to devote themselves to his words, but very few of them obeyed his admonition. At last, angry, he ordered them all to leave his sight. However, Diogenes, captivated by a great zeal for the philosopher's words, would often come to him and did not want to leave. Antisthenes, therefore, threatened that he would hit his head; and when he saw that Diogenes was not terrified by the threats, he did this.

text.lat: Anaxagoras and Pericles.
text.eng: Anaxagoras and Pericles.

text.lat: 265.— Anaxagoras philosophus illustris erat, non modo prae opibus et genere, sed etiam ob animum sapientem. Ut sese studiis omnino dederet, amicis opes suas tradidit, et Athenas adiit. Quo ubi pervenit, apud eum veniebat Pericles, vir praestanti indole et virtute, pauperibus idem liberalissimus. Accidit tamen ut, rebus publicis magnopere studens, Pericles Anaxagorae oblivisci videretur. Quod aegerrime ferens senex, veste obducto capite, fame perire constituit. Quibus auditis Pericles, ad Anaxagoram se contulit, eumque oravit ut viveret, et sapientem animum servaret, lucemque illam, quae sibi tantum boni praebuisset. Cui Anaxagoras, ‘Pericles,’ inquit, ‘ii, quibus opus est lucerna, oleum praebent.’ Itaque ex eo tempore, Pericles magno studio Anaxagoram semper coluit.
text.eng: 265.— Anaxagoras was a distinguished philosopher, not only by wealth and birth but also by his wise mind. In order to give himself entirely to studies, he assigned his wealth to friends and went to Athens. When he arrived there, Pericles, a man of excellent character and virtue, equally liberal to the poor, used to visit him. It happened, however, that as Pericles, deeply engrossed in public affairs, appeared to forget Anaxagoras. The old man, greatly troubled, with his head wrapped in a garment, decided to die of hunger. Upon hearing this, Pericles went to Anaxagoras, asked him to live and preserve his wise mind, and retain that light which had given him so much good. To which Anaxagoras replied, ‘Pericles,’ he said, ‘those who need a lamp provide it with oil.’ Henceforth, Pericles always revered Anaxagoras with great earnestness.
XXII.— THE AETHIOPIANS.
text.lat: XXII.— AETHIOPES.

text.eng: Some account of the Aethiopians, to whom Cambyses sends an embassy.
text.lat: De Aethiopibus narratur, ad quos Cambyses legatos mittit.

281.— Cambyses expeditionem in Aethiopas facere constituit. Itaque speculatores misit nonnullos ex Ichthyopbagis, qui Aethiopum sermone callebant. Hos ad Aethiopas misit, edoctos quid dicere deberent, et dona ferentes, pallium, armillas aureas, et vini utrem. Dicuntur autem hi Aethiopes fortissimi et pulcherrimi esse omnium hominum: quemcunque etiam ex iis pulcherrimum et corporis viribus praestantissimum indicant, hunc regem faciunt. Ad hos igitur homines ubi advenerunt Icthyophagi, haec verba fecerunt: ‘Cambyses Persarum rex, tecum hospitium, o rex, iungere cupiens, nos misit, et dona tibi haec dat, quorum usu et ipse maxime delectatur.’
text.eng: 281.— Cambyses decided to make an expedition against the Aethiopians. Therefore, he sent spies composed of some of the Ichthyophagi, who understood the language of the Aethiopians. He sent them to the Aethiopians, instructed on what they should say, and bearing gifts, a cloak, gold bracelets, and a wineskin. These Aethiopians are said to be the strongest and most beautiful of all men: and they choose as king the one they deem the most beautiful and strongest in body. When the Ichthyophagi arrived at these men, they said these words: 'Cambyses, king of the Persians, desiring to form friendship with you, O king, has sent us, and he gives these gifts to you, which he himself enjoys most.'
The answer of the Aethiopian king.
text.lat: Responsum regis Aethiopis.

282.— Quibus Aethiops intelligens venire eos ut speculatores, in hunc modum respondit: ‘Neque Persarum rex vos misit dona ferentes; nec vos vera dicitis: nec ille vir bonus est: nam si bonus esset, non cupivisset aliud imperium praeter suum, nec in servitutem redegisset homines, qui nulla illum iniuria affecissent. Itaque rex Aethiopum regi Persarum suadet, ut quando ita facile arcubus uti huius modi Persae potuerint, tunc expeditionem in nos suscipiat.’ His dictis sagittam ex arcu emisit iisque qui venerunt arcum tradidit.
text.eng: 282.— To this, the Aethiopian, understanding that they came as spies, responded in this manner: 'Neither did the king of the Persians send you bearing gifts; nor do you speak the truth: nor is he a good man: for if he were good, he would not have desired any empire other than his own, nor subjugated those who had not wronged him. Therefore, the king of the Aethiopians advises the king of the Persians that when they can so easily use bows as such Persians, then they may undertake an expedition against us.' Having said this, he shot an arrow from a bow and handed it to those who came.
He examines the presents.
text.lat: Dona examinavit.

283.— Tum sumpto pallio, quaesivit quid esset, et quonam modo factum. Cui quum vera respondissent Ichthyophagi, ‘dolosos hos homines esse,’ inquit, ‘et dolosa illorum pallia.’ Deinde de armillis quaesivit. Quumque de hoc ornatu dixissent, ridens rex, quum compedes esse putasset, ait, ‘apud ipsos meliores hisce compedes esse.’ Ubi ad vinum venit, valde delectatus potu, deinde interrogavit, ‘quonam cibo uteretur rex, et quodnam esset homini Persae longissimum vitae spatium.’ Et illi ‘pane vesci,’ aiebant; ‘octoginta vero annos terminum esse longissimum vitae hominis datum.’ Tum Aethiops, ‘nil mirum esse,’ ait, ‘quum tali cibo vescantur, tam exiguum eos vivere annorum numerum; qui ne tot quidem annos vivere possent, nisi hoc potu uterentur: hoc enim uno a Persis se superari.’
text.eng: 283.— Then, having taken the cloak, he asked what it was, and how it was made. When the Ichthyophagi answered truthfully, he said, 'These men are deceitful, and so are their cloaks.' Then he asked about the bracelets. And when they explained about this ornament, the king laughed, thinking they were chains, and said, 'Even better chains than these exist among us.' When he came to the wine, he was greatly delighted by the drink, then he asked, 'What does the king eat, and what is the longest span of life for a Persian man?' And they said, 'They eat bread; eighty years, indeed, is the longest term granted to a man's life.' Then the Aethiopian said, 'It is no wonder that they live for such a few number of years, since they eat such food; they would not even reach so many years unless they used this drink: in this alone they surpass the Persians.'
He astonishes the spies.
text.lat: Speculatores miratur.

284.— Vicissim interrogantibus regem Ichthyophagis de vitae spatio et ciborum genere: ‘ad centum et viginti annos,’ ait, ‘pervenire eorum plerosque; cibum vero esse carnem coctam; potum lac.’ Quumque mirarentur speculatores quod de annorum numero dixisset, ad fluvium ab illo ductos se esse referebant, e quo lota pellis splendida facta fuisset, quasi olei fluvius esset; odorem autem suavissimum spirare illam aquam; et diu vivere Aethiopas quod hac aqua uterentur. A fluvio discedentes, ductos se fuisse narrabant in locum quo vincti homines custodirentur, ibique cunctos aureis vinctos compedibus vidisse. Est enim apud hos Aethiopas aes metallorum pretiosissimum.
text.eng: 284.— When they asked the king in turn about the life span and kinds of food: 'Up to one hundred and twenty years,' he said, 'many of them reach; their food is cooked meat; their drink, milk.' When the spies marveled at the number of years he had mentioned, they reported that they were led to a river by him, from which water, when washed, made the skin shine, as if it was a river of oil; and the water had a most pleasant aroma; and the Aethiopians lived long because they used this water. Leaving the river, they reported being taken to a place where bound men were kept, and they saw all chained in golden shackles. For among these Aethiopians, bronze is the most precious of metals.
The failure of the Expedition.
text.lat: Expeditionis defectio.

285.— Speculatores, postquam ista omnia spectaverant, reversi sunt. Qui ubi haec renuntiarunt, Cambyses valde iratus, bellum Aethiopibus inferre constituit, nullo de commeatibus mandato dato, nec secum reputans in ultima terrarum suscipi hanc expeditionem. At milites, quamdiu e terra nancisci aliquid poterant, radices comedentes vitam sustentarunt; ubi vero in arenas pervenere, dirum facinus nonnulli eorum fecere: sorte enim delectum decimum quemque comederunt. Qua re cognita Cambyses, omissa adversus Aethiopas expeditione, domum reversus est.
text.eng: 285.— The spies, after viewing all those things, returned. When they reported these things, Cambyses, very angry, decided to wage war against the Aethiopians, without giving any mandate about supplies, nor considering that this expedition was undertaken to the ends of the earth. But the soldiers, as long as they could find something from the land, ate roots to sustain life; when they came to the sands, some of them committed a terrible deed: by lot they chose every tenth one and ate. After this was known, Cambyses, abandoning the expedition against the Aethiopians, returned home.
